A simple but efficient cop movie with important stakes and a great introduction to the character by Eastwood. This one really aged well even 50 years later.

Don't ever make the mistake of crossing Harry Callahan, a SFPD detective carrying a magnum weapon that will be brought into action at the smallest provocation. As the story begins, Harry has a new partner, a Mexican, Chico Gonzalez, that has come to the police force on his own will, although he has a higher education. Harry is not too happy, but goes along with the choice that was made for him.The mad sniper, Scorpio, has been shooting people from rooftops all over the city. Harry and Chico are sent to deal with this mad person. Harry gets lucky when the criminal makes the mistake of kidnapping a young girl, after his demands for two hundred thousand dollars is not met. Harry chases him into a football field and shoots from a distance, wounding the man. Harry, who is clearly upset, pokes at the man's injured man, but Scorpio warns Harry that even criminals have rights and wants to be treated as a law abiding citizen.Harry finds out in the worst way the D.A., William Rothko, decides to set free Scorpio because according to what he learned about the case, Harry violated a number of laws that protect the criminals, the same way that in his estimation decent folks deserve them. Scorpio does everything in his power, even paying another scum bag, to beat him to a pulp, and accuses Harry of doing it.The last thing Scorpio does is to kidnap a bus carrying some suburban children as they return home. Harry, who is asked to go after Scorpio, has another thing in mind. Knowing what route the man is taking, he bides his time to trap the evil man in a finale that shows no mercy for the man that had no scruples in harming indiscriminately.Don Siegel was the director of "Dirty Harry", and as he had proved with the earlier "Coogan's Bluff", he knew he had a sure winner in this action film that reunited him with Clint Eastwood. Mr. Siegel was a man that understood the genre, as he shows here. Working with the screenplay by Harry Julian and Rita Fink, the action moves to San Francisco, which lends itself to be the backdrop of this rapid paced crime story.Clint Eastwood played Harry Callahan with his usual style. His Harry was a man of action, not given to say much about himself. Reni Santoni is his partner, Chico Gonzalez. Andrew Robinson is Scorpio, the criminal that underestimates Harry's resolution in getting him to justice and has to pay a high price for it. The supporting cast included Harry Guardino, John Vernon, Josef Sommers, and John Larch, among others.Carl Pingitore's editing adds to the enjoyment of the picture. So does the jazzy score by Lalo Schiffrin, a composer of many successful films and television series. Bruce Surtees camera work shows splendid views of scenic San Francisco the way it looked in those years.Ultimately this was the Don Siegel-Clint Eastwood show that teamed up to bring a fast paced entertainment that looks as good today, as when it was shot.

I'm not sure if I was expecting more or what, this film was alright. Maybe the slow-yet-fast/consistent pacing and filmmaking had to do with that, not in the sense of that being a bad thing: but rather in the sense that, what was happening, didn't necessarily make up for it.Take Nicolas Winding Refn's Too Old to Die Young for example. That's the only work of his I've seen so far, besides Bronson. And I don't remember much about its filmmaking. But I'm aware he's done his thing similarly before. That show/long film seemed to almost rely on these super long shots: and the camerawork; it seemed to express passion for one's craft. His style seems to be divisive: a lot of people hated that in the show, from what I've seen, in some of his films, too. I can understand that, but I liked it, possibly because the narrative was captivating.In this film, that style could've been an aspect more negative than positive. At the same time, the story/narrative didn't seem all that captivating to me. That likely made the directing style stand out more which, in turn, affected the already-lacking captivation in a domino effect. If you're to go that route, the story should carry its weight, or that route will probably have the opposite effect.The best aspects of this film were undoubtedly the directing, camerawork, the cinematography, and to a lesser extent, the soundtrack. At first, the soundtrack was alright; different. But upon some reflection, I concluded that 'different' is good, and it was eerie and all that, fitting each instance. The other aspects were the cream of the crop, though.I liked that ironic scene with the monologue. The way Clint Eastwood did that scene, said that monologue, and his smirk at the end, were great, and how it came full circle at the end. The first time was so smooth and chill, which added to it tremendously. It's no wonder that moment became a classic. It's very memorable. I'd say that, and how it came full circle, was the best part of the film.Performance-wise, it seems like people have commended Clint Eastwood. It didn't stand out to me. Neither did most of the performances, but not in a 'these performances are bad' way. But Andrew Robinson's performance was slightly notable, I suppose. Besides him, nobody's performances stood out like a sore thumb, in a good or bad way. They were all acceptable.(Upon further reflection, Clint Eastwood's performance was pretty good. I don't know what I was thinking.)One thing about the ending that stood out to me was the lack of a score. I'm not too sure how I feel about that. It was a change of pace from the usual; I guess that's good in and of itself. Not only that, it acted as a way to set that feeling of seriousness to what was happening. Yet, I don't know: something was lacking. That way of doing things should be utilized more, for sure. It just didn't seem to be cut out for this film.All-in-all, I'm pleased with this film. It was an alluring watch due to the elements I've mentioned. It could've been more entertaining, but that's not a big deal. It's a good thing that I got lucky seeing this film on Youtube off to the side as I was watching another video. That's the reason why I ended up watching it. Who knows how far down the road it would've taken had that not happened. It'll probably be a while until I watch the next film in the series.Other thoughts:The woman at the beginning sort of looked like Maggie Lawson."Yeah, well, when an adult male is chasing a female with intent to commit (the R word), I shoot the bastard. That's my policy." vs. "When I see five weirdos dressed in togas stabbing a guy in a park, I shoot the bastards. That's my policy." in The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad! I'm guessing inspiration for that line came from this film.I was shocked that this film wasn't a one-off but rather the first film out of a film series. Not even a trilogy: a series. I did not know that. At all. I think that was a mildly good thing, though. If I had known, I probably wouldn't have watched it yet. Film trilogies and film series make me feel obligated to watch all of them in a row.

Dirty Harry is a great movie, and one of the best by mega star, Clint Eastwood.  Harry is the kind of cop who does whatever is necessary to get results.  The squinty eyed star is perfect in this action packed and sometimes disturbing hit.  Eastwood, with his unique brand of humor, and massive handgun steal the show, but with strong competition from Andy Robinson, who plays the bad guy, Scorpio.  Robinson is great in the role because by the end of the movie, you really want to see him dead, at any cost.  He has no redeemable features.  Even anti-violent people would love to see him get punished.  This view of Scorpio is also helped by the eerie music which accompanies his scenes.This is a great movie and deserves it status as a classic  10/10

reviews.review_title: A Cop Who Gets Every Dirty Job That Comes Along
reviews.content: "Inspector Harry Callahan" (Clint Eastwood) is a detective for the San Francisco Police Department who has just been assigned to a case involving a psychopathic killer who goes by the nickname of "Scorpio" (Andrew Robinson) and has demanded payment from the city or he will kill again. In addition to the new assignment, Inspector Callahan has also been given a new partner named "Chico" (Reni Santoni) who he is tasked with training as well. And if that wasn't bad enough it appears that management within the police department has adopted a new approach which frowns upon "Dirty Harry's" brutal--but effective--tactics. Now rather than reveal any more I will just say that this was a good movie when it first came out over 45 years ago and it remains very entertaining even today. That being said, for those viewers who might enjoy a movie of this type then I heartedly recommend it and I have rated it accordingly. Above average.

It could have been Frank Sinatra as the lead character if he hadn't injured his hand, you can't really see it, and thankfully the right actor got it, and it is a fantastic film from director Don Siegel (The Beguiled, The Shootist). Insp. 'Dirty' Harry Callahan (Clint Eastwood) is the San Francisco cop who has little respect for almost anyone, and uses unorthodox methods to get the job done, mostly homicide cases. The city is being terrorised by a psychopathic sniper known as Scorpio (Hellraiser's Andrew Robinson), and Harry is assigned to the case, along with new rookie partner Insp. Chico Gonzalez (Reni Santoni) to investigate this madman's murders and track him down. Scorpio is asking for $100,000 from the city, i.e. The Mayor (John Vernon) otherwise he'll kill again. Eventually they agree to pay Scorpio, and Harry volunteers to make the drop off, but ends up running from phone to phone when the killer gives him numerous ones to go to. Harry did manage to stick a knife in the killer's leg, so they know who they are looking for, but when Harry catches him, they have no evidence to convict him. After trying to get Harry in trouble hiring someone to beat him up saying it was him, Scorpio eventually resorts to kidnapping a bus load of kids and the Bus Driver (Ruth Kobart) demanding payment, and Harry is determined to stop him once and for all. Also starring Harry Guardino as Lt. Al Bressler, John Larch as The Chief, John Mitchum as Insp. Frank DiGiorgio, Mae Mercer as Mrs. Russell, Lyn Edgington as Norma, Woodrow Parfrey as Mr. Jaffe, Josef Sommer as Dist. Atty. William T. Rothko, William Paterson as Judge Bannerman, James Nolan as Liquor Store Owner, Maurice S. Argent as Sid Kleinman, Jo De Winter as Miss Willis and Craig G. Kelly as Sgt. Reineke. This is probably the most well known and finest of all Eastwood's performances, Robinson is also brilliant as the gibbering psycho, Siegel directs this film very stylishly to make all action scenes very exciting along with great use of the Golden Gate locations, a must-see crime thriller. Clint Eastwood was number 18 on The 100 Greatest Movie Stars, and he was number 61 on The 100 Greatest Pop Culture Icons, Harry Callahan was number 17 on 100 Years, 100 Heroes & Villains, the film was number 51 on 100 Years, 100 Quotes ("You've got to ask yourself one question: 'Do I feel lucky?' Well do you, punk!"), and it was number 41 on 100 Years, 100 Thrills. Oustanding!

reviews.review_title: Uphold the law, Dirty Harry style.
reviews.content: In essence this is being a very typical detective story, in which a tough cop has to stop a killer. "Dirty Harry" is of course a far from typical movie though. There are several things about it that makes this movie more special- and unlike any other genre attempt.The first reason is also the most obvious one; its main character. Clint Eastwood plays a classic character, in the same vein as for instance a Steve McQueen- or Charles Bronson, in his best days, type of character. A tough looking guy, who backs down for nobody or anything and with an high sense for justice and righteousness. A good guy acting and thinking as a bad guy. Really, these type of characters often have more bad guy characteristics to them but yet they still work out really well as good guys, since they 'fight' for the right causes and are on the good side, even though they quite often break the law.It's all very consistent with the raw and gritty style of the movie, courtesy of director Don Siegel. It's the sort of movie that feels realistic and is not just purely made to entertain. It has very little exaggerated moments in the sense of moments that feel like they couldn't ever happen in real life.You could say that it's also being a slow moving- and not all that spectacular movie because of that but I would mostly disagree. It's fast paced with also plenty of excitement and action in it. Of course when compared to modern genre movies it's nothing too spectacular but it definitely has other qualities to it. It's rawness being one of them, which makes this a very straightforward and effective movie within its genre.There really aren't too many distractions in this movie. It focuses just on the Dirty Harry character and all he is concerned about is getting the bad guy. So no other drama, no distracting love story, or other sentimental ploys. The movie is what it is and it doesn't ever pretend to be more than it truly is.And the story as it is, is just fine. It has plenty of depth and good developments in it, all driven by a good and interesting crime story. It's not really being predictable in any way, which is also mainly due to its villainous character, played by Andrew Robinson. He's a very unpredictable and psychotic character, that no one is safe for. Not every plot development is convincing but it helps to let the story move along and to keep things fresh and interesting.A great, gritty, cop movie, even still in today's perspective.8/10 http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

reviews.review_title: The General Public's Answer To "Billy Jack"
reviews.content: For those who don't understand the review title, "Billy Jack" was a movie about an American Indian former Green Beret who wages a one-man battle against redneck bullies, including a corrupt sheriff, who harass the local members of the counterculture. Dirty Harry Callahan wages a battle against a murderous and brutal hippie-like all-around scumbag who menaces the general public.Yes, both movies are period pieces. "Billy Jack" was meant to show the peaceful hippies being helpless against redneck bullies. "Dirty Harry" shows that the counterculture was no benign force, with drug use, sexual diseases and unwanted pregnancies, and violent crime including terrorism rising sharply by the 1970's. The police forces were viewed as helpless, and the movie depicts this view, with Dirty Harry as the hero who fights back against all the evils. Yes, the characters are one-dimensional and the story is trite, but the movie effectively conveys the message it intends to.

I mean really..... what needs to be said? It's Clint in a bad ass role. Only funny thing is how he walks with zero limp after taking a 9MM to the quad muscle haha then climbs a fence and scales over the top after 2 broken ribs later in the movie. Haha but again.... he's a super hero so who cares haha.

reviews.review_title: This is a bit of an uneven action movie that has some redeeming elements
reviews.content: Dirty Harry (1971) is a movie I watched for the first time in a long time on HBOMAX. The storyline follows a serial killer in San Francisco that's kidnaps people, demands a ransom and kills them anyway even after getting paid. A police officer decides it's time to play outside the rules to bring down the killer. This movie is directed by Don Siegel (Invasion of the Body Snatchers) and stars Clint Eastwood (Pale Rider), John Vernon (Killer Klowns from Outer Space), Andrew Robinson (Hellraiser), Harry Guardino (The Enforcer) and Reni Santoni (Cobra). The storyline for this picture hasn't aged well - cops taking Justice into their own hands and killing criminals they feel deserve it. I remember loving this film as a kid and cringing most of the movie now. Eastwood is excellent as the main character, though it's funny he doesn't know the laws and is corrected about his interpretations of them throughout the movie. His intensity and demeanor sets the tone for the movie and his "do you feel lucky punk" line is legendary. The mayor being so soft was kind of funny. The soundtrack for this is very good as is the villain and closing scene. This is a bit of an uneven action movie that has some redeeming elements. I'd score this a 7/10 and strongly recommend seeing it.

Clint Eastwood plays veteran, no-nonsense San Francisco Police Inspector "Dirty" Harry Callahan, who carries '44 Magnum, and is not afraid to use it on the assorted bank robbers or murderers that come his way. His current case involves a mysterious sniper(calling himself Scorpio) who is killing random people in the city, and threatens to kill more unless a ransom is paid. Harry pays him the ransom money, but later tracks him down and arrests him after a memorable showdown in a football stadium. Harry is reprimanded for not following proper procedure, and Scorpio(Andrew Robinson, quite good) resumes his campaign of terror against the city in general, and Harry in particular...Hard-hitting police drama is among the best ever made, stylish and riveting direction by Don Siegel, a thought-provoking and mesmerizing story, and the dynamic of good but disillusioned cop Harry against the evil madness that Scorpio represents. Audiences loved seeing a cop like Harry take on crime, and this situation is still relevant today.An all-time classic, not to be missed.

I saw this movie when it was first released to theaters. Recently it showed up on HD cable, on UHD, and I decided to watch it. I had forgotten what a cliché-riddled piece of garbage this movie really is. It is an insult to the intelligence, and there simply is no way that any half-intelligent human being could appreciate this movie. The crucial point in the story line is when the prosecuting attorney lectures Harry for having violated the murderous creep's civil rights. Because none of the evidence is deemed admissible in court, they have to release the creep, and it is all Harry's fault. This is all preposterous. There is no semblance to reality, although I am sure that many people do not understand this and believe that creeps are routinely allowed to walk free by sentimental liberals. This movie may in fact have a lot to do with the misinformed belief that many people have, that liberal judges and lawyers are always letting creeps walk free.This movie is pathetically bad. It has no redeeming qualities whatsoever. The acting is as horrible as the story, including the acting by Clint Eastwood. The fact that this movie was every popular at all, is a very sad commentary on our culture.

Classic made by Don Siegel with Clint Eastwood as Callahan or Dirty Harry. Why this is a classic, the way it was shot and the acting. Clint does what he does best but it's the killer, Scorpio, loosely based on the Zodiac killer, performed by Andrew Robinson that takes this flick to a higher level.It spawned a franchise that was popular and it even created the Death Wish franchise. It's always great to see how a city looked back then when it was shot. Even as it doesn't has any cruel or gory shots it does have full frontal nudity a thing that was added a lot in flicks back then. Everything was possible as it shows, a threesome, some strip joints with a free podium, yes this is the seventies especially in San Francisco. Worth picking up and not outdated and it does feature a classic line made history in film. Gore 0/5 Nudity 1/5 Effects 2/5 Story 3/5 Comedy 0/5

I can see why "Dirty Harry" was denounced as fascist by some people when it was released: the idea of a cop (as the protagonist) using some nasty methods to catch a sniper is unnerving - especially given that police brutality was a major issue on people's minds when the movie came out.But other than that, the movie is worth seeing, if only as a reference. I mean, who can think of Clint Eastwood without remembering "You gotta ask yourself one question: do I feel lucky? Well do ya, punk?" Still, it is good to remember that this is not for the fainthearted. Some scenes in the movie are pretty nasty. But overall, I am a punk who's feeling lucky.

reviews.review_title: One tough police man cleaning up the streets of San Francisco...
reviews.content: I remember watching this 1971 movie back in my childhood, during the early 1980s I would guess. However, I couldn't really recall the storyline in "Dirty Harry", though I remembered Clint Eastwood being a touch police man in the movie. So as I had the opportunity to return to visit "Dirty Harry" again here in 2022, of course I jumped at the chance.Writers Harry Julian Fink, Rita M. Fink, Dean Riesner, Terrence Malick, Jo Heims and John Milius actually managed to put together a very macho police story here, and it is something that felt like it was tailored specifically for Clint Eastwood.I found the storyline to be good and enjoyable. It was a story that latch on to you from the very beginning and director Don Siegel takes you on an action and adrenaline-packed chase of cat and mouse, as detective Harry Callahan is chasing after a killer that is making the streets of San Francisco unsafe.There is a good amount of action and straight up tough guy police man elements in "Dirty Harry", and that is what makes this a good movie, and makes it an archetypical Clint Eastwood movie in its own right.They had put together a good cast ensemble for this 1971 movie with Clint Eastwood in the lead, and doing a great job carrying the movie and bringing the rough and tough Harry to life on the screen. He is joined by the likes of John Vernon, Reni Santoni, Harry Guardino and Andrew Robinson."Dirty Harry" is an enjoyable movie, and definitely is a good addition to Clint Eastwood's acting career. And it is also the movie that brought the iconic and highly quotable "Do I feel luck? Well, do ya, punk?"My rating of "Dirty Harry" lands on a six out of ten stars.

reviews.review_title: A real, slightly revisionist grit underlies this iconic, straight-shooting detective drama.
reviews.content: 'Dirty Harry (1971)' isn't quite what you'd expect from the reputation that precedes it; it's far more thematically complex than that. Clint Eastwood's squinting straight-shooter, the disillusioned detective at the heart of this dark yet entertaining tale, is a surprisingly compelling lead, much more than just the poker-faced, hand-cannon-carrying cool cucumber he's now known as. The film itself is just as concerned with its slower moments as it is with its moments of action, building a suspenseful story that explodes with the sort of violence that actually matters. It's essentially a commentary on the justice system and, whether or not you agree with its wider politics, it does a great job of getting you on its side. Ultimately, there's a real, slightly revisionist grit underlying a narrative that's got something to say and isn't afraid to say it. 8/10

reviews.review_title: A great character who I'd love to see more of!
reviews.content: I've seen this movie several times, and the last movie also, but not the movies in between. I need to hunt them down. Just having rewatched this, it is such a classic. Crazy villain, good action, interesting 70's world that was before my time.

reviews.review_title: Cult classic, but shows it's age
reviews.content: Clint Eastwood has a great performance as Dirty Harry, a tough, no nonsense san Fransisco cop. There are some great lines that have been immortalised in pop culture and some funny cinematography, but it ultimately shows it's age and dated nature which, for me, undermines the drama of the film. Obviously nothing that could be done by the production on this, dated film are dated and this was made in the 70's, but it reminded me of a less intense, simpler Die Hard.

An unhinged psychopath is on the loose gunning down innocent people in scenic San Francisco for kicks. There's only one man to stop him: Harry Callahan. A handsome, unfazed and world-weary police inspector who is the living embodiment of a man who "follows the beat of his own drum", Callahan is as much a headache to his superiors as to the crooks who fear and dread his wrath. In their cat and mouse game Callahan and the villain who calls himself "Scorpio" stroll, run, and shoot leaving a trail of smashed objects, bloodied figures, scared pedestrians, dead bodies and a lot of pissed off people. While not the classic it's made out to be, "Dirty Harry" is one of the most notable action flicks whose entertainment value and influence were felt way into the end of the 20th-Century and made Clint Eastwood a legend. The film is also a neat glimpse into Nixon-era America with it's hearse-like cars, sideburns, funky soundtrack and that clear, somewhat sleazy and shady vibe that went hand in hand with a warmth and energy that made the time special and which this world has yet to see again. "Well do you, PUNK"!?

When this movie was released it was cutting edge stuff. As it heads for 40 years, it is now more average stuff. It fit Eastwoods fan base perfect in 1971.John Vernon would go from being Mayor of San Francisco in this to being a college president in Animal House. He always seems to be the same guy in every movie. He is the leader who is blissfully in the dark. He is that man here too.The plots have to do with establishing Harry Callahan as a no nonsense Detectvie in California to a crazy guy name Scorpio trying to kill everybody including Harry in a lunatic binge. This type of plot and action & language & nudity became standard for quite a while after this movie was made. The thing the viewer should ask them self is do they feel lucky? Once you see this one, you understand what established Eastwood enough in this role that he would do it again, and again for about 4 films. Later on in the series, he would utter "make my day" which is copied often too. The copying proves the value of this original film.

I've heard of this movie since it was new. It came out about the same time as "The French Connection," a splendid movie with great acting, direction, cinematography, dialogue, story line and believability.I always assumed this was a great movie, based on its reputation.I was very misinformed.I watched it on television, through all the bad cinematography, errors and lapses in continuity, absurd plot, hopeless screenplay, but after the scene with the judge and the D.A. in the latter's office, that was it. It was way too stupid to put up with it any longer.I lived in San Francisco off and on from 1961 to 1982 and it didn't represent anything close to reality in criminal justice with which I was extremely familiar, during that period. It didn't even make any sense geographically, for instance with the bag man magically moving from one end of the city to the other in the absence of available transportation, and the same with the final bus scene.This debacle was inspired, if you could call it that, by the Zodiac killer, who murdered individuals and couples in San Francisco and all around California. He was never apprehended and his identity remains unknown. This was an opportunity for a great movie that was completely wasted.

reviews.review_title: "Now you know why they call me Dirty Harry: every dirty job that comes along."
reviews.content: I know what you're thinking. "Did he fire six shots or only five?" Well, to tell you the truth, in all this excitement I kinda lost track myself. But being this is a .44 Magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world and would blow your head clean off, you've gotta ask yourself one question: "Do I feel lucky?" Well, do ya, punk?A cult action thriller starring Clint Eastwood, a film that, along with Leone's trilogy, is probably the most responsible for Eastwood's fame, and from which some of the most iconic replicas in film history have originated ... bored me to death and I barely made it to the end. With all due respect for its status and objective qualities, I can't rate it above5/10

reviews.review_title: Feels like a standard TV crime drama
reviews.content: Dirty Harry hasn't aged that well, punk. Now that this type of story has been copied so many times (with certain aspects done better), this movie feels like a standard TV crime drama. Nevertheless, Andrew Robinson is a pretty terrifying villain, and Clint Eastwood plays it cool as Inspector Callahan. I look forward to seeing what the sequels have to offer.

The film that solidified Clint Eastwood's status as America's leading man. Dirty Harry succeeds on every level with what it sets out to achieve. The music is amazing, especially in its exciting percussion and its incorporating of background effects. The camerawork is neat, and the selective use of violence (eg we don't see the dead boy, only Chico's reaction) shows you the care and seriousness put into this film. The football pitch scene is astounding, but for me, the single factor that lifts this movie into legendary status is the astounding performance of Andy Robinson as Scorpio. Cowardly, terrifying, human and yet emotionless, he is devoted to the part for every second and is a true portrait of the serial killer. A resounding scream of defiance to all the liberal attitudes of the sixties, Dirty Harry is a product of modern society, but unlike Death Wish the film doesn't want to stand up and celebrate him, only show how he is a necessary evil.

Despite being a blatant pro-vigilantism movie, is very entertaining. Filled with just about every Clint Eastwood quote you will ever need, it moves along at a decent speed, and never lets up.I still find it amazing that as an actor Eastwood made such one-dimensional shoot-em-up movies, yet, later, as a director, he made some of the most beautiful, layered, sensitive movies you will ever see.

reviews.review_title: Maverick cop protects society from a psychopath and a defective legal system
reviews.content: I enjoyed, and felt sick, when I first saw Dirty Harry.It remains a classic 30 years later. Not perfect, not quite Oscar quality, but still, a combination of terrific acting by Eastwood, Robinson, and the supporting cast, use of cinematography and music (excellent by 70's standards), and a suspenseful story line make this a movie to remember.My take on two matters in this film differs from most commentators: 1)Harry is really not so bad -- he just "plays" bad. His racism, quiet, and anger is largely put on to intimidate. Yes, he was scarred by his wife's death, but he obviously develops affection for Gonzalez, and is decent to Gonzalez's wife. The only people he really hates are the bad guys.2) This film was produced by Clint Eastwood's own Malpaso Company. Although his only credit is the lead, his imprint is all over this (and other Malpaso films). Eastwood is a politically active (former Mayor of Carmel) conservative, long-time resident of Northern California, and this film is a polemic against weak-kneed politicians that want to give in to or negotiate with terrorists, and certain excesses of our system of rights, particularly the exclusionary rule (why can't we admit the evidence, as long as "chain of evidence" is unbroken, and discipline the police officers who broke the rules / violated rights, like in the UK?). The real message is that the system should be organized to protect victims, not criminals, so that ordinary police work can put the bad guys away. In such a world, Harry would not exist.I imagine that people who have a problem with his view of "law and order" politics would not enjoy this film at all, but it is beautifully done all the same.

Andrew Robinson plays one heck of a villain but aside from that, this movie is mostly famous for the "Do you feel lucky?" line which makes sense, and I think that the second time he says it is more iconic than the time he says it the first time which is the most memorized generally. It's violent for the time, scary, leaves you on edge, and the exact kind of movie that needed to be made for its time! Clint Eastwood will always be a legend!

reviews.review_title: Simple yet captivating screenplay allows Clint Eastwood to drive the star vehicle
reviews.content: Dirty Harry is one of the most legendary and popular characters which has spawned numerous imitations not just in Hollywood but different movie industries across the world. Who else better to pull this off than Clint Eastwood who is flawless and effortless in portraying the role.Harry Callahan (Clint Eastwood) is a trigger happy unconventional cop but always brings results. When the city is threatened by a sniper aka Scorpio Killer (Andrew Robinson) who keeps putting down random victims holds the city police for ransom to stop his rampage. Harry is assigned for the task and they come up with a plan. The sniper gives them a slip after repeated plans lure him to their cage. This time the Scorpio killer takes it personal and asks Harry to deliver the ransom for a final showdown.Follows a textbook story telling process which later becomes a formula for the genre. A detailed introduction of the antagonist followed by the protagonist only after which the plot surfaces (as wafer thin as it might be) slowly building up to a final showdown. Though the Scorpio killer initially comes off as weak and mad, his character progresses steadily during the course of the story giving multiple dimensions and levels to his character. It is not comprehensible how the police department misses the sniper even multiple sightings with all the man power, pre-planning and technology. But the star is undoubtedly Clint Eastwood who carries the entire weight of the movie and even gives it a considerable boost with an uninterested look on his face, the hype surrounding him because of his volatile trigger happy nature and sharp one-liners.Simple yet captivating screenplay allows Clint Eastwood to drive the star vehicle

It's somewhat ironic that Clint Eastwood would become a household name by playing "the man with no name" before transitioning away from Westerns into contemporary movies, and then the movie that made him a superstar for the second time was a larger than life character than be identified first as a classic archetype and cinema icon and as a Eastwood role second.Everybody knows Dirty Harry. The attitude, the scowl, and the one-liners have been mimicked and parodied so many times, and the original movie, and it's sequels, have spawned countless new generations of similar hardcore heroes. Without Harry Callaghan there would be no John Matrix, no Cobra, no John McClane, no Martin Riggs, etc. Is the original film itself any good? Well, it's certainly controversial, even in the present day. Though much of the film's politics seem to be projected into the movie by its audience than actually part of film itself. In reality it's a very straight-forward, laid-back affair with minimalist dialogue, editing, and a subdued style.There's not much in the way of plot, and there's very little detective work or puzzle solving on Harry's part. He's just a blunt tool used for a dirty job, hence the name. For a movie that barely nudges past the 100-minute mark it does feel a lot long, with lingering shots, huge chunks of purely visual storytelling, and a few detours that feel like padding. The central story of a crazed sniper offing random civilians in San Francisco, inspired by the real life Zodiac murder case, isn't strong enough to last the already thin running time.It is a movie that is about style over substance, and for its day it was very slick and high key with gorgeous anamorphic Panavision photography. Does it hold up? Just about. It's not a movie that I watch for the entertainment value, but merely to study how certain classics were made.

So there's me, the biggest Clint Eastwood fan in south London (to my knowledge) being asked what mark out of ten I should give "Dirty Harry". I'm biased I admit it, so I was gonna give it 10/10. But then I thought to myself, that's just a bit TOO biased, so I decided to give it 9/10. But then I stopped and thought again. This really is a perfect film. Direction: Perfect. Script: Perfect. Acting: Perfect. No really, the acting is perfect. I'm the first to admit that Clint ain't the greatest actor on the planet, but I'm sure he knows that himself. I mean, it's not like he goes around trying to play Hamlet is it? So I reckon that the acting in this film is perfect because Clint was perfect casting in the role and he does no more and no less than the role requires. As Harry himself says in the sequel: "A man's gotta know his limitations..." And I think that's exactly what Eastwood himself knows. Plus the film says more about America in the 70's than tons of the films. Possibly more about American in the 2000's than anything being made today. And Clint's still saying these things, Don Siegel taught him well...

reviews.review_title: I know what your thinking. Did he give it a six... or only a 5
reviews.content: 'DIRTY HARRY' was directed by Don Siegel and stars Clint Eastwood, Andrew Robinson and Reni Santoni. ​After a woman gets shot in a pool, it's up to Inspector Harry Callahan(Clint Eastwood) - Dirty Harry - to hunt down her killer, who threatens to kill one more every day until he gets $100,000.I understand that a six may seem harsh for the movie, considering the cult status it has achieved. And let me just clarify, I wholeheartedly recommend you see this movie; it definitely deserves a watch. It is a solid, interesting, DISPOSABLE thriller. But that is it's big flaw. It is just disposable. Obviously, there are some memorable and amazing moments but the plot drags it down for me.Expanding on that point, I love the concept of some serial killer manipulating a city into giving him money but I think the film throws too many 'twists and turns' to make it seem more intelligent than it is. I'd rather they stick with the, possibly cliché, story of Dirty Harry hunting down Scorpio, rather than try to make the plot more complicated. Probably just my personal preference but I still consider it some form of flaw. As a whole, it is very enjoyable but it just isn't that well structured or written.Another thing I wasn't a fan of was the climax. With the exception of some truly badass moments and scenes, it just felt rushed as a whole. The location is different and interesting but the way they UTILISE it wasn't. I didn't want a huge giant climax featuring tanks, fire and the Death Star(Yeah I know Star Wars wasn't released yet) because action wasn't the focus and I understand that. I just would have rather they either changed the premise of the climax entirely, or put a little more effort in. I do love the final minute or two, however.Clint Eastwood was amazing as Dirty Harry and I think this is his most iconic role. He really owns the character and knows the perfect mix of being likable and loathsome, to make a tough guy cop. Harry is a very interesting and well written protagonist. I am very happy his past was left in his past because that gives him a level of mystery and intrigue, which I hope isn't spoiled in the sequels when I watch them.Andrew Robinson is great as the eerily insane an terrifying Scorpio. Scorpio was genuinely threatening and scary. He was a classic loathsome villain, with no levels of likability or charisma. He was just classically bad and I really like that.Reni Santoni was passable as Chico Gonzalez. Gonzalez was just a bland and boring character. He had no qualities to make him interesting . Him and Callahan had NO chemistry and I really don't understand why he was even in the movie.The cinematography and editing was pretty solid for the most. It looked fine. I do have some issues with the lighting, however. It got too dark for me at points and it was pretty hard to see. The costume design was perfectly passable.This movie contains one of the greatest one liners in cinema history. I wont write it here because it will take too long but you need to see the movie just to see this line put to good use. As stated prior, this movie is a perfectly disposable thriller. I do recommend you watch it, however. I'll rate this film 6 'LUCKY PUNKS' out of 10.

reviews.review_title: One of the common classic justice movies of 70's decade
reviews.content: The movie was much like western genre movies that Clint Eastwood ever act as solo character who want to bring the justice all alone and kick some asses. I couldn't give the movie a lot of credit cause in my opinion the story line was not much interesting.

Rightly DIRTY HARRY is respected for being a classic cop movie . Clint Eastwood - who I`m normally not keen on - gives a good performance as Inspector Harry Callahan , it`s very well directed and has a violent script with an intelligent subtext on how far law enforcement should go in order to deal with criminals. The script also contains a great deal of wit like " Hey now I know why you`re called Dirty Harry " and " My friends call me Alice - and I will take a dare " . But for me what makes this film a classic is the performance of Andy Robinson as the villain . The scene where he`s on the school bus conducting a singalong is chilling , and it`s a pity he didn`t go on to become a major Hollywood name

It's hard to imagine just how shocking this movie was way back in 1971. To see a cop who DELIBERATELY sidestepped the law to dispense his own particular brand of justice was nothing short of a revelation. Dirty Harry believes in good, old-fashioned frontier justice (which didn't always jibe with the law as laid out by them as lays out laws). He also happens to be absolutely right in taking the law into his own hands: the system proves ineffectual against the likes of Scorpio, who manages to manipulate both the law and the media to his own nefarious ends. (One can only be thankful that John Wayne turned down the part: if ever an actor was more closely associated with the party line than Wayne, I never heard of him, and DIRTY HARRY cried out for- if you will- a maverick leading man. Clint Eastwood was the perfect choice, having made his reputation in Italian Westerns.) Director Don Siegel, one of the most talented filmmakers to ever come down the pike, reached his peak with this one. And that's saying a lot.

Clint Eastwood, an actor famous for playing tough guys, plays Harry Callahan, a no nonsense cop with a big gun and who shoots first and asks questions later. He is on the case of a rooftop sniper who is holding San Francisco to ransom. Andy Robinson brilliantly plays the crazed killer Scorpio, I honestly think that he is one of the best psychos in movie history and although Dirty Harry is classed as an action thriller I also see some serious horror in the movie too. Plenty of action, this movie never gets boring, it has two fantastic leads, some great shots of SF, a cool soundtrack and some nudity, this is my favourite cop movie ever and I think Eastwood's best role, just nudging The Man With No Name of his spaghetti Westerns into a close second place.

"Dirty Harry" is a great cop movie. It features Clint Eastwood in the eponymous role, trying to chase down a psychotic killer played brilliantly by Andrew "Garak of Deep Space 9" Robinson.The plot is fairly simple. Harry stop Scorpio (the killer). In between Harry gets to foil a few other crimes - my favourite being the hilarious scene where Harry talks down a man from committing suicide. This is a prime example of some the delicious black humour running through "Dirty Harry", that helps elevate it above the dross. The main killer is particularly effective because of the way Robinson portrays him, as if a wild man is trapped inside a normal citizen. The killings themselves are violent and brutal and perfectly match the film's gritty nature.Eastwood suits the dry, sarcastic, down-beat Harry to a tee as he's perfected all the looks necessary over his career. He's a cop you don't ever want to mess with. His partner - who have previously had the career of a Spinal Tap drummer - plays surprisingly well off him, considering the circumstances, even if his fate is somewhat inevitable.I'd recommend "Dirty Harry" to any fans of the cop genre, as Dirty Harry - the cop, not the movie - is a great character. IMDB's rating is spot on for this one at 7.5/10.

reviews.review_title: The perfect and almighty cop flick.
reviews.content: Ahh, "Dirty Harry", the ultimate macho flick that is able to rise up your manhood. As a cop flick it goes further when criticizing the justice system (a dangerous criminal recovers his freedom under stranger circumstances). A bad-ass cop takes justice with his own hands and gun! Also, this cop known as "Dirty Harry", famous because of his bad temper, cool one-liners, not so methodical, is chasing a mad serial killer known as "Scorpio". (Is it me or Heath Ledger inspired his Joker character too much on him?). This leads to a series of unfortunate events that deal with violence that put the hierarchy cops in jeopardy. I can't praise this movie enough. It contains the required action, cool dialogs, realistic cop situations, and a memorable performance by Clint Eastwood.Watch it because it's not only a classic, it took the cop flicks sub- genre to a higher level. Word of mouth.

Clint Eastwood plays a nonchalant San Francisco cop chasing 'the killer', a depraved lunatic demanding $200k. It's a fairly interesting concept, which plays out well in a cat and mouse type storyline. The acting is good, the cinematography done well for its age, and the storyline well developed. Just sort of misses a bit as the scenes jump around.

Clint Eastwood is detective 'Harry Callahan', better known as "Dirty Harry". His mean, no nonsense approach to police work in downtown San Francisco wins him few friends, but one has to admit that he gets his job done.Don Siegel's film, which finds Harry up against a psychotic roof-top killer, would have had quite an impact on audiences back in 1971, due to its forcefulness and, what would then have been, high level violence. Yet by today's standards, the violence level in this film would be considered average.The movie remains fairly entertaining throughout, though we do know that no creep or punk will escape Harry's .44 magnum. Not bad if you like your heroes mean and cold.Sunday, July 5, 1992 - Video

reviews.review_title: I was very "lucky" to watch such a great flick!
reviews.content: What can you say about Dirty Harry that hasn't already been said? This is a very cool movie and without a doubt my favorite Clint Eastwood character. He is just such a cool good/bad cop, you gotta love him. Especially those famous words "You gotta ask yourself one question: Do I feel lucky? Well, do you, punk?". What a great line! What great deliverance as well! Dirty Harry was the movie before any famous cop flicks came out really, and it was interesting to see from a cop's point of view on the emotions that run through his head when he captures a filthy criminal and they go free. The whole movie you just root for his character and hope that good will always triumph. This is a terrific film and essential to the 70's! 8/10

Seen 34 years after it originally appeared -- and only because we've been greatly impressed with Clint Eastwood's recent work -- "Dirty Harry" is so dated as to be almost laughable. As a director, Eastwood has specialized in simple, straight-forward narratives and gritty realism. "Dirty Harry" is a convoluted fantasy about a maniacal serial killer and an invulnerable cop. San Francisco is a marvelous backdrop but, aside from long views of the Golden Gate Bridge, not exploited nearly as effectively as it could have been. The "mayor" is a caricature, the killer all but foams at the mouth and Eastwood's character has more in common with Superman than with everyday cops depicted on television since the advent of Hill Street Blues. Unlike many of films noir made years earlier, "Dirty Harry" retains none of what must have been its impact when originally released. If you're looking for a crime movie, find something with Humphrey Bogart or Edward G. Robinson in place of this one.

reviews.review_title: The first and the best, an Icon is born.
reviews.content: Though there were several actors interested in the role, we can all be thankful that it was a 41 year-old Clint Eastwood that ultimately landed the role and film history was made.In this first (and best) installment of the series, we have Inspector Harry Callahan of the San Francisco PD on the trail of Scorpio, a sadistic serial-killer, whose attempting to extort the city of $100,000 - but the sum soon rises as do the stakes. The role of Scorpio is brilliantly portrayed by the little-known/under-rated actor Andy Robinson, who, after this movie should have gone on to do great things, but instead, he was soon cast for a role in a soap opera pathetically enough; of which he was soon fired from merely because "he's that mean man, from that scary movie". Knowing this, one can easily surmise that the soap opera crowd must be some of the softest and most delicate people in the world. Anyway back to the movie, Eastwood's good friend and mentor, veteran film director Don Siegel helmed the project, which was filmed in and around Clint's home town of San Francisco, the primary location for all but one (Sudden Impact) of the series.Owing much to the fact that Scorpio's a homicidally insane night-owl, who has a very busy night-life, many of the movies most crucial scenes occur at night, which were strikingly captured by the masterful eye of veteran cinematographer Bruce Sortees. The scene on the roof-tops involving the attempt on the catholic priests life, where Scorpio gleefully shoots-up the rotating "Jesus Saves" sign is the most perfectly composed/photographed night scene I've ever seen in a movie, another great one is the scene involving the labyrinthine layers of Kezar stadium (which dramatically ends with one of the best helicopter shots ever). Scorpio as you'll see, is a man whose not burdened by a conscience and leaves a trail of destruction virtually everywhere he goes and though he's highly impulsive, he's not stupid and ropes along Callahan, The Mayor and the SFPD for almost the entire movie, first with extortion attempts, then he tries his hand at blackmail - and more extortion.When watching this first outing of Dirty Harry one quickly realizes just how perfectly suited the cast and crew were, it's a marvel, a thing of sheer perfection and as a result of their combined talents, every single aspect of this film seems to fall perfectly into place and crystallizes at that moment, resulting in the creation of an iconic screen hero/film series. Though four more "Dirties" would follow, the first film still stands out as the best of the lot; but what are the reasons behind that, as there are so many to consider. First of all Eastwood's great as always - that's a given. However for me it's the thrillingly compelling performance of Andy Robinson, that elevates this film to the next level and the series never had a more effective antagonist. Huge props must also be given to Don Siegel, whose skillful direction fully compliments the film and keeps the pace rolling at a high level of intrigue. Siegel's direction is so to the point that there's not a single scene wasted, not even a single wasted frame.Another stalwart of the series is composer extraordinaire Lalo Schifrin (the man behind the Mission Impossible theme), who scored all but one of the series five films. But it's in this film that his music is most memorable and effective, Schifrin's music has a way of capturing the vibe of Scorpio's murky, night-time world, pitch perfectly. I'm particularly found of the tension his music stirs up whenever Scorpio is coldly eyeing his victim from a distance. Schrifin was, again, the perfect choice of composer, which as stated earlier is a recurring fact, when considering the people who where behind this classic film. Which finally brings us to George Milius, the films screen-writer, whose contributions are invaluable to this films lasting greatness. Milius is primarily remembered for his iconic "Do I feel lucky" routine, which Harry loves to taunt criminals with; his famous words are, of course, reinforced by the presence of his infamous partner - the mighty Smith & Wesson 44 magnum revolver.What this all adds up to is the best cop drama ever made and it's scary to think of how badly this movie would have sucked, with someone else in Clint's signature role. Give praise to the exploits of Inspector Callahan, as this series has been an institution of greatness for nearly the past half a century.

reviews.review_title: Watch this trendsetter(of the 'loose canon' cops)
reviews.content: Ambivalent opinion ! The plot and the characters, in the first place, aren't notable enough to make an impression(probably I'm unfair writing this in 2015 about 1971 movie), Eastwood's acting limitations surface several times during the movie. But given the era of the movie, the plot is certainly realistic and innovative - urban crime, remnants of racism, the lame mindset of the law, the dangers and the frustration dealt by daredevil officers and the 'loose cannon' concept force the viewer to be uncomfortable and ponder over the the underbelly of the otherwise 'dream cities'. While I still rate 'Die Hard''s 'McClane' as the best 'dirty cop', Dirty Harry' probably was the trendsetter for which it should be given the due credit ...

reviews.review_title: Dirty Harry is a film and after that a leading film
reviews.content: Popularity of works like Dirty Harry is more about the wave it created in a genre of it's own type (here thriller Genre), for this reason when someone writes about films like dirty harry must face the wave that film has unleashed and this is not fair. Film wholly revolves around Clint Eastwood and it is his charisma that has kept dirty harry standing; Perhaps imagining someone other than Eastwood in the role of harry and gaining this amount of popularity for the film is completely vain. Opposing someone with this level of intelligence and ability (just compare Scorpio's intelligence and ability with zodiac's, it is said Scorpio's character inspired by his character and actions) for ransom (100000$ or 200000$) with the heads of a big city is eccentric and idiotic. reviews.review_title: Ticks every box for true movie buffs
reviews.content: Sadly they don't make em like this anymore, thanks to the overly sensitive woke, who help champion crap films of late. This is a true 70's classic with the ever cool Eastwood playing Inspector Callahan. A not by the book but common sense lawman who loves .44 mags. Don Siegal directs a top notch thriller with newcomer Andy Robinson turing in a great performance as the serial killer. reviews.review_title: "Dirty Harry" - Still the dirtiest 37 years later
reviews.content: Landmark cinema doesn't get any "dirtier" than the legendary "Dirty Harry," the titular character, San Francisco Detective "Dirty" Harry Callahan, played with 44. Magnum slyness by none other than star Clint Eastwood. Of course at the time, Eastwood was already a cult figure known for his numerous appearances in dozens of westerns, the most notable of which were the "spaghetti westerns" of Sergio Leone. When Frank Sinatra turned down the role due to an old injury, it was then offered to Eastwood, and screen legend (and infamy) was born."Dirty Harry" was groundbreaking for its hard violence and "fascistic-vigilante" approach to law enforcement. This played hard for liberals and anyone concerned with criminal rights (though the argument could be made that criminals have no rights, but this IS America, right?). As a criminal justice major myself, this puts me in an awkward position: on the one hand, I want to cheer Harry Callahan for breaking the rules to get positive results, but on the other hand we live in America, and we have a responsibility to show to the rest of the world that we're a civilized country, and we treat everyone (yes, even our criminals) fairly.In "Dirty Harry," a sniper, dubbed "Scorpio" (Andy Robinson), is terrorizing the Bay area, shooting innocent civilians at random until the city hands him over $200,000. The rule-breaking "Dirty" Harry Callahan is put on the case, partnered with Chico Gonzalez (Reni Santoni), to track down the elusive Scorpio Killer, who was based on the real-life Zodiac Killer (and who was terrorizing the city at the same time the movie was being filmed and was never captured). But political red-tape and suspects'-rights force Harry to earn his namesake, and go beyond the law to capture a dangerous psychopath.Eastwood's close friend and directorial mentor, director Don Siegel, working from a screenplay by Harry Julian Fink & R.M. Fink and Dean Riesner, made excellent use of the San Francisco city-scape to depict a world that was not only on the brink and rife with violent crime and debauchery, but gives the audience a real reason to shun suspects'-rights (the then-recent Miranda case, coercive interrogation techniques, denial of right-to-legal-counsel) and get justice by any means necessary. So you get why "Dirty Harry," which was released during a time of great change in Hollywood, when filmmakers were taking a stab (no pun intended) at left-wing Hollywood morality and was telling the liberal politics to take a hike, was so revolutionary. (It was released the same year as "A Clockwork Orange" and "Straw Dogs.")Controversy aside, "Dirty Harry" is one of the best action films ever made, certainly one of the most action-packed thrillers of the genre. Eastwood became a legend, with his 44. Magnum in hand and his most-quotable "Do you feel lucky, punk?" line. Not to be overlooked, also, is the contribution of Andy Robinson as Scorpio, who is often cited as one of the great (if not the greatest) movie villains.For a hero so good at breaking the rules, now we know why we call him "Dirty" Harry.10/10

Dirty Harry is an action crime movie starring Andrew Robinson, Harry Guardino and Clint Eastwood in the main role as Harry "Dirty" Callahan, a detective with an ethic far beyond his peers and a giant hate for everyone. Even though he's presented as a terrifying and awful character, he's likeable and relatable and we can't help but to be on his side. Eastwood was born to play this type of roles and his performance is magnificent along Andrew Robinson who also did a captivating performance. The screenplay is well-written and the soundtrack is compelling. Do I feel lucky today? Yes, I do!

Plot; San Francisco detective Harry Callahan gets caught in a game of cat and mouse with a deranged serial sniper.The zeitgeist of the era certainly informs this first entry in Eastwood's Dirty Harry saga, but far less so than its reputation. The cultural clutter is certainly there on the margins, but at it its core Dirty Harry is a reasonably well made thriller anchored by Eastwood's steely turn as the titular character and Andy Robinson's deranged Scorpio killer. I think the movie might've worked a bit better had the latter had a clearer ideology and objective, but Robinson sells it with his unhinged performance.

Eastwood's facial expression after he wastes a bad guy is incredible.  If you follow the story one gets the feeling of why Eastwood is a super star.  I will not ruin this story by telling you about, all I can say is rent the unedited version of this film to see the full story.

The Dirty Harry series is classic, but why? I do not know, but here is part one of my search for an answer, which brings me to the conclusion, that this film is not good. The acting is merely OK most of the times, although Eastwood performs good as the 'Dirty One' and the bad guy is pretty good too. But what really kills this film, is lack of pace (too slow), very bad cinematography (what does one expect in the 'sex n drugs n rock 'n roll 70's?) and a bad score which is either too bloody loud or absent.4 out of 10

Great film always brings back memories.
When Harry walks in the diner before the bank robbery a cinema around the corner is showing "Play Misty for Me" another Eastwood film which was released 3 months before Dirty Harry.

A number of respected reviewers have been highly critical of this movie over the years which has surprised me a little as it contains some good elements. True, it is, perhaps, a touch too violent which isn't really my scene. But, Clint Eastwood and Andy Robinson are excellent in their respective roles.I'm a sucker for anything that's been filmed in San Francisco (always a picturesque backdrop)and Lalo Schifrin's music is so evocative of the era. Eastwood was never better than he was in this picture as the thoroughly unlikeable maverick cop Harry Callaghan who believes that justice should be dispensed instantly and decisively right on the streets without the formality of a court case.Robinson also did a sterling job as "Scorpio", the psychotic sniper who terrorizes the 'City by the Bay' from the top of downtown buildings. Although there are moments when Callaghan's capacity for cruelty makes Scorpio look like a rank amateur.For my money, it's still one of Eastwood's best performances. Clint will never be remembered for having one of the most animated personalities in the history of Hollywood. But when it came to delivering his own, unique brand of cynical and ultra cool vindictiveness he rarely failed to come through.

reviews.review_title: Classic, one of Clint's best and the best film in the series
reviews.content: Dirty Harry was a game changer for cop movies, as well as action movies as a whole. This project turned down by many of the popular leading men of the time. However, there is no doubt in my mind Clint Eastwood was THE MAN to play this. Coming off an experimental part in his career (where he made some of excellent movies like The Beguiled and Play Misty For Me) this cements Clint's place as top action star of his day. Director Don Siegel and Clint Eastwood have worked well together for a while now and are the perfect actor/director team for this project (in my opinion). Don and Clint took elements of Clint's westerns and made it work in a gritty, modern setting. Clint's iconic screen presence and cynical sense of humor makes for one tough cop. Dirty Harry has his match with sadistic serial killer Scorpio. Scorpio is played very clever and with diabolical glee by actor Andy Robinson. Dirty Harry was a huge hit in it's day. But, not everyone loved it. Some thought the film was fascist and questions some of the methods Dirty Harry would employ to bring in the suspect. That's open to interpretation, but the quality of filmaking and performances are undisputed. This would pretty much change the action genre and create a franchise of 4 more films. Dirty Harry is by far the best, but is followed up with the also quite excellent Magnum Force.

An entertaining movie all because of the superb acting of a charismatic, ultra cool and tough as nail Eastwood.After half a century it still holds like concrete. The .44 Magnum and Eastwood are one hell of a fusion.Screenplay/story: 7Development: 8Realism: 8Entertainment: 8Acting: 8Filming/cinematography: 8.5Visual/special effects: 7Music/score: 7.5Depth: 7Logic: 6.5Flow: 7.5Action/crime/thriller: 7.5Ending/closure: 7.5.

Dirty Harry is every cop thriller you've ever seen. The bad guys play dirty, so the cops have to play dirty. Gee, that's never been done before.I love Clint Eastwood as a stoic antihero, but he's a horrible cop. A cop that doesn't care is worse than a cop that cares too much. Eastwood's cop is boring and has hardly any character. What small bits of personal information we're fed have no place in the rest of the plot, thus feel out of place and excess.The writing is awful. It's unimaginative, unoriginal, and aimless. The story feels cooked up just to get Eastwood behind a gun again. It's barely held together by the search for the Scorpio killer, who is a boring antagonist and is in no way a match for Eastwood. Everything he does is predictable, which completely disarms him as a real threat.This movie is popular because everybody likes to see Clint Eastwood with a gun and an attitude. This is not to say he isn't good at what he does, but it isn't enough to save a bad movie, which Dirty Harry undoubtedly is.

reviews.review_title: What's so great about this movie????
reviews.content: Can somebody please explain me what is so great about this movie, because I didn't see it. Let's be honest, we all know that this kind of cop doesn't exist in real life and even if he existed he wouldn't get a badge or loose it the first day he's on the streets. Dirty Harry walks around with a gun the size of a small canon, he shoots without hesitation and he doesn't mind to cross the line and yet his superiors don't fire him.No, this isn't the kind of movie that deserves an Oscar. Not for the direction (a lot of the time you don't even see what's happening and the killer's identity is shown much too soon), not for the acting (it's too stereotypical), not for anything... Only the story is OK: there is a killer roaming the streets of San Fransisco. He blackmails the mayor, telling him that he'll shoot some people if he doesn't give him 100,000 dollar. It ends in a cat-and-mouse game between Dirty Harry and the 'Punk'.I guess this is a movie that will be loved by the fans of Schwarzenegger or Stalone, and probably also by the members and sympathizers of the NRA and all other weapon freaks who think they should be allowed to carry guns and shoot anybody without asking questions when they feel "threatened". But I'm not a fan of this genre and I don't like movements like the NRA. That's why I gave it a 5/10 (only because of the story).

Gritty, violent, and politically incorrect as hell, Don Siegel's "Dirty Harry" of 1971 is doubtlessly one of the chosen few films that influenced and defined the greatest and grittiest cinematic decade of the 70s most, and positively the most essential Cop-flick ever made. It is also one of the essential films in the career of one of cinema's all-time greats, Clint Eastwood, who had already epitomized coolness many times before, most memorably in Sergio Leone's brilliant Dollar-Trilogy, which culminated in the immortal masterpiece "The Good, The Bad And The Ugly" ("Il Buono, Il Brutto Il Cattivo", 1966), positively the greatest Western ever made. Along with the Dollar films, "Dirty Harry" is doubtlessly the most memorable among the many great films that Eastwood has been part of. When it was the Dollar films that basically created the Western anti-hero, it was "Dirty Harry" that created the character of the unorthodox and supremely bad-ass Cop with the eponymous Inspector 'Dirty' Harry Callahan.Dressed in cool suits and wearing a hip hairstyle, San Francisco homicide detective Inspector 'Dirty' Harry Callahan is the archetype of the tough and unorthodox Cop that has been copied many times, but never quite reached. Callahan hates criminals as much as he hates crime, and he is never afraid to stop crime with his huge 44. Magnum, the 'most powerful handgun in the world' which he assures whimpering thugs would 'blow your head clean off'. It is not imaginable for anyone but Clint Eastwood to play this role. Several other actors (Frank Sinatra, Steve McQueen and John Wayne) were considered for the role before it went to Eastwood, but there is no doubt that the role seems as if it was written specifically for Eastwood. Every hero needs a villain, and this villain is terrifically brought to life by Andrew Robinson as the 'Scorpio Killer'. Robinson is brilliantly evil in his role. Sadly, Robinson did not get many other highly memorable roles, except for this film and Clive Barker's Horror masterpiece "Hellraiser" of 1987. Scorpio is based on the uncaught Zodiac-Killer who terrorized real-life San Francisco in the late sixties. This film's Scorpio is an megalomaniac, often pathetic but even way more sardonic and deranged psycho who shoots random people in order to blackmail the city. If the city refuses to pay him, he will continue to kill people. When released in 1971, "Dirty Harry" caused outrage among critics because of its incredible political incorrectness and violent content. Fact is that the film is incredibly politically incorrect, and the political incorrectness is one of the factors that make it so awesome. Luckily enough, the fact that the unorthodox copper who isn't afraid of bending the law in order to stop criminals was an anathema to faint-hearted critics didn't stop exactly that type of character from becoming one of the most popular roles in bad-ass cult cinema of the 70s. The film is stunningly paced and profits from a brilliant cinematography and a great score. The opening sequence alone is a masterwork of cinematographic ingenuity. Calling "Dirty Harry" a trend-setter would be an understatement. Apart from four sequels, the film spawned countless rip-offs, including many awesome Italian films, and it has continued to influence Police-flicks and Action/Thrillers in general to this day. However many great Police films there have been made and hopefully will be made in the future, however, no other cinematic cop will ever compare to Clint Eastwood's Inspector 'Dirty' Harry Calahan. This eponymous character alone more than justifies the description 'masterpiece' for this film, which is brilliant on so many levels. The dialogue includes some of the most memorable lines ever in cinema, such as the statement that 'Harry Hates Everybody', or Harry's immortal 'Do You Feel Lucky' monologue. "Dirty Harry" simply is the definition of cinematic bad-assery, and, along with Martin Scorsese's "Taxi Driver" it is probably THE most defining American film of the 1970s. This is one of the films that can be watched an infinite number of times and only become more awesome. I've personally lost count long ago of how many times I've seen it, and I will certainly watch it many more times to come. All said, this film is an absolute proof for the genius of Don Siegel as a director and Clint Eastwood as a leading man. Without exaggeration, "Dirty Harry" is positively one of the most influential and incomparably entertaining films ever made and no one interested in cinema can afford to miss it. 10/10

reviews.review_title: Classic Hard-As-Nails Cop In Sleazy San Francisco Action Thriller
reviews.content: The city of San Francisco is held to ransom by Scorpio, a rooftop killer who shoots bystanders with a high-powered rifle. Someone has to stop him, and there's only one man dangerous enough for the job - Inspector Harry Callahan ...This is the original and best psycho cop movie, a landmark in action films and crowd-pleasing adult thrillers, a key role for Eastwood (he reprised it four times), an amazing timepiece of west-coast America in the early seventies, and probably the most influential crime thriller ever made. Its importance in Hollywood terms can't be overestimated. Half of the crime movies made since copy it - the idea of the renegade tough guy cop with nothing to lose who's maybe just as crazy as the perps he's chasing simultaneously allows for great action scenes, intriguing characters and social commentary. What makes this film so good is the character of Harry Callahan - he is the hero, but is he really the guy you want protecting you ? He gets the job done when no-one else can, but at what cost ? Unlike so many imitators (Lethal Weapon, Bad Boys, about a zillion others), the movie doesn't give its hero any redeeming qualities - he's just a crime-smashing maniac. The key scene is the one in the football field, which culminates in one of the greatest shots ever done - a stunning helicopter pull-back of Harry grinding his heel in the killer's stab-wound to extract the information he wants, fading into a murky grey as the line between hero and villain is quite literally blurred. Eastwood is about as close to perfect casting as you can get - it's impossible to imagine anyone else playing this role, although ironically the part is nothing like Eastwood the man, and when he played roles closer to home (such as Bronco Billy or Honkytonk Man) his films weren't as popular. There's good support from Guardino and Santoni, and Robinson is fabulously nasty as the evil Scorpio (check him out also in Hellraiser). There's also a great little unbilled bit by Albert Popwell as the unfortunate blagger in the classic "I gots to know" bank-robbery scene. This was Siegel and Eastwood's fourth film together and they were obviously in perfect synchronicity as the movie flows together smoothly, buoyed by Lalo Schifrin's wonderfully scritchy jazz-blues music, a classic seventies score. The location photography by Bruce Surtees is just terrific throughout; somehow both documentary realism (back-of-car and street-scene shots) and moody darkness, and a fantastic travelogue of San Fransisco - Golden Gate Park, City Hall, the Mission District, Mount Davidson. A dynamite thriller, and the best film of Siegel's distinguished career (Riot In Cell Block 11, Invasion Of The Body Snatchers, The Killers, Escape From Alcatraz). It doesn't matter if you're a paid-up NRA member who idolises Harry, or a queasy liberal who thinks he's the original Fascist Pig, this is the movie to go see together and argue about. The toughest of the tough guys.

Sometimes a man has to forget the rules and hunt the bastard down himself, even if it is only a metaphor for his next sales call.The exchange that occurs twice in the movie is a classic that is well known by all: Harry Callahan: I know what you're thinking. "Did he fire six shots or only five?" Well, to tell you the truth, in all this excitement I kind of lost track myself. But being as this is a .44 Magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world, and would blow your head clean off, you've got to ask yourself a question: Do I feel lucky? Well, do ya, punk? This established Clint Eastwood as not only a great western star, but the baddest cop on the block. The man who defied the prissy establishment that was concerned with public image rather that justice. It put him fully in command of the über-male - the man who does what is right instead of what is popular.Skintastic Moment: Poor old Debralee Scott gives us her only nude performance and doesn't even get credited.

"Dirty Harry" is one of the iconic movies of the 1970s but it seems to have fallen by the cinematic wayside a bit. Sure, everyone knows it was one of Clint Eastwood's signature roles, about a tough but effective San Francisco cop who asks "Do you feel lucky, punk?" but for such a widely known movie, it isn't a cable staple, it's not an essential for DVD libraries. It's one of those movies everyone knows of but not a great many younger viewers actually bother to see. Is it getting a fair rap?The movie has its moments. As the movie starts, Eastwood's Harry Callahan is trying to mind his own business and have a sandwich but is forced to stop a team of bank robbers. This epic scene evokes the image of Eastwood's classic Man with No Name as he walks through the smokey urban canyon, huge gun drawn, fearlessly doing battle against long odds, and coming out with a mere scratch.I think the main problem with the movie is its core plot pitting Harry against a pure-evil maniac serial killer terrorizing San Francisco. The killer is played well enough but it's just so cartoonish a role that it's hard to take the movie too seriously, and considering the gritty, hard message the movie presents, it's a real problem that the villain is a cliché. The movie's message is that criminals can run rampant because of the 1960s civil rights restrictions to cop's ability torture suspect's for information, or having to get warrants before breaking into suspect's houses, and these sorts of restrictions where why there was so much crime. It's a message that might have had some populist appeal in 1971 but it comes off as pretty kooky 40 years later.Dirty Harry isn't a bad movie, but it's clear that it's dated. It's not as exciting as action movies of the 1980s, there have been much better detective movies, and its message is a tad naive and outdated. It's clear to me why this is a movie everyone has heard of but not a lot of people see anymore. Still, it's worth seeing... but it's not a must-see movie.

reviews.review_title: They don't get any better than this!
reviews.content: "Dirty Harry" is one of two Police thrillers that are without equal. The other film being "The French Connection." Both films are that well made in every department, along with being HUGELY influential, that every other American 1970s Cop film was bound to be compared. Putting it simply, you shall not find another movie of this kind that can match them. It is interesting in itself how different a film "Dirty Harry" would have been if a different actor had been cast in the leading role of the San Francisco Police Inspector. People like Paul Newman and Burt Lancaster were offered the part but due to their liberal political views, neither man was interested. Apart from anything else, both actors were given different scripts to look over. The closest contender for the Harry Callahan character, was Frank Sinatra. I'm not saying he wouldn't have been any good but the film as a whole would have been completely different. In addition, it is highly doubtful that "Dirty Harry" would be enjoying the following that it has had since its release in 1971. Sinatra wouldn't really have been physically imposing enough either. However, he did a good job in the 1968 movie, "The Detective." Thank goodness Clint Eastwood was cast. Who else can say lines like "Go ahead, make my day" or "Do you feel lucky?" and carry the same kind of impact? Thanks to films like "Hang 'Em High," "Coogan's Bluff" and "The Beguiled," Clint Eastwood was on his way to becoming a box office sensation. It was inspired that he and Don Siegel work together for their fourth collaboration. Their previous films were very good on the whole but both men saved their best for "Dirty Harry." Harry Callahan, from his first scene with dialogue, immediately displays his contempt for authority and bureaucracy. This occurs via his complaining about having to wait a long time before the Mayor of San Francisco calls Callahan into his office. The viewers are left in no doubt as to how Callahan functions as a person as well as a Police officer. He doesn't seem to cultivate many friendships or relationships, he hasn't many interests outside of his work and is constantly being reprimanded by his superiors for one reason or another. The latter has been done to death in cinema but back in 1971, that was quite a new thing. Callahan's colleagues don't particularly care for his working methods but still begrudge him some respect for being a tough son of a gun and for producing good results. It is no small wonder that Callahan has had many partners, all of whom either die whilst on active duty or they request a transfer. The opening scene of "Dirty Harry" sets the tone for the whole film. Don Siegel cleverly disguises the true appearance of the psychopathic sniper but the killer's presence is certainly felt. The music is somewhat off centre but that only heightens the tension as that woman in the swimming pool falls victim.... Andrew Robinson gives a defining performance as the sniper in question.
