Apparently, he was spotted by Clint Eastwood during a theatre performance and so, Eastwood put Andrew Robinson's name forward. Harry Guardino, John Larch and John Vernon provide excellent support. They know Callahan's methods only too well, judging by the considerable paperwork they are given each time Callahan uses his signature 44 Magnum. There is plenty of excitement in this film. The scene where Callahan has his lunch interrupted by the bank robbery is terrific as he opens fire on the perpetrators in question. As hard as he is, even Callahan displays a vulnerable side. The section where he secretly liaisons with "Scorpio" (Andrew Robinson) in the city park, shows that side to Callahan's character. It is a violent and tense moment of cinema and is very well done. My late father always complained when Callahan uses torture in order to extract either a confession or vital information after a teenage girl is abducted by Scorpio. It is enough that Callahan stabbed the killer in order to defend himself after his brutal assault in the park. It is a bit over the top for Callahan to shoot the injured leg of the killer and to then slowly rotate his foot over the killer's profusely bleeding injury. The scream that Scorpio gives is enough to make the hair on the back of your neck stand on end. The scene finishes with the camera slowly gliding away as Callahan continues his torture....... The only thing that can be said in Callahan's defence, is that he was very concerned about the girl's safety and location. Does that justify using torture so as to extract information from an unarmed suspect? Only the viewer can decide. Naturally, Callahan was brought to order over his conduct by being given a severe reprimand by the District Attorney. Don Siegel cranks up the tension further with the climax, including a bus full of school children being held hostage by Scorpio. It was bound to come down to a confrontation between Callahan and Scorpio. Their climatic gunfight is brilliant. The ending is slightly steeped in ambiguity. When Callahan throws his Police badge into the pond, did he do that as a sign of his anger and frustration or did he choose to resign? Again, only the viewer can decide. A truly definitive Police thriller and it is worthy of a far higher rating on this website.

Everyone, including Clint Eastwood novices, has heard of Dirty Harry. The famous titular character was established by Eastwood in the 1971 film by Don Siegel. In the film, Harry is a tough-talking cop intent on tracking down a serial killer haunting the streets of SanFrancisco. A mystery that quickly devolved into a cat-and-mouse game with a great '70's score makes up the iconic film.After a string of seemingly unrelated murders, San Francisco police receive communication with the perpetrator who only refers to himself as Scorpio. In the letter, Scorpio demands a ransom to ensure that no more victims are taken and begins to leave notes at each crime scene. Harry (Clint Eastwood) refuses to toe the company line and submit to the demands of a serial killer, so he goes rogue with his newest partner to track down Scorpio and stop him on his own terms. Harry will stop at nothing to catch the killer and prove the origin of his nickname, Dirty Harry, along the way.I was hoping Dirty Harry would be more of a whodunit exercise than a cat-and-mouse game. The killer is revealed early in the film and with little mystery surrounding the reveal. The opening was fantastic and seemed to be sure to maintain the mystery and intrigue throughout the film, yet once the killer was revealed, the pace began to screech along rather sluggishly. The camera work was fun, however, making sure I stayed put through the entire runtime of the film. Low-angle shots are a surefire way to keep me glued to my seat, and Siegel's use of them so often and effectively was beautiful to watch. Dirty Harry fails the hardest in its inability to hold the same intrigue established in the opening which was a monumental disappointment. If you're looking for an apt cat-and- mouse chase film, Dirty Harry will fit the bill, despite how lacking it is in the mystery component.

reviews.review_title: A Well Acted Crime Film with One of Eastwoods Most Memorable Performances
reviews.content: Dirty Harry is a good movie with a well developed storyline and a terrific cast. It is a very enjoyable crime film that contains both thrilling scenes and also some stellar action sequences, it has a nice mix of both and neither feel overused. The role of Harry Callahan was perfect for Clint Eastwood, it was the right character for him, gave him the chance to stretch his acting skills a lot more and break free from doing westerns, it is one of his most memorable performances and it is clear throughout that he really connected with this character. Very well acted and quite thrilling, Dirty Harry is a very enjoyable movie that I would recommend to anyone looking for a good crime film or thriller. A maverick cop attempts to bring a cold blooded serial killer to justice before he kills again.Best Performance: Clint Eastwood Worst Performance: Harry Guardino

Are people who consider this an all-time classic smoking something? Even for a 50-year old movie, this is unspeakably bad. The acting is atrocious, the action scenes are comical and the plot development is actually quite insulting. Could well be one of the most overhyped movies ever made.

reviews.review_title: I know I wouldn't feel lucky
reviews.content: Already trenched into the American film consciousness as a handsome,gritty figure in Spagheti Westerns by the end of the 60s,Clint EAstwood would embark on a relatively new genre for the time: the justice-minded,independent hero that blows through bureaucracy and authority to get his man,dead or alive,in contemporary America. This Don Siegel-directed film would set a standard for a new wave of Eastwood films where he wasn't just a tough guy,but THE tough guy on the scene. In retrospect,it seems slightly ironic that a effective,craft-loyal auteur would be synonymous over the nation and world as Inspector "Dirty Harry"Callahan,but given his background in Westerns,it fits like a glove.(Just HOW this character managed to be promoted as high as he was given his total sense of contempt for hand-cuffing authority is a plot hole that is never really reconciled,BTW)Callahan has a great record of dispatching of criminal scum on the streets of San Francisco,and he's got a perfect prey in a mostly random killer with a hyena-laugh and witchy voice(Andy Robinson). The killer works the system,first as he victimizes residents,then when he is captured. To say that this doesn't sit well with the flinty,glinty,SFPD inspector would be an understatement,to say the least.From the jarring,seemingly low-key opening scene to the jarring,climactic scene involving a bus load of school kids,this movie is both an effective"Kick a**" movie,and yet a wise usage of societal norms and police politics. The sequels this film would spawn would be a lot louder and would up the ante considerably,but this film stands alone as a legend.

reviews.review_title: You gotta ask yourself one question...
reviews.content: Hard as nails San Francisco cop, Harry Callahan known as "Dirty Harry" by his fellow peers for his perchance at handling any dirty situation that comes his way. Along with Magnum Smith and Wesson, Harry must stop a serial psychopath known as The Scorpio Killer, whose viciousness is only matched by Harry's ruthlessness in this deadly game of cat and mouse.The first in a series of films, in what quintessentially is the bread and butter of several action films to follow it. Eastwood is perfect in his representation of Harry and what is considered the standard bearer for all cop films and action heroes to come. Dark, gritty and raw in its very core, nothing about this film is soft or even considered politically correct in today's standards. The story is original for its time as well as the pacing of this film. The dialog is spectacular and the viewer will become engrossed in this film from its very opening minuets to its climactic conclusion. It's hard to not become engrossed or the very least fond of Eastwood's portrayal as he fits the role of the character perfectly, and with his signature catch phrase that has now etched its way into popular culture, Dirty Harry is a film that not only resonates but has held up to the test of time. A film that eventually will spawn 4 sequels, dark, moody and specially violent for its time, this film is a must see for any fans of pure cinema and one can't consider themselves a movie buff without viewing what is now considered a classic not only for the genre but in cinematic history.

reviews.review_title: The Most Serious Unserious Movie Ever !
reviews.content: This is a memorable movie for sure. Not for being an attractive action thriller only, but for leaving such a deep effect on the American pop culture, and the hero's image in American movies and TV shows for following decades. Inspector ('Dirty' Harry Callahan) is the godfather of every ideal, angry, and maverick American cop since the early 1970s till now. Here, you'll find some perusal for the dark side of the American good hero (imagine a "John Wayne" who can shoot bad guys in the back), while battling a super evil criminal who assures that the modern civilization's law misses some savagery to execute its justice.However, the movie's main downside is that super evil criminal. The script didn't present the character of (Charles 'Scorpio Killer' Davis) as a criminal inasmuch as the crime itself. He steals, blackmails, kidnaps, and kills. Most probably, in the first draft, these very crimes were done by many criminals, then it got modified to make more unity and one villain. Though the final result was uneven and unbelievable. Furthermore, we didn't watch any motive or history for (Scorpio). They made him *The Psychopath Killer* to justify his mega craziness, and compensate for his unstoppable extreme crimes. But with loose absolute evil, read: exaggeration, the character lost its credibility totally.It gets ironic when the antagonist is dealt with by that weakness, while all the caring goes to the protagonist. Clearly, (Harry) is well presented as a sincere cop, who lost his wife, hence dedicated his life for his work, as well as released all of his passions into his war against crime, where no victory without equal violence. And if you felt that the treatment of the whole thing was that superficial, wait to watch the rest of the franchise, where the action ate the drama. Actually, in here, it's the sole time to see (Harry) that desperate to throw his badge into the river, but it mirrors the fact that this movie wasn't meant to be a series.The nudity, the profanity, and the violence are all here. Done for a realistic factor to seduce the critics, or for a commercial factor to seduce the audience, both ways I didn't buy it, or like it. These goods were / are / will be ugly, distractive, and have nothing to do with arts. Day after day, they became inhumanly overabundant, let alone how I believe that they establish, and legislate, degeneration in societies as well!On the upside, the music's lamentable sense was so touching and profound. You'll get it wholly in the last scene, and sorrowfully you won't find it in any of the next sequels. The cinematography was so tense, a little realistic compared to the action movies at the time, and artistic; to draw and color (Dirty Harry) along with his world eloquently. See how (Harry) had that special halo around him, showing as a high shining giant whose kind of isolated and deeply in pain.(Clint Eastwood) seemed bigger than life. It's enough to remember the shot when (Scorpio) looks surprisingly, from the bus that he kidnapped, to see (Harry) standing in black shoes, suit, and sunglasses on the bridge ahead of him. Aside from being a complete magical moment of cinema, or proving that (Eastwood)'s charisma is astonishing, the whole cadre made the tall (Harry) as portly upright part of this disturbed city.(Dirty Harry) is a fierce yet idealistic cowboy, and a simple commercial movie which tells openly a lot about a dirty world that needs dirty manners sometimes, since its laws are deficient. So as another police story, it's rough, impudent, and satiric. But don't mistake it for a serious movie. It's rather the exploitation version of the message movie that tickles important issues. Because if you give it a little thinking, you'll easily see that "violence begets violence", hence (Dirty Harry) isn't the solution, instead he's part of the problem. So he's another Hollywood fantasy, which is dirty as a renewal, to attract a new generation, and make good money, while having a cover of sullen reality, and a flavor of light satire. That's why I used to call this movie "the most serious unserious movie ever".

reviews.review_title: Brutal and gritty cop film noir
reviews.content: This movie screams 70s at every frame. Clint Eastwood plays the eponymous brutal cop on the tail of a serial killer in San Francisco. Surely the movie has a weird pacing and no strong supporting characters. And surely it delivers a controversial message, coming through as quite fascist. But I can enjoy a nice violent cop movie without stirring an inner ethical conflict, especially when it is well made.Clint is just perfect in the role, the killer is also insanely good and you just want to see him brutally stopped. Another great point is photography and camera work: apart from some scenes a bit too dark, the initial shot of SF from above are breathtaking.

reviews.review_title: "Well, I'm all broken up over that man's rights!"
reviews.content: Great movie. Gritty and realistic in most places, this is one of Clint Eastwood's best (if not THE best). Whether he's snarling at the Mayor, egging on a jumper, or facing off against the Scorpio killer, Callahan is a fascinating treat to watch. Andrew Robinson is very creepy as the sniper/killer.Coolest scenes: The scene at the stadium which has an intense and uncomfortable torture and ends with a great zoom out (via helicopter), the final face-off, and (of course) the first "Do ya feel lucky?" scene.

I missed this in the theaters it's first time around and saw it a first a few years later as a double bill with it's sequel/prequel Magnum Force. Clint Eastwood is Inspector Harry Callahan, a tough unconventional San Francisco detective who has lost several assignment partners in the line of duty and is kind of like his man with no name western characters in that he is smooth, unsmiling and confident but can explode in deadly violence in a split second. He is tracking a psychotic sniper killer and kidnapper that is terrorizing the city called Scorpio. The Scorpio character is loosely based on the Zodiac killer that killed apparently random victims in the Bay area from late 1968 to late 1969 and taunted police and newspapers for years after claiming additional unconfirmed victims and threatening to kill more including a school bus of kids as a potential target. This story by the husband and wife team of Harry Julian Fink and Rita Fink went through at least three rewrites and screenwriter Dean Riesner was brought on to work on it. The Finks collaborated on five Clint Eastwood films during their careers and Riesner also wrote for five Eastwood films and had been a writer on Eastwood's old TV series Rawhide. Additional dialog was scripted by Terrence Malick and John Milius before the final draft was ready for the screen. Originally titled Dead Right it was to star Frank Sinatra and be directed by Irwin Kerhner. Kirshner was dropped when Sinatra pulled out. Several other actors were rumored to have been approached for the title role including Paul Newman who it is said suggested Eastwood for the role of Dirty Harry. Director Don Siegel, who directed five of Eastwood's films in his career, was brought in. Cinematographer Bruce Surtees who would photographed 12 of Eastwood's films in his career is the film's cinematographer. Veteran film composer Lalo Schifrin provides the score. Harry Guardino, Reni Santori, John Vernon and Andrew Robinson are the principal supporting cast. This movie still looks good today. I would give it a 9.0 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Eastwood at his best - and dirtiest!
reviews.content:
In spite of its age and dated looks DH is probably one of the best cop movies to come out of Hollywood. It spawned a host of variations on a theme, even though some would argue DH took a few ideas from the 1968 Bullitt.The idea of a cop trying to bring criminals to book, but using tactics otherwise outside the law, was quite a novel idea back then and was probably an indictment of how the crimewave in some parts of the States had spiralled during the liberalised late 60's and early 70s.Of course if Mr Harry Callaghan had tried such unorthodox methods of arrest in these politically correct days you can be sure the criminal would have sued for millions of dollars, shouting human rights violations and demanding the cop be arrested & jailed for a thousand years.Which is a salient point in a way, because back in the 70s such Correctness was exactly the kind of thing Callaghan was fighting against along with creaking police procedures of arrest.Not only does he find it hard enough keeping tracks on Scorpio as he causes mayhem in the streets of SF, but he also has to battle the law & order system. Is it any wonder he steps out of line when justice seems to support the alleged criminal rather than protecting the innocents...sounds so familiar these days.Eastwood really got his foot in the Stardom threshold with this movie. Somehow I don't think an ageing John Wayne or Sinatra would have had the same kind of steely glare as Eastwood, especially during the final standoff with Scorpio and Harry recites his infamous "Punk" line. Nobody has a tighter jawline than Eastwood at times like this.
Eastwood expands on his previous Dollar "man with no name" characters to good effect: essentially we have a man who is more a renegade, a man who tries to live outside the restrictions of law & order in order to achieve a legitimate goal, although unlike the Dollar films Eastwood becomes a little more cultured in the streets of SF rather than way out in the middle of some western desert.The bandits he challenges to duels in the Dollar films are no different to the criminals he challenges in Dirty Harry, and even though he has the law on his side, its often not enough.Siegal's direction and the script never lets up for a minute coupled with a very good musical score. But the best part is of course the stand-off at the end. What Eastwood does with his badge is perhaps one of the great pieces of symbolism in movie history and probably had a million liberals up in arms!The less said about the sequels the better: they seem to follow the Jaws trend, Magnum Force being competent but The Enforcer et al just get steadily worse.Pick the best and make his day, Punk!****/*****

reviews.review_title: The Dirtiest "Dirty Harry" Of Them All!
reviews.content: Cast as the eponymous protagonist in Don Siegel's urban thriller "Dirty Harry" (1971), Clint Eastwood plays San Francisco Police Inspector Harry Callahan. He can spot a crime in progress and proves it early on when he thwarts a bank robbery while eating a hotdog for lunch. When the assailants emerge from the bank, Harry wields his massive Smith & Wesson revolver, stops a car, kills one black robber and wounds another. Sprawled on the sidewalk in front of the bank with his pump-action shotgun inches away from his fingertips, the robber (Albert Popwell) glares back at Callahan. Harry taunts him. "I know what're thinking. Did he fire six shots or only five? Well, to tell you the truth, in all this excitement, I kind of lost track myself. But being as this is a .44 magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world and would blow your head clean off, you've got to ask yourself one question, do I feel, lucky? Well, do you, punk?" Harry grins, confiscates the shotgun and saunters off. The robber wants to know, so Harry takes aim and squeezes the trigger. CLICK! In this memorable scene, Siegel and his scenarists summed up everything about their abrasive protagonist. Later, Callahan coaxes a suicide jumper off a high-rise building by badgering the man. Audiences ate up "Dirty Harry." Eastwood reprised his role as the insubordinate but saintly cop in "Magnum Force" (1972), "The Enforcer" (1976), "Sudden Impact" (1984), and "The Dead Pool" (1987), but the sequels lacked the spontaneity of the original. Eastwood accommodated Warner Brothers so the studio would release his personal projects, such as "The Honkytonk Man" (1982).Seasoned director Don Siegel of "Invasion of the Body Snatchers" had collaborated earlier with Eastwood in another police procedural, "Coogan's Bluff" (1968), that explored similar issues about another contemporary, non-conformist Arizona lawman on the trail of a murderer who had fled to New York City. Altogether, Siegel and Eastwood made five films, but "Dirty Harry" ranked as their finest work. Like "Invasion of the Body Snatchers," "Dirty Harry" appeared during a time of social unrest. The Vietnam War was raging. The "New York Times" had published the secret Pentagon Papers. Inspector Callahan represented another of Siegel's pariahs that refused to join the status quo. This controversial, R-rated, police procedural about a cynical cop who gets "every dirty job that comes along" generated a debate between liberals and conservatives about police brutality and a suspect's civil rights. Recent court rulings in favor of criminal suspects, namely the Miranda Rights and Escobedo rulings had extended rights to criminals. Liberals lambasted "Dirty Harry" as a fascist's manifesto. Later "Dirty Harry" sequels would clarify Harry's behavior. "A man has got to know his limitations," Harry says in the sequel when he refuses to join a group of vigilante cops that acts as self-appointed judges, juries and executioners.Callahan clashes with a psychotic sniper who initially holds San Francisco for ransom to the tune of $100-thousand dollars. He targets minorities, Catholic priests and young women. Ostensibly based on the real-life Zodiac killer, Scorpio (Andy Robinson) wears a peace sign as a belt buckle and shows no qualms about killing. The film unfolds with Scorpio atop one skyscraper calmly killing a bikini-clad woman in a swimming pool atop another skyscraper. Eventually, Harry captures Scorpio, but the District Attorney releases him. Our heroit seems--infringed on the felon's liberties in the Bill of Rights. Harry arrested Scorpio without reading him his Miranda rights, tortured him, and confiscated his sniper's rifle without a search warrant. Worse, Harry knew what he was doing when he violated Scorpio's rights. Callahan wanted to rescue the kidnap victim that Scorpio had buried with limited oxygen in a hole before she died. Later, Scorpio hijacks a school bus carrying children and demands a $200-thousand ransom and a jetliner. Harry refuses to serve as the intermediary. Instead, he thwarts Scorpio, kills him and hurls his badge away"High Noon" stylein disgust.Interestingly, several prominent stars, including Frank Sinatra, Paul Newman, and John Wayne, passed up "Dirty Harry." Siegel wrung nail-biting suspense out of every predicament that Harry finds himself in against the cunning sniper. Although "Dirty Harry" earned more money than his previous films, Siegel preferred an earlier Clint Eastwood Gothic movie "The Beguiled." The complexity of "Dirty Harry" is reflected Siegel's attitude toward him. Although Harry is the hero, Siegel found himself at odds with Harry's conduct and told one interviewer, "This doesn't mean I agree with him."

reviews.review_title: mostly a fun movie with some originality
reviews.content: DIRTY HARRY is a pretty definitive and well known movie. I don't believe there is a possible spoiler, but still I won't spoil it. The movie was one of the original of it's type, and it inspired a lot of people, and it still does. It basically is about being fed up with punks. Most people can relate to that, which makes this a very popular movie. Also the movie is somewhat fun. To be honest, even for the time period it dragged and dragged. There are memorable action sequences, but this movie lived and died with the "trailer" scenes. Take away the advertised scenes, and it was frankly dull. Still, the premise was original. There were some classic moments, and the memorable lines. It was written well enough that whoever played Dirty Harry would be granted instant praise and super stardom. In recap, this is one of those movies about personality instead of character, about the scene instead of the play. There is a logical plot, which does set it apart from other movies of this sort. Intriguing message sent with movie, which is pretty timeless. Would rate higher if it didn't drag on.

The one that started it all is none other than this action packed film, Dirty Harry! Clint Eastwood was really good! Andrew Robinson was great as the villain! John Vernon was good! Lalo Schifrin's music was good as always! The action scenes are top notch and these kind are not seen in every action film! The action is quite unique! Strongly recommended!

Psycho killer Scorpio is terrorizing the city of San Francisco and the police, handcuffed by a mayor afraid of bad publicity, are unable to do anything about it. That is except for Inspector Harry Callahan (Clint Eastwood), a politically incorrect tough cop who gets results regardless of how many rules he breaks or feelings he hurts. Harry defies his superiors and takes on Scorpio his way.This is one of Eastwood's best and one of my personal favorite films from the '70s. Clint's terrific, as is Andrew Robinson as Scorpio. Great direction from Don Siegel, a smart and witty script with grit, and a terrific cast make this one of the best cop movies ever made. A taut action-thriller that introduced an iconic character that's been poorly imitated many times since. Followed by four sequels of varying quality but all watchable.

reviews.review_title: Dirty Harry - never a name was so fitting
reviews.content: Dirty Harry is a film that promotes racism, torture and anti- liberal ideology. I don't know, honestly, how this film reached classic status. Unless if the film is a satire master work, this film shouldn't be watched by any means and should be burned in the fire. Seriously, I wonder how these people who liked this film are so naive(they think probably Dirty Harry is only a 'good action film with bad-ass scenes'. Well, they need to see the big picture then.In the background of a B cinematography and a funky jazz porn-like soundtrack,the film shows Harry, a cop which is basically the typical right-winged moron. He hates Mexicans and like to use violent methods against criminals. And the film approves that, of course, and some viewers applaud and even give a stand-ovation when Harry abandons the police(which follows,rightfully so, the rules) so he can finally use his torture and murderer methods against the 'villain' without the law guilty.The villain, if you note well, is a symbol of the liberal hippie. Yes. He has a belt with the symbol that resembles perfectly the symbol of peace and love, used mostly by hippies. So, the film says basically that the hipsters/liberals are evil. Disturbing.Shame on you, Clint Eastwood. 5.6/10

The exchange that occurs twice in the movie is a classic that is well know by all: Harry Callahan: I know what you're thinking. "Did he fire six shots or only five?" Well, to tell you the truth, in all this excitement I kind of lost track myself. But being as this is a .44 Magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world, and would blow your head clean off, you've got to ask yourself a question: Do I feel lucky? Well, do ya, punk? This established Clint Eastwood as not only a great western star, but the baddest cop on the block. The man who defied the prissy establishment that was concerned with public image rather that justice. It put him fully in command of the über-male - the man who does what is right instead of what is popular.Poor old Debralee Scott gives us her only nude performance and doesn't even get credited.

Amsterdam 1972, saw posters of "Dirty Harry" everywhere. When I finally did see Dirty Harry I loved it and how he was such a cool underdog but he had such insights to human behavior. I am watching it again today 2017 and he is more timely than ever. He had skill, intelligence, guts, and the ability to accomplish the dirty assignments.

reviews.review_title: Try the original, never been bettered
reviews.content: Dirty Harry is a first rate film.It is an excellent police thriller about a serial killer who can only be brought to book by a police officer who is prepared to bend the rules a little. As well as being an exciting and suspenseful story in itself, there is an interesting - and unresolved - subtext about whether the end justifies the means (the film, long before any sequels were envisioned, ends with Harry's vigilante-style policing administering the roughest of justice to killer Scorpio, but then throwing his police shield away in disgust at how impotent due process leaves authority against such people).There is a strong sense of time and place - San Francisco is very much a character in the movie.Lalo Schifrin's score is punchy and contemporary (now, perhaps, a little dated).The supporting cast is excellent, with special praise for Reni Santoni's sidekick Chico, totally unprepared for the partner he is teamed up with, and Andy Robinson's superbly slimy Scorpio, screaming for his rights while denying his victims theirs (the film deliberately fosters a sense of outrage at this).There are non-stop seminal moments throughout the movie, with the "I know what you're thinking..." speech being by far the most iconic.And, above all, there is Eastwood, creating a contemporary character with as much resonance as the Man With No Name, so much so that he was brought back for 4 sequels (which, inevitably, dwindled in impact with each successive movie).But this is the first. The original. Never bettered.See it.

A classic cop movie up with the ranks of "Bullitt" and "The French Connection.""Dirty" Harry Callahan is a cop assigned to bring in a serial sniper who is extorting the city of San Francisco. The killer, being equally clever as the our hero, notices Callahan's tough reputation and gets tries to get the public to believe that he is the victim of a brutal cop abusing his power.That serves for a good twist on the standard cop vs killer story. Also great is the character development as it made Clint Eastwood who he is today: Hollywood's foremost tough guy. Though since replaced from the top this movie ensured Eastwood his currently legendary status.Safe to say is that this film put Clint's former personage, the lone tough gunman in the West, into a city setting. This film only owes itself to "Bullitt" and sticks up very well to it. 8/10

"You know, you're crazy if you think you've heard the last of this guy. He's gonna kill again," Harry Callahan (Clint Eastwood) sighs to his superior. A maniac (a fantastic Andrew Robinson) is on the loose, killing anybody who comes to his liking, usually on the edges of rooftops with a polished sniper rifle. His wild, long blond hair blows in the wind with the prowess of a lion ready for an attack, his deranged face snarling with noxious elation. He is the Scorpio, a murderer who finds himself amused when blood spills onto his hands. Callahan has done everything to stop him, yet he has escaped the grip of authority with aggravating repetition.Unfortunately for the so-called Scorpio, Callahan is no Frank Bullitt and is definitely not a Jacques Clouseau-type. Carrying a .44 magnum, which he dubs "the most powerful gun in the world," Callahan is unflinchingly acerbic, humorless, and unafraid to sidestep the law and take justice into his own hands.When Dirty Harry was released in 1971, it was a new kind of cop movie. It was one with an outrageous amount of violence and one with a lack of a moral compass. Simply put, it was a source of serious controversy. Police brutality was something left untouched by most American films, and to have a hero slightly deranged himself was something far and away from the well-defined good guy/bad guy cliché. But to take Dirty Harry seriously would be like viewing a comic book with a realistic lens; it's a piece of seedy pulp that takes the police thriller genre and stretches it out with operatic carnage and dark alley sleaziness. The streets of San Francisco are like the frames of a graphic novel, colored with dim electric light by night and saturated with disconcerting warmth by day. The film lives in a world where crime runs around with menace, becoming nearly casual to its citizens. Harry Callahan is like Batman, minus the suit, Batmobile, immortal sidekick, and underground lair. He is most well-defined in an early scene where he sits down in a diner for a midday snack. That moment of peace, though, is interrupted when he notices a bank robbery in progress across the street. A few of the criminals have been gunned down, but one lies on the steps of the entrance, bleeding and moaning. Rather than arrest him, Callahan is inspired to taunt him, make him transform from predator to prey in a matter of seconds. He deadpans his way through a mini-speech that seems prewritten as he cocks his gun: "I know what you're thinking. 'Did he fire six shots or only five?' This is a .44 Magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world. It would blow you head clean off. You've gotta ask yourself one question: 'Do I feel lucky?'" We discover that the thief is lucky – Callahan has fired all six shots.But it becomes clear later on that he most likely already knew that all six shots were fired. When it comes to a dirty criminal, however, why not play a sick game of Russian Roulette? Callahan would prefer to teach brutal lessons and give bad guys a taste of their own medicine; Miranda rights and the amendments are for sissies.Harry Callahan was the original tough-guy detective, remaining to be a brute force of fortitude and pointed courage. Without Eastwood, he wouldn't have that ominous edge by his side. It's a performance of precise emotion. He delivers every line with a diverting softly spoken voice, only to later explode with an awesome capability for violence. As he whispers his few words, we can only wonder what's going on in his head. Callahan is such a legendary figure in cinema because every move he makes is recognizable, embedded into the foreboding underbellies of neo-noir. Dirty Harry is iconic for a reason. Few cop movies have been able to thrill without the slight glitter of Hollywood lure. It can be sickeningly violent, but that's only because one foot is glued on action and the other is on realism. Read more reviews at petersonreviews.com

reviews.review_title: My friends call me Alice, I will take a dare....
reviews.content: San Francisco is under the terrorising eye of a psychopathic sniper called Scorpio, and claims in one of his written letters to the SFPD, that he will keep killing until his demands are made. Inspector 'Dirty' Harry Callahan is a San Francisco police officer, with an attitude and uses little methods to what the law prescribes. It becomes a menacing task for Callahan, as he's been assigned to apprehend the menacing killer at all cost, which later unravels into a cat-and-mouse game between the two men. One killer with a sinister, distasteful sense of humour. The other, a killer with just a plain dirty attitude who holds the badge.....What can be said about this film that already hasn't been said? It's Eastwoods most iconic roles and its one of the best movies ever made. And it stands the test of time for several reasons.It's quotable and then some. And not just the 'I know what your thinking....' line, its the endless sarcastic remarks Harry makes to his peers and the fact he gets away with it.And Siegel has a wonderful eye for beautiful shots. From the opening shot where we are staring down the barrel of a gun, to the downright genius of the track away shot from the football field, right down to the coolest shot of the seventies, Harry standing on the bridge, the film looks so fresh and vibrant.Harry is the original bad a** cop, and this film released its own sub genre. The majority of action movies released since then, owe this film a huge debt, including in my opinion the greatest movie ever made, 'Die Hard'.I truly believe that if this was never made, we probably wouldn't have had that influx of crazy action movies in the eighties, and Seagals, Van Damme, and even Schwarzeneggar would probably be obsolete.The story is great, the acting is fantastic, and it has a great score.If you haven't seen this, see it, you must.

An influential cop movie that helped make Eastwood into a superstar. It has his memorable soliloquy ("I know what you're thinking punk..."). Seeing it now, however, it is not much better than an episode of a cop show on TV. The script is rather lame. The scene where Eastwood jumps on the bus from the overpass is pretty silly. What happens to the yellow bag that Eastwood carries to the killer? Robinson makes a terrifying villain yet he's also pretty funny, particularly in the scene where he has the kids sing in the bus. Director Siegel is in his element in this kind of film. This is an interesting companion piece to Bullitt, a better film made three years earlier.

I know, I know, this is a classic, some speeches from this movie have become an icon in pop culture. But I have to write an honest review for people who haven't seen it before, which means they will watch it in 2020 or later, so I have to use modern standards to judge. And from that point of view, this movie has nothing that we haven't seen before, nor does it present it in a better way. It's just an action film, with a slower pace than we are used to in this genre. It's enjoyable, but it hasn't aged well.

reviews.review_title: The quintessential cop movie produces one of Hollywood's great tough guys
reviews.content: Maybe I'm 50 years too late to be watching this for the first time, but I'm not coming from the rose coloured glasses of nostalgia. Obviously coasting on the winning formula they had with the titular character, Clint Eastwood is the ultimate bad ass and it's fun to watch him play up that shtick. The movie surrounding him may be secondary, but it's still solid, with a suitably detestable villain and fast paced plot. Not sure if the cop movie cliches were already well established at this time or if this movie really laid the foundation for things to come, but familiar genre tropes abound. Under the modern lens, some things didn't age well, there is some cringey racial insensitivity, next to no female representation and the underlying idea that a rogue cop that shoots first and asks questions later is inherently a good thing, but it's a product of it's time and should be viewed accordingly.

In 1971 two movies were rivalling each other but would both go on to be cult classics. They were The French Connection and Dirty Harry. I thought The French Connection was absolutely terrible but Dirty Harry really blew me away. I seriously think it should be the pure classic of 1971, not The French Connection.Clint Eastwood plays his legendary signature role of Inspector Harry Callahan in the first of a series of five movies where he investigates a string of murders which leads on to a brilliant storyline. It has a few good action sequences too. But the most memorable part of the movie is Clint Eastwood's brilliant job as the conservative Inspector Harry Callahan whose character created the benchmark for many other similar movie roles. Eastwood may be well known when it comes to directing movies but when it comes to acting, it will be Harry Callahan for which he will be most remembered for.All the Dirty Harry movies are good but this first one is the best by far.

Early 1970s Hollywood saw the rise of vigilante films, which portrayed cops and citizens who were discontented by the state of crime in America and took up arms without a go-ahead from the police. In 1971, director Don Siegel and western star Clint Eastwood made 'Dirty Harry,' widely viewed as the definitive crime film of its time. While not entirely about vigilantism, 'Dirty Harry' is probably the best example of films that depict a justice system fixated on the rights of criminals when American cities are becoming overrun with felons who pay no heed to the law.'Dirty Harry' focuses on the deeds of Scorpio, a sniveling, obnoxious madman played by Andrew Robinson. Scorpio takes fun in placing all of San Francisco under siege by killing civilians from rooftops and threatening additional deaths if the city fails to pay a huge ransom. After some coddling by the police, Scorpio decides to kidnap a young girl whom he rapes and hides underground with limited oxygen. The police immediately turn to Harry Callahan (Eastwood), an inspector who is frowned upon for his rough-and-ready ways but tolerated since there are few 'dirty' assignments he won't take on. Callahan, already disillusioned by his superiors, is pushed even further to the limit in tracking down Scorpio and the missing teenager. With help from his new partner Gonzalez (Reni Santoni) and hanger-on Frank DiGiorgio (John Mitchum), Harry manages to capture Scorpio, only to see him walk free after the prosecution drops all charges on grounds of illegal search and seizure. Which leads, of course, to a hostage crisis that no sane person could imagineWhile the sentiments of 'Dirty Harry' may now seem quaint, the film still asks important questions about a middle ground between rights of innocent people and the accused. Callahan is depicted as a police officer who wants the American justice system to work, but finds himself at odds when trying to defend San Francisco against a ruthless lunatic. Harry sees law and order disintegrating at the hands of people like Scorpio, who are beyond reason and must be stopped at all costs. Callahan dishes out his personal brand of justice as expected, but the film ends rather bleakly, his vigilante-type deeds being just another indication of a society gone mad.Despite its controversy, 'Dirty Harry' had tremendous impact on the crime genre, leading to four sequels and influencing movies such as 'Death Wish,' 'Lipstick,' '10 to Midnight,' and the Abel Ferrara thriller 'Ms. .45.' A large portion of Dirty Harry's success is owed to Eastwood, whose rugged style of acting in the Leone westerns can be seen here. Eastwood's portrayal is balanced, with none of his speech or physical action wandering into excess. In fact, his acting is at times so understated that Harry comes across as a humorous and somewhat likable man. Only the role of Scorpio calls for an over-the-top presence and this is pulled off masterfully by Andrew Robinson, who admitted to having no experience in reading film scripts. The supporting roles, including Gonzalez (Reni Santoni), San Francisco's mayor (John Vernon), and Lieutenant Bressler (Harry Guardino), are all played with honesty.The straightforward editing of Carl Pingitore ('Play Misty for Me,' 'Across 110th Street') is nicely paced, keeping the action sequences moving at a brisk clip while at times slowing things down to keep the film grounded in reality. 'Dirty Harry' maximizes the San Francisco locations with broad angles and overhead shots by cinematographer Bruce Surtees. Never do we feel that 'Dirty Harry' is taking place in a studio or at a secondary venue. Composer Lalo Schifrin is also in top form with his eerie score that combines synthesizers and a regular ensemble to background this funky, depraved urban landscape.Although its sequels never lived up to the original installment, 'Dirty Harry' became a solid movie franchise, lasting for five titles over a 17-year period. Anyone who has seen heavily-edited, full frame versions of 'Dirty Harry' on television will appreciate Warner Brothers' 2000 DVD release of the film, which comes packed with extras. The movie is presented in its original widescreen format with Dolby 5.1 surround sound; French 'dubbing' is included with subtitles in English, French, and Spanish. Disc extras include a short documentary made at the time of Dirty Harry's release; a new 30-minute program on the impact of Dirty Harry, hosted by Robert Urich; interview clips with several who were involved in the Dirty Harry series; and the theatrical trailer.'Dirty Harry' is in excellent condition, although there are occasional artifacts such as grain and speckling. Unfortunately, its Dolby enhancement is not the finest, putting too much emphasis on gunshots and Schifrin's music. Dialogue and background noise are comparably soft, while Callahan's magnum and Schifrin's bass flex come out throbbing at climactic moments. This is not necessarily a bad thing, although it seems geared to those interested just in action. The original documentary is an interesting look at how 'Dirty Harry' was sold to audiences with its controversial subject matter. WB's new program is well-made and deals with the influence of Harry, but could have explored the film's initial reception and the flack its makers had to live with. Overall, fans of Harry should be pleased and the disc will be of great help in creating a new legion of fans.*** out of 4Roving Reviewer - www.geocities.com/paul_johnr

reviews.review_title: The Inimitable Clint Eastwood Gets Down and 'Dirty'!
reviews.content: Clint Eastwood was a Western icon for a fistful of spaghetti Westerns and cynical American copycats. When he strapped on his .44 Magnum to stride the streets of San Francisco as Inspector Harry Callahan, known to the squad as Dirty Harry, Eastwood turned his frontier persona into an urban cowboy on the mean streets of our urban world and helped him cultivate an iconic image.In Dirty Harry, maverick San Francisco cop Harry Callahan is ordered by the city mayor to stop a pathological, bigoted serial killer who calls himself Scorpio (Andy Robinson who proves to be a wonderfully odious villain). The psycho wants $100,000, or he will continue his bloody work. The mayor and others are willing to capitulate, but Eastwood disagrees, sensing it would be just the first payment. Eastwood bristles when teamed with young Chico (Reni Santoni) against his wishes (Chico fails Callahan on three counts, by being new to the force, Mexican-American, and, perhaps worst of all, college-educated); but he reluctantly begins to accept the junior partner. Scorpio says he's buried a teenage girl somewhere in the city and will let her die unless the town comes up with $200,000. Eastwood gets the job of delivering the money (backed up by Chico), but eventually pursues his own, extralegal route to nail Scorpio.Dirty Harry is both of its time and timeless. Visually it reeks of the early 1970s with enough graphic violence quite a bit of gratuitous female nudity on display. But at the same time the story is a gripping game of cat and mouse between cop and psycho killer that transcends the setting and time period. It is a visceral film, directed with urgency and style by Don Siegel, embellished with some of the coolest electro-jazz confections.But above all, Dirty Harry works because it is driven by the inimitable Clint as Detective "Dirty" Harry Callahan. Harry, the hero, is a flawed anachronism - a frontiersman in modern society. His tough-as-nails persona is one that has often been imitated. He bucks authority because he cares more about justice than he does about rules. Harry Callahan is both more openly scornful of the law, an equal opportunity bigot and, thanks to Eastwood's perfectly calibrated performance, more compelling an individual, than Siegel's earlier neo-vigilantes.In real life, we'd be terrified of Harry and the loose cannon he calls a handgun. On the big screen, you can't help but applaud his frontier justice as Eastwood mouths the now iconic line "Do you feel lucky, punk?"

Don Siegel has an impressive filmography, by any standards, but this may very well be his most memorable film. Eastwood's, too, depending on whom you ask. It's a movie that came roaring onto the big screen 40 years ago with something to prove, and it won't be forgotten anytime soon. Clint Eastwood stars as SFPD Inspector Harry Callahan who goes head-to-head with a crazed serial killer named Scorpio (Andrew Robinson). Scorpio moves from one victim to the next, with Inspector Callahan hot on his trail. While the upper level officials in the Mayor's office continue scrambling to come up ransom money, Callahan grows impatient with the red tape and civil rights issues that go hand-in-hand with being a cop and takes to vigilante justice (equipped with his ridiculously huge revolver) to bring Scorpio down.It's impressive just how well "Dirty Harry" holds up after forty years. It's tense filmmaking, and one of the finest gritty cop movies in cinema history. The film's anti-PC message of speaking for the rights of the victim is clear from the get-go, and punctuated by Harry's open disdain for the rules. Eastwood loves playing this guy; it's right there on the screen. And he sinks his teeth right in. Andrew Robinson really sells the unhinged killer, Lalo Schifin's supercool urban, jazzy score keeps everything humming on a real groove. This was not a movie to be taken lightly. Its impact on pop culture can be still be felt 40 years after the fact. You see a .44 Magnum, you think "Dirty Harry". More often than not, you see Clint Eastwood, you think "Dirty Harry". When Keifer Sutherland tortures a terrorist on TV, you know deep down that Eastwood pioneered that divisive hero. It's easy to get hung up on Harry's apparent fascistic role model (as Pauline Kael and Roger Ebert famously have), but it's also easy to eschew such politics in favor of what the movie's selling: Eastwood's badass cop is there to set things right, by a moral code that we (as moviegoers) can root for. 8.5/10

reviews.review_title: The modern cop film is born!
reviews.content: "Do you feel lucky...?" Yes, I do! Lucky enough to be able to retrospectively admire the greatness of Clint Eastwood. The actor-director was at the forefront of some of the most groundbreaking, original films of all time, A FISTFUL OF DOLLARS and the later films he did with Sergio Leone that re-invented the Western, PLAY MISTY FOR ME, the prototype for the stalker film, and of course, this film, DIRTY HARRY, the forefather of the modern day cop film. Before DIRTY HARRY (1971), cop movies were really 'just the facts' films, with cops being portrayed as humdrum, mostly uniformed officers who ALWAYS arrived at the scene one minute too late and who only liked to patrol around in their police cars eating donuts and drinking free coffee. This film changed all that.In DIRTY HARRY, the protagonist is a man's man of a cop: tough, abrasive, smart, quick-thinking, with a take-no-prisoners attitude. Screw the system! Our hero is one San Francisco Police Inspector Harry Callahan (played by the aforementioned Eastwood in a truly legendary performance). I don't think that Eastwood was ever thought of as a great actor, but one thing you can say for his films: he was always in on the joke. The "joke" here is that DIRTY HARRY is not just some standard good guys versus bad guys saga. It is really a not-so-subtle swipe at the not-always-fair police-judicial system. The film contains several scenes that illustrate the bureaucratic hogwash that goes along with catching criminals and trying to put them away (Miranda rights, illegal search and seizure, prisoner abuse, etc.) The main criminal in this film is obviously guilty, but the system allows him to go free on technicalities. The bad guy is a sniper who calls himself Scorpio (played by Andy Robinson in one of the creepiest performances of all time). Scorpio assassinates a girl in a swimming pool at the film's outset and then demands ransom from the city or he will kill more people until he gets what he wants. In comes Insp. Callahan, aka Dirty Harry to investigate and catch the killer. Harry is partnered with rookie Insp. Chico Gonzalez (played by Reni Santoni doing fine work). Harry reluctantly accepts Chico as his partner. It is implied that Harry may be prejudiced and he probably has never worked with a minority, but really Harry is a savvy veteran who knows how dangerous life is about to become for his new partner.Ironically, they catch Scorpio early on, but the system lets him free and so Harry's personal quest to bring down this vicious assassin makes up the 2nd half of the film. It must have been a strange twist in 1971 to actually catch the killer halfway through the film! Harry himself becomes a 'criminal' of sorts, stalking Scorpio, waiting for him to slip up, against department orders.DIRTY HARRY has of course one of the most famous speeches (the "lucky" speech) in film history, but that is not its only appeal. It is a very thrilling piece that keeps the viewer on the edge of their seats. The on-location shooting in beautiful San Francisco really is a character itself. The film really captures the gritty, urban feel and while the plot may be a tad preposterous, realistic scenery adds to the action, drama, and plot. The great director Don Siegel directed this film and it is right up there with the best of the 1970s. It definitely ushered in a new kind of cop hero in Harry Callahan, aka DIRTY HARRY.

reviews.review_title: Fantastic police thriller and beats easily many/most subsequent efforts of its kind
reviews.content:
Don Siegel's classic Dirty Harry has lost none of its power during all these years. Clint Eastwood's character is still among the most memorable and toughest police officers in any film, and also Andy Robinson as psychotic Scorpio is totally unmatchable in his lunatic performance. Dirty Harry is exactly what similar movies of today should be; far from calculated entertainment and thoroughly personal work.Dirty Harry is a tough cop in San Francisco where killer is on the loose. The killer demands huge amount of money in order to quit the killings, victims being chosen by random. Police is helpless as they don't know what to do, saving tax moneys seems to be more important than saving the lives of subsequent victims. Harry gets a partner and they start the relentless hunt and fight against time and that psychotic killer, named Scorpio.I hardly can say any negative points about this marvellous piece of film. This is challenging action cinema at its greatest. From what point it is "allowed" to use violence in order to make justice? Harry doesn't want to obey stupid and restrictive orders by authorities, he only wants to get that killer and stop the violence. He doesn't want Scorpio dead, he just wants to get him and trap him and thus get him in jail. But this seems not to work out, as all the things are against this kind of theory and Scorpio seems to have even media sympathy and protection on his side. It is obvious that Scorpio is unstoppable by using lawful methods, so Harry decides to do the Dirty job and stop him in any method, lawful or not. He is willing to sacrifice himself in order to stop the killings of Scorpio. This is really what makes the viewer think as even Scorpio has his rights that should not be violated. It is important to ask how this kind of person has been born and why, maybe the answer is not too far away from ourselves and the society we live in. The film does not praise violence, it just analyzes it and shows many aspects of it. The film criticizes society very much and is meant to be seen by all the leaders and police chiefs anywhere in the world. The setting is very gritty and ugly (both mentally and physically) as the city is full of pimps, criminals, violence and depravity, so it is obvious, there's something even worse than Scorpio and that may be/is the whole reason for Scorpio's existence.Dirty Harry is fantastically shot and edited and all the cinematic aspects of the film are very professional and as powerful today as they were back then, in the early 70's. This is among the most intense and exciting police thrillers I've seen and beats easily most of its imitators and miserable commercial efforts copying this original and incorruptible classic. Eastwood is here in his greatest performance as hardboiled cop in world that has boiled him very hard. It is easy to see how he puts his soul into the role as Harry. Andrew Robinson is among the scariest psychos I've seen, and just look at him at the end scene in the school bus. Very powerful and haunting performance by this talented actor.Don Siegel is here as masterful as director can be, and I think this is his masterpiece, but of course there are many other great films in his filmography, too. Dirty Harry is a film that should be seen in theatre but if that's not possible, make sure you watch it in widescreen format as the film looks gorgeous in its original wide aspect ratio. I'd seen this previously on full screen format, and now that I watched it in full widescreen, the viewing experience was fantastic. It is sad that so many home videos are in wrong aspect ratio made to "suit your television."
Dirty Harry is classic masterpiece of action cinema and very thought-provoking in its content, themes and messages about society and people in it and in charge of it. Highly recommended and gets definitely the highest 10 rating from me.

The movie Dirty Harry really is all it's cracked up to be: A damned good action-packed crime-thriller. Dirty Harry (Clint Eastwood) is out to get the notorious and crazed Scorpio-killer Andy Robinson (Andrew Robinson). It is a film worth watching if you like crime-thrillers with some action.Some critics are not fond of Andy Robinson as the Scorpio-killer but I have to completely disagree. I think Robinson was perfect for the role. With Andrew playing the role, we have a killer (Andy) with an innocent look about him - and that alone is enough to believe him blameless of such gruesome crimes - but behind his looks is a mind of a criminally sick man. Outstanding performance by Andrew Robinson.Clint Eastwood - he is just as good as always. He is a well seasoned, brilliant actor.8.5/10

Along with The French Connection, this influential thriller set the standard for cop movies for the 70's, i.e. tough, violent, bleak and unflinching. This movie, in particular, attracted a lot of criticism that it was a fascistic celebration of police brutality. And while it's hard to argue against this, Dirty Harry is an extremely well-made thriller that is still sufficiently edgy and energetic to appeal to modern audiences.It's about a renegade cop called Harry Callaghan who is on a mission to stop – by any means possible – a psychotic killer-hippy who is holding San Francisco to ransom. Clint Eastwood is perfectly cast in the lead role. This, along with his Man With No Name roles in Sergio Leone's Dollars Trilogy, is his most defining and iconic screen performance. He is believably tough and has a great screen presence. Other standout members of the cast are Andy Robinson as the vile villain and John Vernon as the agreeably cheesy mayor. The film is helped hugely, too, by the great soundtrack by Lalo Schifrin. This funky score gives the film an energy and atmosphere that's integral to its success. It compliments both the high octane action and the suspense scenes. There's some great cinematography too, such as the beautiful pan of the San Francisco Bay early in the movie and the extraordinary reverse zoom that takes us from Callaghan torturing Scorpio in the sports stadium to high up in the sky; an incredible shot.This film still holds up well after all these years. It still has retained much of its edge. Don Siegel keeps everything moving along at a great pace and shows himself very adept at creating a threatening atmosphere when required. The set-piece in the park at night is almost in Italian giallo territory. Going back to the accusations of Dirty Harry appealing to a right-wing mentality and that the Scorpio character represents the ugly side of the counter-culture, deserving of no mercy from the authorities. While all this is true, it's also true that the villain is such an irredeemable scumbag that it is impossible not to back Harry Callaghan to the hilt. And at the end of the day this is a cop-thriller so no one should really be taking it THAT seriously. A much better approach is to just sit back, relax and enjoy a classic hard, sleazy and thrilling piece of 70's cinema.

The great invention of this movie is Scorpio. Without Scorpio there is no need for Harry. With Scorpio Clint Eastwood could bounce off a great performance. The music score and the cinematography are the other great performances. Other than that it is a simple action movie with a very bad guy. When I first saw it, it hit the spot. Now that I am a little older I recognize the stereotypes. It was one of the first to dial up violence, portray a degenerate, show nudity, criticize liberals... go for the red meat.

reviews.review_title: A Great Start to a Long Series
reviews.content: This is the first in Clint Eastwood's Dirty Harry series. It set a new standard for action movies, in my opinion. It started a trend with a main character who operates just within or just outside the law, dispensing justice with hard-nosed action. The San Francisco scenes are excellent; the dialog is perfect; and Eastwood was great in this role. The action is very realistic, although we know that our laws would not allow it to really happen. The bad guy is so bad that we have no pity for him at all and are happy to see him die. The role was played to perfection by Andrew Robinson, who was new to movies, coming from the stage. I like all the Dirty Harry movies, and this one really set the stage for the series. I will watch it again often.

Last time, while I was reading the news on my laptop, I was both shocked and saddened by the story of a young 17-year old girl raped and killed while jogging before her corpse would be meticulously hidden and burnt, a sordid and macabre story whose savagery unfortunately equals its daily frequency in our world. And while I was reading the Internet readers' comments, I found out that many of them, filled with the same anger than I, were demanding vengeance or asking for more ruthlessness from the authorities. And although I always try to be rational, the cruelty of the crime made me question my own approach to justice, if its blindness puts the victim and the criminal on an equal foot or if its only purpose should be to punish and repress those who banish themselves from society.That's the issue, the frontier between repression and fascism is so thin that any zealous expression of Law's repressive hand can be perceived as oppressive. This is why "Dirty" Harry Callahan was probably one of these characters that embodied so many contradictions he became one of the quintessential anti-heroic figures of American cinema, and it's no surprise that he was created during that glorious 'New Hollywood' era that tackled social issues with a rebellious attitude and total disregard for political correctness. The contradiction of "Dirty" Harry is that in the context of the 70's where urban criminality reached a high level of violence and savagery, it put the police cops in a weak position, in the public opinion's eyes, so people needed a strong model to incarnate Law and Authority. But during that same context, a new air of freedom and rebellion against the power was filling the youth's hearts, or any idealistic people that could perceive Harry as a fascist. We can say that basically, there were two sides in 1971, the Jimmy "Popeye" Doyle and the Alex De Large's side, while "Dirty" Harry has something of both.Harry Callahan is the incarnation of Law in its most Antic form, carrying his iconic Magnum .44 as the sword to fight the evildoer and the shield to protect the widow and the orphan, yet he's victim of his own hatred, and uses violence as a personal policy, with a Magnum that provides a virile magnetism, inspiring our respect despite everything. Indeed, Clint Eastwood incarnates this violence with such charisma and the perfect amount of fierceness in his eyes that it's hard not to find him appealing, and I defy any man not to have a male crush on him, seriously, I'm not ashamed to admit that he's probably the most handsome and manly character ever. And what makes him so dangerously attractive is the key element he has in common with De Large, more than Doyle : his enjoyment of ultra violence. If you look closer : he get his kicks by applying justice with his Magnum, as a phallic extension. The way he uses his 'feel lucky' catchphrase as an usual tirade that allows him to tease the criminal is the little delight, sadistic maybe, but with quite an allure.But I guess this is the danger of Dirty Harry and what earned the film so many criticisms at the time of its release when it was labeled as a "right-wing fantasy" or a film with fascist tendencies, as if it conveyed the dangerous idea that the ends justified the means, and the use of violence can be legitimate in some extreme cases. And maybe this is the manipulative aspect of the film, it features an extremely vicious criminal who kills innocent people, more innocent than usual, just for money and certainly not without pleasure. As much as we admire the performance of the actor, he's impossible to root for, as he represents the degeneration of a society with no values and morality, and the most capable hero must have the same level of cruelty as the villain. It's an eye for an eye yes, it's not very legal, but this is Harry's law. It's not fascist, it's just 'extreme'. An extreme way used in the right side of the law, and 40 years later, despite all the criticism from left-wing or feminist movements, the movie had four sequels, and Harry Callahan is one of the most iconic movie characters ever, #17 in AFI's list of heroes, for having paved the way to other classic "loose cannon" cops facing incompetent superiors like in "Die Hard" or "Lethal Weapon".The movie stood the test of time, and for a simple reason: people needed a character like "Dirty Harry" to identify with, to stop associating the law with dumb policemen or simple comic reliefs, they needed a model of power and manly integrity. The "right-wing fantasy" is half right, there is something super-heroic in Callahan, that makes the movie like a sort of fantasy, but the man is vulnerable, he takes hits, he's victim of his own prejudices and bigotry, he's got the same flaws as an Ethan Edwards or a Fred C. Dobbs, which makes his brutality, more forgivable because he's fundamentally good. He's definitely the archetypal antihero, and maybe his appeal is revealing or our own subconscious perception of violence. Something we condemn, we debate on, but which we're glad when it's being done.I started the review by evoking a news item, I will conclude with something more global by comparing Harry to those soldiers who were sent to Vietnam if we keep the movie into context, or now in Iraq, or Afghanistan to do all the dirty jobs, while the politicians were talking about freedom, justice, and democracy, all these big words without echoes in those doomed places in the world. Harry fascinates us, because he makes us think of our own hypocritical approach to violence, and our possible need of dirty Harries to clean our consciences, maybe that's the question we've got to ask ourselves.

In San Francisco, detective Harry Callhan (Clint Eastwood) is on the verge to hunt down a deadly assassin named Scorpio (Andy Robinson) whom has been killing some helpless victims as he wants the city for ransom.Outstanding and original crime action thriller that became one of the most influential and popular movies of the genre and became one of Eastwood's signature roles. The film was a major success back in 1971 among audiences and critics alike, the performances are great especially the legendary John Vernon whom you remember as the Dean from "Animal House" and there's the legendary quote "You gotta ask yourself, do you feel lucky punk? well do you? punk!".Here is a no-nonsense thrill ride that keeps you on the edge of your seat and never let's go! if you have good taste in films then this is worth owning for your movie collection.

reviews.review_title: the one that started it all
reviews.content: while i did like this first film in the Dirty Harry series for the most part,there were a few things about it that didn't work for me.one thing was i thought it was a bit slow in spots,not enough to make a huge difference in quality,just enough to notice.also the story***possible minor spoiler.i think it was based(loosely)on the real life Zodiac killings***end of spoiler.it just seemed a bit ordinary to me.it didn't have any gravitas or oomph to it.the acting was good all around,although i have to single out Andy Robinson who was superb as the villain.overall,despite a few minor problems,this is still a very good film,with many more positive aspects than negatives.for me,Dirty Harry is a 7/10

reviews.review_title: Eastwood's Signature Role Is Still A Winner
reviews.content: Clint Eastwood will always be thought of as Dirty Harry - even I, who had never before seen Dirty Harry, knew enough about the movie for instance, to be able to understand the similarities between Harry and Eastwood's character of Walt Kowalski from 2008's "Gran Torino." This is his signature role for good reason - he's perfectly cast as Inspector Harry Callahan and the movie is both exciting and interesting and has a realistic feel to it.Callahan is assigned to locate a serial killer who calls himself "Scorpio" and threatens to kill a person a day unless the city of San Francisco pays him $100,000 (later raised to $200,000.) Callahan doesn't go by the book. In his view, his job is to get the bad guys and that's what he does - except that not going by the book lets the serial killer get away, because his constitutional rights were violated. That's really the underlying theme of the movie - how do you defend the rights of the innocent victims when you have to be so concerned about the rights of the accused. That's a concern that remains with us even today, so even though the movie is almost 40 years old, it still has a relevance to it; a message which will resonate with many people. The movie leads up to a pretty exciting ending with the school bus hijacking, and Callahan's last statement of contempt for the system in which he works.If I were to compare this to, say, "Gran Torino" (Eastwood's latest and perhaps last movie) I'd say that I preferred "Gran Torino" more because there seemed to be more sustained excitement in it, whereas "Dirty Harry" (because Callahan is an active cop) has a few more mundane scenes, since it has to portray the system in which Callahan works. I still liked this, though. It's a great role for Eastwood.

reviews.review_title: Well made, Strong ending, Thick but Poignant
reviews.content: So the film certainly starts off slow. It looks like it's going to be a completely self-explanatory, ostensibly obvious and pretty painful watch with as predictable a development as the ending would be. It turns out that: no, that's just that first half hour. Gradually the film takes a hold of the viewer and drags him into a more enticing development of the plot, one that engages the public right into the thick of the film's crux. It's like the film at its core has a heavy weight to bear and wishes to unload the burden onto the viewer, who finds himself morally and emotionally committed to the lead character's dilemma: going by the letter of the law and following standard procedure - or - choosing what 'feels right' regardless of the institutions.The film does a well enough job to not be as clichéd as you'd expect, to not be too linear with the plot which is praiseworthy since the film's entirety is really just one big premise (and 'Dirty Harry' so easily could've been a constant reiteration of the same scene over and over), and the protagonist despite being basically a comic book character still remains very relatable for his humanity which is also very much commendable. Strong ending with a very symbolic gesture which gives the whole all the more meaning and appeal, and you know a movie that ends well is infinitely more important than a movie that merely starts well (!).7.5/10.
