reviews.review_title: The beginning of a classic 70's series
reviews.content: This movie is the epitome of what 70's movie was at least for this type, and has many good aspect to it. This movie may come off a bit cliché but it has certain elements that make it really stand out, plus it's a movie from the 70's. Not just that this was somewhat the pioneer when it comes to cop versus serial killer style scenario, well at least the direction of it all. This movie is about Harry Callahan played by Clint Eastwood who is a badass inspector that gets into some police action while trying to track down the main villain who kills innocent people with a sniper rifle. This movie is constant but steady cop action movie. Sure some parts the cops seem overly incompetent at times and the villain sometimes comes off really ridiculous although vile. But it doesn't go way too over the top, overall this movie is a steady action/thriller that doesn't get boring. It even has classic one liners like "you gotta ask yourself one question. Do I feel lucky? Well do you punk?". Sometimes the dialogue maybe a bit silly at times but it doesn't get to the point where it gets irritating to listen to. This isn't the best movie I seen for this type of genre but for a movie that is made in the 70's it's really authentic.8/10

This iconic film is ridiculously underrated. Even if you have an aversion to violence in movies, you must appreciate this film.1). Of the 5 in the series, it received the highest rating by IMDb viewers. That's good, just not nearly high enough.2). The storyline of a good, yet very tough, widower cop who's extreme conviction to stopping crime (that is matched only by his self-confidence and bravura), set the tone for so many copycats (in one form or another), to follow.3). This is #1 factor: Andy Robinson. I have spoken to so many, and it's acknowledged in so many circles; that his portrayal of the killer was beyond impeccable. Believable like so many other ARE NOT. Robinson had much trouble landing roles after Dirty Harry. So how can you be typecast from a single 2 hr movie? Only one way. Just be that damned convincing. He wasn't nuts, nor was he portrayed that way. He was just evil. Sure Hannibal was scary, but that villain is quasi-fantasy, and that's ok. There was nothing unbelievable about Andy Robinson's Scorpio killer. He didn't just pull it off; he killed it. Deserved awards. That's not an easy role to play. Most villains since then, are so over the top, they're often cartoonish.4). If you want to have a good looking guy, who's ultra cool, successful with the ladies, suave, well, who better than Clint? I mean really. Can you believe Sinatra was the original choice by casting. Thank God he turned it down. I mean seriously, that's fair.I wouldn't ask Eastwood to sing New York New York. I don't know a female friend, including my own honey, that doesn't concur on this point (re- Eastwood's sex appeal.)5). The story moved well, with different scenarios.A). First, your introduction to who Harry really is (Bank Robbery)
b). Why he's called dirty (his new partner, the suicide attempt, and more.).C). Scorpio running Harry around SF, so as to get his ransom without a hitch.D). Scorpio turning the tables on Harry by having a professional beat him 1/2 to death, blame Harry, and get the press on his side, with the primary goal achieved, getting Harry off his tail.E.). The final showdown was very good as well, which I won't go into since I'm sure y'all have seen the movie 10-15 times by now. What's that tell you about the entertainment value of this film.Ok, more than enough said.Thx for listening.Bob R.

One of Clint Eastwood's most influential films.Harry Callahan is a character that is almost impossible to see on the movie screen today, an uncompromising and vicious policeman who despises crime and does not hesitate to use his gun against criminals.The film is as uncompromising as its main character, showing how criminals avoid punishment, but that in the end they still get the fate they deserve.It shows how journalists are sometimes irresponsible and judges naive and gullible, and in the end Inspector Harry Callahan has to deal with the
killer himself. Andrew Robinson brilliantly portrayed the psychopathic and manipulative killer.The cinematography is interesting and the music suits the atmosphere of the film. The direction is interesting, the film has an authentic look of the early seventies and perfectly evokes the atmosphere of that time.An unforgettable classic.

reviews.review_title: Great telelens photography, great Lalo Schifrin soundtrack, great slowburning story UP untill a quite ridiculous plot turn, which deflates the whole suspense. Still enjoyable!
reviews.content: A hardboiled cop, who doesnt follow the rules, has to track down a serial killer. Will he find him and at what cost?Dirty Harry really is a riveting cop movie UP until an hour into the movie. Then all of a sudden there is a quite ridiculous plot turn which deflated all the suspense there was up to that point. I never like it when the writer doesnt take his movie audience seriously.Part of a series of 4 Clint Eastwood cop movies in which violence and retribution get glorified and civil rights and police procedures get ridiculed. This is a full on promo for police brutality and the way in which this story is portrayed I was rooting for the cops to get violent as well. That's the power of this classic, it really quite convincingly let's me believe that cop violence is good and the only way forward to combat crime, which ofcourse it isnt.Lots of fierce criticism followed when this movie was released in 1971, because of the glorification of violence and the disrespect for civil rights. In the second editon of the Dirty Harry series, called "Magnum Force" Eastwood has suddenly become a civil rights promotor instead of bashing those rights in like he does in this first edition. Clint Eastwood mentioned in an interview that he liked "Magnum Force" the best of all the Dirty Harry series (4).Besides the well known cool poses and oneliners by Clint Eastwood, lots of attention for technical detail went into this movie, resulting in great (telelens) photography for instance, the likes I havent seen much lately. A great, spacious sounding soundtrack by the legendary Lalo Schifrin is another one of those delightful technical details, which enhances the power of this already suspenseful movie.

reviews.review_title: Defining movie and role for Eastwood
reviews.content:
I would dare say one of the more important films in Eastwood's rich career. His Harry has become an icon and a definition of the character he will play for the next few decades. Stubborn, full of hatred for almost all people, but always ready to act justly according to his postulate, which is why he often conflicts with the law. Certain criticism in this film is obviously directed at the American law that allows a multiple psychopath-killer to go free. A psychopath called Scorpio, whose real name we don't even know, is creepy and dangerous, a worthy opponent of Dirty Harry. His character is based on the famous Zodiac killer who harassed, killed and left messages to the police. The film balances brilliantly between a thoroughbred shot and a suspenseful thriller, and the Magnum is currently becoming the most popular gun in the world. We see a great characterization of the characters seemingly in small and irrelevant scenes and conversations where we learn a lot about what Callahan really is, like a scene where his lunch is interrupted by a bank robbery, when he talks to a potential suicide, to a partner or his boss and law enforcement. What a cult classic it would be without the iconic final showdown and the very end of the film. After solving the case, but in his own way, Harry showed one contrast that was in keeping with his character. Although he has sorted everything out with a big bang, he still ends up in silence and without a word, far away from us because he is aware that as a representative of the law he still cannot protect those who should protect the same law. The interesting thing is that the directorial debut of Eastwood (Play Misty for me) was released in the same year, and we also have a collaboration with Don Siegel, the director of Dirty Harry, who got a role in the film here. What a great year in the resume! (This is 1971, a full fifty years have already passed). A real classic that will be given to us four more sequels, but also an influence on many films that were made after this. I can say that this was a very brave move to make a film like this in the very beginning of the seventies. Eastwood has made better films, of better quality, but this is certainly the cornerstone of his career, probably the most iconic and recognizable because in later films he will always weave at least a little Inspector Callahan (Gran Torino is a film about retired Dirty Harry, right?).
I feel lucky, even though I'm not a punk.

reviews.review_title: Good acting by Clint Eastwood,but the film is just another action film with bad story.
reviews.content: A cop determined to bring in psychotic serial killer Robinson, even if he has to break some rules.This film is not exciting,that´s maybe because I don´t like the story.Clint Eastwood acts great as the hard(almost crazy)cop Harry Callahan.3/5

(There are Spoilers) The movie "Dirty Harry" begins and ends in a body of water. As if it had to do with the primal fears of safety and survival that flow in depths of the minds of those watching the motion picture."Dirty Harry" starts off with a girl diving into a swimming pool and then being caught in the cross-hairs of the sadistic killer in the film, Scorpio, and shot dead, The movie ends with Scorpio trying to go for his gun after "Dirty Harry" Callahan had blown it out of his hand a moment before and then being blasted by Harry's 44 Magnum and falling into the river dead. In between those two scenes director Don Siegle and actor Clint Eastwood constructed a morality play about whats wrong in America circa 1971. The criminals are too safe and the law abiding public are not thank to the liberals and the laws they passed in favor of the criminal element in this country. This was in 1971 before crimes in high places by CEO's as well as elected officials became common place in the news. If "Dirty Harry" were made today it would not have any impact at all on the public like it did back in 1971 and would have flopped in the box office because the public has learned a lot since then. What the public learned is that if you take the rights away from one person, no matter how guilty he may seem to be, you take the rights away from every one of us no matter how innocent we are. In the movie Harry could do no wrong, he's right in every one of his actions, in his war against the criminal element of San Francisco. His superiors, from the mayor on down, come across as gutless cowards at best or lying hypocrites at worst and make those watching the movie wonder just how they ever got elected and kept their jobs in the first place.With the danger to the public now gone Harry, in disgust, at the end of the movie throws his badge into the river where the dead Scorpio is floating, whom he had just shot. Like Gary Cooper in "High Noon" Harry turns his back on the society that he just saved from the likes of Scorpio and walks into the sunset leaving them to fend for themselves, because they didn't accept and appreciate what he's done for them.In short the movie "Dirty Harry" was really a propaganda film for less laws and more power for those in power. It was interesting to see that in only two years, at the height of the Watergate scandal in 1973, after "Dirty Harry" was released that it's sequel "Magnum Force" had "Dirty Harry" Callahan talking like the wimps and cowards in the first "Dirty Harry" movie. Harry is now in favor of letting the law and the system do it's job. Harry's enemy in that movie is a squad of vigilante cops who were nothing but "Dirty Harry" clones led by a corrupt police official and at one point in the movie they even invited Harry to join them which of course he refused. Thats what was the difference between the original "Dirty Harry" movie and the four sequels that followed it. The first took itself seriously and the others didn't. What we learned since 1971, when "Dirty Harry" was released, was what Benjamin Franklin said over two hundred years ago: "That when one gives up his rights for peace and security he ends up having neither", and so did the film makers of the "Dirty Harry" movies.

reviews.review_title: Why isn't this movie in the top 250????
reviews.content: Most actors are lucky if they have one moment that outlives their whole career. Clint Eastwood has had loads of these, but Dirty Harry still stands as his defining moment.Eastwood claimed in a documentary that the film struck a chord with people at that time because of the legal system being more concerned with the rights of the criminal than the victim. The audience feel Harry's frustration at not being able to see justice done. The legal system practises law, Harry Callahan and his 44 Magnum practise justice.The film is more famous for setting the standards for urban cop movies. It's fair to say that every screen cop since then owes some inspiration to Harry Callahan i.e no Martin Riggs, no Vincent Hanna. There wouldn't even be a Rambo. Between Eastwood, director Don Siegel and writers Harry Julian Fink and his wife, R.M Fink, they conjured up a cop that people looked up to and admired. It appears 'Dirty' Harry Callahan isn't going into obscurity ever.

A gritty urban police drama with exceptional direction by Siegel. Clint plays the hard boiled detective that will stop at nothing to get his man. Andrew Robinson is excellent playing the demented homicidal gunman rampaging through early 70's San Francisco. One of the most impressive shots in any police drama is the aerial of Clint hovering over the killer in the middle of the football field,foot to injured leg,Scorpio screaming in pain as the camera pans straight out of Kezar Stadium.

reviews.review_title: Good story and cinematography with OK acting.
reviews.content: Dirty Harry can be argued as having been the pioneer of cop films which paved the way for many more cop films later on. As this genre is increasingly popular, it is hard to compare and to see how this film works in regards to itself. Keeping in mind that this is a very early cop film I would have to say that it did a pretty good job.I don't think I have ever actually seen a young Clint Eastwood before, and it was rather unnerving to see so much likeness of how he looks now compared to then. He did a good job of playing the cool, tough cop who - though is a man of the law, doesn't really follow it. He judges his morality as higher than others and in the name of justice, does what he thinks is right in order to correct the wrong. Andrew Robinson who plays the killer gives an erratic performance which befitted his character. Very wild and out of control, his 'crazy' eyes are characteristic of his character, as are the animalistic screams he makes.The story is pretty average, with the focus on Harry and his obsession on getting the killer. The film kind of shows that the law isn't very good at protecting its citizens though, with Harry being depicted as the only one who really cares if the killer is caught (with the exception of his partner Chico). But the story was pretty engaging and had good action scenes.There was also some pretty great shots in this. We get some pretty good point of view shots from Harry and the killer's perspective. But noticeably, the most impactful shot is probably the one where Harry is standing on the bridge as the bus travels on the road below. For some reason it reminds me of the terminator, what with his sunglasses and all.However this film does have some issues with race, gender and social hierarchy. For one, all the high ranking officers/ powerful figures are white and the robbers who appear briefly are black. The killer himself while is white, is feminized in the way he walks and screams while Harry is the epitome of masculinity with his calm demeanour and low voice. There are hardly any women in this film too, except to be victims or someone's wife, not to mention that the killer is made out to be homophobic as he targets a gay man in one of the scenes. Furthermore the many reasons why dirty Harry is called dirty comes into play, not just as a referral to him doing all the dirty jobs, but also because he is a sort of peeping tom.Read more movie reviews at: championangels.wordpress.com

I just saw the film again on TV for the first time in many years, and several avoidable errors were apparent.  Factual error: When Harry finds the empty cartridge case atop the building, it's a .308 but later he says it's a (much longer) .30-06.Factual error: In the bank shootout when Harry's leg is struck by several shotgun pellets in his leg he's a good 35 yards from the shooter (he walks about 40 paces beyond the car) yet the hit pattern is extremely tight--impossible at that distance.More importantly, he fired four rounds from his revolver yet he's empty when he asks "Do you feel lucky?"  If that's in the original version, it's a serious story/continuity error.

reviews.review_title: Launching a Hollywood legend---Dirty Harry is a classic of its time
reviews.content: As one of the world's biggest Clint Eastwood fans I can already foresee fellow Eastwood fans taking offense to my 'low' rating. It actually surprised me when I re-watched Dirty Harry which I hadn't seen for probably better than 10 years. It isn't that I dislike Dirty Harry whatsoever. You couldn't possibly NOT like Dirty Harry, the character and the film is legendary and I thoroughly enjoy ranting out Harry's infamous "Do you feel lucky, punk?" speech whenever I get the chance. However I also believe Dirty Harry has lost something to time. One of the things that makes Dirty Harry so legendary is the timing. Dirty Harry put a strong face to the law who didn't have the best reputation coming out of the sixties and rioting. Harry Callahan hated everyone equally...he wasn't racist, he just hated all scum of any color and wasn't afraid to pull his gun to blow that scum away if need be. Essentially Harry Callahan was the original Jack Bauer (24--Kiefer Sutherland) The film set up a deranged killer that certainly looked the psycho role and you rooted for Harry because he was determined to always do the right thing no matter what he had to do to do it.Clint Eastwood is Dirty Harry. He was Harry before Harry existed and he'll be Harry long after he's gone. Eastwood being the baddest ass dude on the planet and Harry is clearly the baddest ass cop on the planet. It's not a brilliant performance but it also has more depth than some of his earlier work, like his Westerns. It is good that they serialized the Dirty Harry films because this first movie left you wanting to know more about him. Dirty Harry launched a four decade career for actor Andrew Robinson who after seeing him play the "Scorpio" killer you'll be convinced he truly is deranged. He has few lines but what he does with his facial expressions and his eyes is just astounding. The large supporting cast includes the likes of John Vernon, John Larch, and Reni Santoni to name a few of the stronger members. The problem is they all should get more screen time and they seem like strong characters but they take a back seat.Dirty Harry could also be described as one of the great cat and mouse films of all time. Harry chasing Scorpio through various locations and situations but then that isn't the only thing happening in the film. Harry is also breaking up robberies, stopping to help citizens and busting the scum off the street. Legendary director Don Siegel takes the helm and gives it his gritty style that is a must for the film. It's almost like he takes the wild west and turns it into a modern day San Francisco. Siegal and Eastwood worked together a lot in the seventies and I'm thinking why Eastwood was likely able to create Harry Callahan exactly the way he wanted him to be. Dirty Harry is almost always classified as an "action film" but it isn't. Instead Dirty Harry is a dark drama about a cop who will stop at nothing to take a psychotic off the streets. Harry Callahan is Jack Bauer, Martin Riggs, Starsky, Hutch, Rockford, and Columbo rolled into one hero. It is a must see but don't expect it to live up to the standards of nowadays. 7/10

Dirty Harry came in the same year as FRENCH CONNECTION that made Gene Hackman the 'badass' cop. But Clint Eastwood's Harry Callahan stands out even today for his 'dirty' ways The movie starts on a promising note and soon turns into a cat and mouse game between the hero and the villain. There is nothing exceptional in the story but it is the screenplay that gels well with Clint Eastwood's 'dirty' act keeping you engaged till the very last frame. Don Siegel masterful direction has always extracted the best from Clint Eastwood and this movie is no exception to that. The antagonist in the movie is weak but it is his rather unconventional ways that makes him a perfect villain opposite the anti-hero Harry. No doubt the movie churned out 4 more movies, PUNK!

"I know what you're thinking. Did he fire six shots or only five? Well, to tell you the truth, in all this excitement, I've kinda lost track myself. But being as this is a .44 Magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world, and would blow your head clean off, you've got to ask yourself one question: Do I feel lucky? Well, do ya punk?"It's sad to say that many people don't understand this movie. Many people think that this is just another action movie with a lot of unnecessary violence. The fact is that it's not. This movie is supposed to represent realistic violence and give us a glimpse of San Francisco in the `70s. At the same time it showed us a cop who doesn't go by the rules but still gets results. Harry is basically a character we can all relate with and that combined with every day violence makes a more interesting and complex feature. This is basically an early Scorsese movie not directed by him.***out of****stars

reviews.review_title: Changed the Action Genre For the Next 20+ Years!
reviews.content: This is the movie that sets the mould for the cop action genre for a long time. Even Liam Neeson's Taken owes a lot to this movie.The hero (some times anti-hero), tough uncompromising, brutal, arrogant, funny (at other's expense) and all out of patience.I have a job to do...get out of my way...you don't like it...here's my badge!As a movie doesn't pack the oomph that it did upon its initial release, but still an out and out classic!

reviews.review_title: Superior in more ways than one.
reviews.content:
So much has been made of the character of "Dirty Harry" and what he stands for that it's easy to forget just how technically well-made this film is.
I think we all know about what kind of a cop Eastwood plays in these films, so I won't go into great detail about the character. I will say, however, that Clint Eastwood's portrayal of this maverick cop is the main reason he is my all-time favorite actor. In this original installment, we see Dirty Harry track down a sociopath sniper who is picking off random victims and demanding $ from the city. Sniper cases have become all too familiar in real life these past couple of years, thus it sort of makes this film timely despite its age. The story, acting, and pacing are superb. But where this film really sets itself apart from the others in the series is the work of director Don Siegel and cinematographer Bruce Surtees. So many memorable shots! My favorite are as follows:Very early on, we see the sniper taking his position on a rooftop in San Francisco. He has a woman in a swimming pool on the roof of another building in his sights... Bang! She never could have dreamed what hit her, but we could see it coming from a mile away.A few moments later, Clint is up on the rooftop where the shot was fired. As he walks around looking for clues, the camera follows his every step, and we get an incredible view of the entire San Francisco Bay behind him. Wow!And how about that shot of him with the sniper in the middle of the football field? The camera raises and almost floats out of old Kezar Stadium as Clint begins to "apply pressure" to the gunshot wound he has inflicted on the "suspect". This is one of the most unforgettable shots I have ever seen in a film.And the very next shot is so beautiful, yet so dreary. We have Clint on a hillside over-looking the Golden Gate Bridge in the earliest glimpse of morning light while below him, the body of a young girl is being recovered from a hole in the ground where our "suspect" left her to die.San Francisco looks like such a beautiful city. Much like in real life, the San Francisco of this film serves as a heavenly stage for some truly grotesque behavior by its inhabitants. This was the first dvd I ever bought. I'm glad I did, because I had forgotten what a truly awesome film this was.10 of 10 stars seems fair enoughSo sayeth the Hound.

reviews.review_title: The most important American-made film of the past 50 years!
reviews.content: Recently I've considered drastically negatively re-appraising Clint Eastwood's work, both directorially and as a thespian, as a knee-jerk reaction to his constant defense of the more racially-bigoted face of conservative America, but because of what his work has meant to me as a cinephile over the years, plus in tribute to everyone else's work involved in this film, particularly director Don Siegel's, that simply wouldn't be fair.As well, you're basically getting, boiled down in its 103-minute timespan, 45 years after the fact, the main dilemma facing the USA. Whose rights are more important--the good guys' or the bad guys'? If they're equal, should they be considered equal, and what does that mean to the law enforcement and judicial systems? Quite simply, THE most important American-made film of the past 50 years. NOT my very favourite (that's '2001: A Space Odyssey'), but the most significant.And it hasn't aged a single day because of it.
I don't know if this movie looks odd because it is old or looks old because it is odd... but it is still rather enjoyable despite the numerous clichés.

reviews.review_title: A hardened veteran San Francisco Police inspector is assigned the task of tracking down a crazed crook that has become of menace to the Bay Area.
reviews.content: In the early 70s, the city of San Francisco was a place of many diverse lifestyles. As a seasoned officer for the SFPD, Inspector Harry Callahan has made these various experiences his routine, and he doesn't like it one bit. Preferring the "shoot first, ask second" approach to police work, Callahan is living in a city where his version of justice is old-fashioned. His grit has put him at odds with the upper-ranks, and as a result he is given every dirty case investigation. When we first meet our titular character, he has been brought into the Mayor's office because a psychotic man self-named "Scorpio" has sent a ransom letter. The man has already killed once, and we have seen his skill with a sniper rifle. The criminal says that he will continue his killing rampage unless he is given $100,000. Contrary to Callahan's insistence on taking down the crook before he kills again, the department decides to play the bad guy's game. This decision will send Callahan to track down the elusive Scorpio, and to reveal the growing failure in the city's justice system.For years and years, I've heard that Dirty Harry is a classic. The "did I fire five shots or six?" and "do you feel lucky, punk?" lines have been on every list I've ever seen of "Most Famous Lines of All-Time", and so I was excited to see this film at last. Clint Eastwood is a master of the "lone hero" sub-genre of action flicks, and this is one of his signature roles. While this film does highlight Eastwood's steely composure and quick gun-hand, I found this film lacking in one major area: its storyline. Maybe it was the fact that I watched it on TV (meaning multiple pauses for fast-forwarding), or maybe it's because it truly did lack in proper execution, but this movie just did not flow well enough for my liking. Hailed as one of the best thrillers of the 1970s, I came into this film with quite high expectations, and these prospects were found soundly untouched. Putting aside this fault, from a technical standpoint, this film was well done. The cinematography was done reasonably well, and the acting was the same. Though this movie did not receive any attention from the Academy, this film in my opinion was edited very well. Following my time watching this film, I looked up some other people's reviews, both amateur and professional. In some cases, the reviewer saw something in the film that I did not. However, I found the factor that both made it a success at its time of release and the reason why it did not click with me: it's portrayal of society at a time where it clashed with the norm. At the time of Dirty Harry's release, the popular trend in society was to be more focused on sympathizing with the killer and less on the victim. This film was in conflict with the fashionable and recycled idea of its time period, and that is what makes this film a classic. In addition to the storyline flaws, there were also some, in my opinion, unneeded nudity pieces. We see at least two naked women (prostitutes), and I don't think that they added to the story. As I think about it, I think that I know where the director was going with it. By showing these foul people living in the city that Callahan has sworn to protect, we see one of the major reasons why he does not trust in his own cityWith the combination of the pacing errors and the extraneous nudity, I found this film to be pretty good, yet not as good as I had hoped. I think that this film only did fire five shots and not six; leaving one needed bullet in the chamber. www.sportsandcelluloid.blogspot.com

This film is the absolute matrix for a series of four more films with and by Clint Eastwood as well as a new way to deal with the problem of extreme crime and both the police answer and the political lack of courage in front of this emerging serial killing practice. We are in 1971 before the emergence of profiling that will come from the FBI in Quantico. So both police departments (led by elected sheriffs or marshals) and political personnel, like mayors and district attorneys, do not know what to do with such criminals and they tend to take a conservative stance hiding behind the very famous Miranda (the tree hiding the forest) and treating the crimes separately, hence erasing the serial dimension. Clint Eastwood reacting along the same line as the general public considered that the police had to be a lot more responsive, hence active and even brutal with these criminals, to the point of shooting first without any warning and asking questions afterwards, and only if they did not have any bullets left in their weapons. Some yelled at abuse of power. Others applauded to support the use of force to protect innocent bystanders. We were in the post 1968 period, the post Woodstock period, and the post hippy period. That strong stance on Clint Eastwood's side was the backlash at excessive tolerance and liberalism that was shown for what it had become in films like "Zabriskie Point" or "Fritz the Cat," a direct encouragement to criminal activities.That feeling of fear in the wide public was also racially motivated for some white people because that was the time when the Black Panther Party and the Nation of Islam started using the second amendment to justify their decision to carry weapons in public in full respect of what all whites could do. This feeling was amplified by the persistence of the Vietnam War and the very conservative policy of Richard Nixon. The number of casualties in Vietnam and the cost of the war, not to speak of the cost of the veterans who were lucky enough to come back in one piece though quite often severely impaired, becoming more and more visible and expensive, the people were quite ready to ask for a change in policy, a return of money in larger quantities to security within the country, which meant the end of the war. And yet it was still to go on for four years, increasing all the time the exasperation of the public.This film is still slightly slow but it is stampeding away in 1971. That was an action film and it had to be fast, though it is here more endurance than speed, and yet many of the tricks that were to develop in the next decades were already there: short sequences edited in clean cut ellipses. The camera did not have any time and energy to waste to give small descriptive details but it emphasized the successive moments in the action, even at times in a nearly impossible sequence, like Inspector Harry climbing to the top of the high building from which the serial killer had shot his first victim in less time than it took the coroner's team to wrap up the body of the victim and take it off the crime scene. Here the editing ellipse with Harry at the top point of the building and the body of the victim being removed makes it look extremely fast and meaningful.But this film is the matrix for many films to come that expose the inability of elected personnel, on both the police side and the political side, and even the judicial side, to understand that some urgent revision of police procedures has to be worked out – out of a magician's hat if necessary – that would at the same time respect judicial and legal procedures, empower the police to respond to such criminals at top speed, and protect the public against such criminals who cannot be saved in anyway because they like – sorry some of them do love – killing. From this obvious point to the idea that they have to be killed on the spot while committing a crime there is only one small step that is often climbed or taken in the heat of action. But we can be sure this film was the matrix of what was to become very popular detective – or rather nowadays police – series. Colombo is out and CSI or NCIS are in. And then you can work on details with Dexter or Criminal Minds and Bones. But it is always the same idea: these serial killers have to be neutralized at best – or worst – and eliminated from society at worst – or at best. For Inspector Harry the second option is the only one. Since then a lot of thinking has been done and particularly we have understood that such serial killers may be psychopaths or sociopaths, but they are necessarily super intelligent and they cannot be considered as intellectually underdeveloped, let alone handicapped or differently abled if you prefer.That's probably why Clint Eastwood will come back to that character four more times over the next seventeen years.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU

'Dirty Harry' and 'French Connection'.  Comparing the two is exhausting, but here's the basics.'Harry' is a continuation of the American anti-hero theme, this time as the Western vigilante with a badge.  It is neither slick nor stylish anymore and could be considered Don Siegel's version of "The Jungle" for law enforcement.  It isn't entertainment, but calling it "social satire" is an overstatement.  In the 30+ years since its release, 'Harry' has aged badly. Clint is nothing more than the stereotypical bigoted Southern cop and given the maxim of his Western counterpart, the Man with No Name.  Not even the value of the music has remained.  Music, after all, is what the director uses to get our emotions going because he can't do it with images most of the time.'French' is a pseudo-documentary that tries using an offensive snob for a character.  Like 'Harry', it isn't slick by any modern definition, but that isn't the point.  The three points made by the movies (police brutality, serial killers, and drug trade) are as what must've been revolutionary ideas for their times, but they've dated severely and are too simple by today's standards.  Just look at 'Traffic'.Overall, these two films really aren't necessary anymore, but are useful for historical value to show where we've come from.  For that I feel justified in my equal rating.  If the 70s tried exposing the underbelly in America, 'Harry' and 'Connection' failed in their duties.(50%)

reviews.review_title: Which one was the psycho gunman?
reviews.content: Dirty Harry (1) (1971) -I didn't like Harry's (Clint Eastwood) style of law enforcement at all, but then I've never been one for guns or using them to stop crimes by killing the criminals and sometimes innocents.I also didn't see why people have been so excited about his character, like he was the greatest lawman of our time and I'm baffled as to why Harry appeared in so many sequels. He should have been fired and put on a list of people to watch out for before the film had even started. His hedonistic approach to things would not earn him any points in my police force. Although the whole team were possibly the worst police force I've ever seen on screen and I've seen all 7 'Police Academy' (1984-94) films.The story was a similar concept to 'Die Hard With A Vengeance' (1995) in the way that the killer took him on a wild goose chase, but without the same excitement and as a result, a huge lack of interest on my part, because it just wasn't done skilfully at all.I preferred the British 'Sort Of' equivalent with Michael Caine as Harry Palmer in 'The Ipcress File' (1965) and its sequels, as they came over far more realistically and he wasn't quite so let loose.It was also a very dark film and I don't just mean that it was nasty, but it was almost completely pitch black at times, so it was like - Why Bother if there was nothing to see?And the camera work was very shaky, it didn't add any effect, but made it even more annoying to watch.I was also starting to think that Ron Burgundy* was in charge of the soundtrack with his jazz flute. Because of that I got the impression that they were trying to make it artsy and cool, but it just made it easily dateable in my opinion.I could see why Andrew Robinson was later hired to play Garak in 'Star Trek: Deep Space Nine' (1993-9), he was the same kind of freaky as the Cardassian character and perfect in the role of the Killer, which isn't a spoiler, because that was clear from the get go and he was even listed as "Killer" on IMDB.Both he and Clint were also better at shooting at the beginning of the film, by the time it got to the end, the shots were going everywhere and far too conveniently.I was also annoyed with the District Attorney, who was surely in error for dismissing the case earlier on? They at least had evidence and could prove that the Killer had beaten and attempted to murder two police officers? If they couldn't get him for the other deaths, then they could have got him for that.But there was no way that the bosses would have allowed Harry to continue to work, even after the first cock up.Overall I found it very flawed, not my thing and quite dull. I suppose that I have been spoiled and seen other films done better since, perhaps they were built on the idea of this one, but they definitely outshone it.343.11/1000.*Anchorman: The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004).

reviews.review_title: A film 40 years old but still as fresh and relevant as ever
reviews.content: Really there are few words left to describe Dirty Harry and the massive effect it had on world cinema. On the one hand it virtually invented the maverick cop genre and we have it to thank for the slew of pale imitations which followed (notably the Lethal Weapon series) and parodies (such as the brilliant Slegehammer). Clint Eastwood is iconic and fantastic in the role, really the first cop who breaks the rules and enjoys it, the first movie cop to really carry a distinctive handgun (de riguer nowadays), Harry really is a force a nature, not so much a fascist as some would argue but a man who actually cares so much about society and the people that he's prepared to be ruthless to protect them. People see this as a right-wing film but it's not really, Scorpios victims include an Afro-American child and 2 young women, the police are able to save a flamboyantly gay man and a Catholic priest. It was always regarded as 'every frame votes for Nixon' but given his overwhelming election victory during the period it was certainly catching the mood of the times. When the girl gets kidnapped Harry immediately writes her off whilst the Mayor and the police Captain refuse to do so and want to pay the ransom and you're really not sure who's right or wrong? The DA and judge who let Scorpio go do so reluctantly but convincingly argue that we can't introduce evidence in court obtained by torture. Whilst the script ultimately sides with Harry's viewpoint it's not always so black and white as is often assumed.People argue this is a humourless film but I don't think so, the humour is just extremely dark and cutting. Harry just continually seems to be surrounded by people who just don't get him and his constant frustration is just hilarious and played to great comic effect. You do have to wonder if his nickname Dirty Harry is due purely to his methods? He always seems to be looking through naked girl's windows and following Scorpio into strip clubs?Terrific music although not as good as it will be in the arguably superior sequel Magnum Force. Wonderful performance from Andrew Robinson, the child of the free love 60s gone horribly wrong, so nice that Star Trek;DS9 will later give him a career resurgence. Apart from Harry and Scorpio the 2 characters that really stick in your mind are the superbly telegenic city of San Francisco itself and Harry's beloved 44 Magnum, not the most powerful handgun in the world and won't blow your head clean off (although I'd love to see Mythbusters try that)but still packs a hell of a punch. Michael Mann's Heat aside possibly the greatest cop movie ever.

Here's a solid cop police drama, that spawned a number or entertaining sequels, but also hails a new tough guy. Believe it, you've never met a more hardened cop, than inspector Harry Callahan. God, if every cop was like Harry, the world would be a much better place. This is Eastwood's best role, the role he was born to play. Dirty Harry has some bloody terrifying moments made that way by the killer nicknamed Scorpio, a brilliant if work of art performance by Andrew Robinson. Saddled with a new out of his depth sick partner Reni Santori, (Pepe in Seinfeld) we see all Harry's pet hates. He's a cop that works alone, and that's just how we like him. This Scorpio killer, a psychopathic sniper, has been making quite a nuisance of himself, and has put the city of SF under siege, threatening to kill someone else, if this ransom is not paid. And you can guess Harry's reaction. And it's up to Harry, to take out this madman permanently. And talk about kicking a killer when he's down in one scene. Another scene has the killer paying someone to have him worked over and transfer the blame on Callahan, who when viewing some photos of the battered maniac, harry defends himself, by saying "The killer looks too damned good". The bus scene with Andrew Robinson, really shows his sick, evil, pathetic self come to life. Although this isn't my favourite dirty Harry Movie, with the legendary line, nonetheless, is a solid action thriller, where at the time, would of upset some public, as to the rights of killers, where Death Wish followed two years later. But when it come to ridding scum, and delivering justice, Hey, I'm on Harry's side.

reviews.review_title: How to make an iconic character that everyone wants to be
reviews.content: There are a lot of iconic film characters who have single handedly launched franchises: James Bond, Rocky, Indiana Jones, etc. but none are as gracefully done as Inspector Harry Callahan. Other than his .45 Magnum and a little spiel for the criminals that get in his way, there aren't any other gimmicks. Who you see is who you get -- a cop with a moral compass that doesn't let the law set its bearing. He's fast-talking, hard-nosed and merciless -- the cop that everyone wishes they could be but few have the balls to be. He's the model for how a singular character can drive a film.The first step is Clint Eastwood. Known mostly at the time for his Sergio Leone spaghetti westerns, Eastwood is a proved one-liner machine gun. He's the got the looks, the poise and the verbal delivery of a certified rebel, a man capable of anything. He makes "Dirty Harry" tick. All icons are made by their actors and Eastwood was born to do iconic.Part of what makes "Dirty Harry" a classic is that it's a vicarious movie-going experience. Everyone wishes they could just take justice into their own hands just like Callahan. The plot provides that same experience. Harry is a San Francisco detective on the trail of the "Scorpio Killer," a concept ripped straight from the San Francisco Chronicle headlines in the late '60s revolving around the mysterious Zodiac Killer who was on the loose. In a sense, Harry was born out of the country's frustration with the ineptitude of law enforcement in bringing that killer to justice. Harry does to the Scorpio Killer what we all wish we could've done to the Zodiac -- let him have it.An iconic character is also nothing without his lines and a clearly defined set of convictions as indicated in the script. Maybe one of his best lines (of many) is when he describes to some other police how he knew that a man chasing a woman in the street was intent to rape. It perfectly sums up that Harry is a man who doesn't wait to let the law define what's right and wrong. This vision for Harry is guided with strength by Don Siegel. Siegel carefully plans out his critical shots: a long distance zoom-out from the football field as Harry executes his version of justice and a wide shot of Harry above the bridge as he plans to intercept a school bus hijacked by the killer. Siegel creates iconic moments for his truly memorable character and it makes "Dirty Harry" a more unforgettable film.

The title character of "Dirty Harry," Inspector Harry Callahan, is a well-known cliché in the movies: a police detective who chafes under all the rules and regulations that get in the way of his catching criminals. In the movie "Dragnet" (1954), Officer Frank Smith asks his partner Sergeant Joe Friday why the laws always protect the criminals, to which Friday responds, "Because the innocent don't need them." This attitude is rather widespread, unfortunately. An innocent man, the thinking goes, would never insist on having an attorney present while being interrogated by the police, would never demand to see a warrant before letting the police into his house, and would never plead the Fifth Amendment and refuse to testify at his own trial. Only criminals do that sort of thing.For people who think that way, Harry Callahan is their kind of cop, because he never lets something as fussy as a bunch of rights get in the way of catching the bad guys. In one scene in the movie, the district attorney tells Harry he violated several of the suspect's rights, namely the ones embodied in the Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution. Harry says, "I'm all broken up about that man's rights." The district attorney responds that he should be, because the man will have to be released as a result, none of the evidence collected without a warrant being admissible, because that is the law. Harry says, "Then the law is crazy!" Harry then asks of the deceased victim, "And Ann Mary Deacon, what about her rights?" Thus does Harry give voice to much of the frustration felt by the audience that criminals have rights at the expense of the rights of their innocent victims.The district attorney in that scene refers to the Miranda ruling, which requires that a suspect be informed of his rights to an attorney and the right to remain silent. Before the Miranda ruling it used to be habeas corpus that conservatives hated. In the movie "Scarface" (1932), for example, Tony Camonte (Paul Muni) is arrested and then released on what Tony jokingly refers to as a writ of hocus pocus.The circumstance in which Harry violated all that suspect's rights involved torture, and this movie brings out all the necessary conditions for torture to be justified in a movie. When depicted in film, torture is usually portrayed as something evil, something done by Nazis, for instance. But "Dirty Harry" is one of the first movies to present torture as being good. Early in the movie, the "Scorpio Killer" has buried a little girl alive with only enough oxygen to last her a few hours, and then demands ransom for her release. Harry agrees to deliver the money. When he does, the serial killer announces that he intends to let the little girl die. When Harry catches up with him, he tortures the killer until he tells him where the girl has been buried.Even if we disapprove of torture in real life, we cannot help but approve of Dirty Harry's actions while watching the movie. And this is for five reasons: (1) We are certain the man is guilty. Dirty Harry knows, as do we, that the man he is torturing is the Scorpio Killer. (2) The punishment fits the crime. The Scorpio Killer is evil, and clearly deserves the pain Harry inflicts on him. (3) There is a time element. In just a few hours, the girl will die, so the information must be extracted from him immediately. (4) The situation is ad hoc. Although early in the movie a doctor jokes about Harry beating a confession out of a suspect, it is our sense that he does not routinely torture criminals. (5) The torture is effective. We find out later that the girl was already dead, but Harry does get the information concerning where she is buried.The one condition that no longer seems to be necessary to justify torture in the movies is the fourth one, the requirement that the situation be ad hoc. In the show "24," torture almost seems to be part of Jack Bauer's job description. But the other four conditions obtain. These ideal conditions by which torture is justified are seldom realized in real life. There is typically no time element, sometimes referred to as the "ticking time bomb." Sometimes innocent people are tortured. And the effectiveness of torture is hotly debated. Nevertheless, those who favor torture will often try to justify its use by appealing to movies like "Dirty Harry" or shows like "24," as if the ideal circumstances in those dramas were just like those found in real life.A few years before "Dirty Harry" was produced, another movie employing a similar type of police detective was "Madigan" (1968). Early in the movie, another detective says of the title character (played by Richard Widmark), "Madigan doesn't always go by the book, but he's a good cop," thereby spelling out the cliché referred to in the opening paragraph, which is inept, dramatically speaking. Fortunately, "Dirty Harry" does not tell us Harry is that kind of cop. It shows us through his words and actions. That is just one of the reasons why "Dirty Harry" is a great movie, while "Madigan" is just second rate.But it does raise the question, will we ever see a movie about a police detective who never violates a suspect's rights, who never uses undue force, who never enters a suspect's house without a warrant, and who believes that it is more important to obey the law than catch the bad guys, and as a result, the criminals often escape justice? In other words, will we ever see a movie in which someone says, "Detective Fussbottom is a bad cop, but at least he always goes by the book"? Probably not, but if we ever do see such a movie, it will have to be a comedy.
