reviews.review_title: Clint Eastwood before he looked like Clint Eastwood
reviews.content: This is the first of what was to go on to become five Dirty Harry films. They have now come out in a DVD box set, digitally remastered, so I thought it time to have a rummage through them again. I can hardly believe it was more than forty years ago that Clint Eastwood made DIRTY HARRY. He did not at all look like himself then, in fact he was surprisingly bland and uninteresting at that age. What makes him interesting now is all the character in his face, of which he had little trace back then. Although I bear him a deep grudge because of the way he treated Sondra Locke, I have to admit he is amazingly talented, as witness his directorial work especially (see my reviews). It is interesting in retrospect to consider why this film and its sequels became such a huge hit. The film in itself is very good but nothing to jump up and down with excitement about. Director Don Siegel did an excellent job of trying to make it look as good as he could, and San Francisco is always a plus as a location, as we know, especially when you have got Bruce Surtees as the cinematographer. But the reason why this film 'clicked' is because Eastwood's character Police Inspector Harry Callaghan challenges all the idiotic liberal safeguards for the excessive rights of criminals which ignore the rights of victims. This is one of the most serious dilemmas of our times, more important now than it was in 1971, for this crazy imbalance of 'rights' which is continually perpetuated by all the functionaries who are intent on self-destructing our societies from within hold every criminal precious and dear to their hearts, whereas victims can just get stuffed. Dirty Harry shows his disgust clearly, a disgust already in 1971 held deeply by probably a majority of the American population, and certainly a majority outside the urban conglomerations of the trendy Coasts. (And where in the USA is trendier or more wildly liberal than San Francisco, the setting of this film?) The story plays to this angle by showing a raving psychopathic murderer who is going around shooting people from rooftops, and the San Francisco District Attorney lets him go, after Dirty Harry has caught him and put him in jail, because his 'rights' have been infringed and the rifle he was using to assassinate people in the streets was seized without a warrant. When Eastwood asks what about the rights of the victims not to get killed he is told 'it is the law'. Naturally we all internally cheer when Eastwood resumes his pursuit of the madman in his private time and defies 'orders from the fifth floor'. By the way, in one shot Eastwood is entering a café and we can see a cinema nearby, which is advertising his own film PLAY MISTY FOR ME. An early example of product placement! It is a good joke, but can only be glimpsed for a moment. Don't production teams like to amuse themselves! This film was the first cinema appearance of Andrew Robinson, who plays the psychopath brilliantly, and who then went on to appear in 103 titles, and there is no record I know of his having murdered anyone since 1971, so, well done Andrew, you have restrained your murderous impulses for four decades! That's true professionalism! This film is entertaining if you don't mind a certain amount of violence. John Vernon is good, as usual, as the Mayor of San Francisco, but then he wants to let the bad guys out of jail too. I thought Ruth Kobart was very good as a terrified elderly driver of a hijacked school bus with the amusing name of Priscilla Platt. It takes a lot of talent to look that terrified when you are just sitting at a steering wheel and when your character is called Priscilla Platt. Some of the school children get slapped around pretty badly by the psychopath, so sensitive people will not find this film easy watching in places. The clever ruse the psychopath uses to try to discredit Eastwood by pretending Eastwood beat him to a pulp, namely by paying someone else $200 to beat him to a pulp so that he can pretend it was done by Eastwood, is one of the most shocking aspects of the film. Never trust a psychopath, that's my motto, which is why it is so difficult to cast a vote sometimes.

1970s was a great era for film. This gritty hard hitting action flick is embellished with dry sardonic wit keeping the entertainment and tension high.
In the year 1971, ignoring the orders of his superiors, maverick police detective Inspector Dirty Harry Callahan , gambles with innocent lives to capture a psychopathic killer blackmailing San Francisco.
This film is full of classic one liners, action and attitude which simply does not date.

"Dirty Harry" was the film that boosted star Clint Eastwood to super star status. Climbing down from the saddle, Clint found the ideal character...the urban gunfighterIn San Francisco, a serial killer known only as the Scorpian has begun killing innocent citizens at random. A young girl is shot while swimming in the latest killing. Inspector Harry Callahan (Eastwood) has been assigned the case. The Scorpian has left a note demanding $100,000 or he will kill a priest. The Mayor (John Vernon) has to find the money while Chief of Police (John Larch) and Harry's boss Lt. Bressler (Harry Guardino) are concerned. The three have questioned Harry's methods in the past but are willing to give him another chance.Harry is assigned a new partner, Chico (Rene Santini). Harry's partners in the past have not fared too well so Harry is not happy over having to break in a new man. Harry goes to lunch and while eating a hot dog foils a bank robbery. It is here that we are introduced to Harry's .44 magnum...the most powerful hand gun in the world. It is here that Harry utters the immortal words to one of the robbers..."Do ya feel lucky punk?". Harry tells Chico that he is called "Dirty Harry" because he seems to wind up with all of the dirty jobs.One of these jobs is the rescue of a potential suicide from the top of a building. Harry and Chico set up a stake out to lure the killer into a trap. The killer takes the bait but escapes after an exchange of gunfire. The killer, upset over being caught in the act, raises his demands to $200,000, Harry offers to bring the money to the killer but has Chico follow out of sight.Harry is surprised by the killer and is beaten. Chico is wounded in an exchange of gunfire. Harry manages to stab the killer in the leg which disables him and he loses the money in the confusion. Chico becomes disenchanted and decides to leave the force to become a teacher. The killer meanwhile, has kidnapped a young 14 year old girl and holds her for the $200,000 ransom.Harry and Inspector De Georgio (John Mitchum) track the killer to a football stadium where Harry captures him. The killer fails to disclose the location of the young girl. Through legal technicalities, the killer is released. He has a tough beat him up and has the blame placed upon Harry.
Harry begins to follow the killer on his own time. The young girl is found dead as Harry continues his pursuit.The killer takes over a school bus with several children aboard and.................................Eastwood is essentially playing Harry as "the man with no name" in a suit. He brings out that big gun at every opportunity but does so in the interest of law and order. There's no love interest here but there are some nude scenes in a strip bar to satisfy the men in the audience. Andrew Robinson, in his first film, makes a great baby faced villain and no he is not related to Edward G. Robinson as has been reported in some circles. John Mitchum, the brother of Robert was a poet of some renown and would appear in two future films in the series.Followed by four sequels.

reviews.review_title: The action film that set the standard
reviews.content: I am a big Clint Eastwood fan,and this by far is my favorite Eastwood film.Every action film made since this time is no doubt measured by it.Clint is great as the teeth gritting,die hard,not always by the book Harry Callahan,and almost stealing the show from him is Andrew Robinson as Scorpio,giving one of the best villain performances ever. I have always had a passion for seeing the bad people of this world get what they deserve,and Dirty Harry,fantasy though it may be,delivers the best example of good triumphing over evil.Go get'em Harry.

Very few stars from the golden age of television and film survived into the Reagan era the way that Clint Eastwood did. If you're looking for reasons, the answer is in "Dirty Harry" and its reactionary message of hatred for the counter-culture. Unlike the fine docudrama, "Helter Skelter," "Dirty Harry" doesn't go into character in any depth, preferring to create hateful paper thin stereotypes for the bigots in the audience, regardless of whether they hate left wingers, liberals or cops.Ironically, this exploitation film must have appealed very much to the unofficial censors in Washington, D.C. who later gave birth to the influential media lobbying groups which turned Hollywood into a propaganda organ of the political right wing with such movies as "Missing in Action" and "Rambo II." The miraculous success of Eastwood's career since this mediocre movie was made shows how adopting a right wing approach confers a competitive advantage in politically reactionary times. By the late 80's his movies were showing all the time on broadcast TV, but hardly anyone else who got started in the golden age received any air time at all. Because there were so many stars more talented than Eastwood who got started in the golden age around the same time -- Clint Walker, Tony Franciosa and Nick Adams, just to name a very few -- it's reasonable to wonder if there wasn't an anti-left wing black list in Hollywood and Washington beginning in the early 70's, which favored reactionaries like Eastwood over the more talented competition. Nonetheless, I'm sort of a reluctant fan. It's too late now, but instead of "Dirty Harry" I wish that Eastwood had appeared in a movie version of "A Cool Million," from the novel by Nathanael West -- a satire on the subject of homegrown American style right wing totalitarianism. The part of Lemuel Pitkin, the boneheaded leader of the buckskin shirted fascists, would have been perfect for him and a real challenge to his acting ability!

reviews.review_title: With 'Dirty Harry' Callahan Eastwood provided us with one of cinema's most iconic characters
reviews.content: Inspector 'Dirty Harry' Callahan (Clint Eastwood) is assigned to one of his toughest cases when he finds himself having to track down a notorious serial killer simply known as Scorpio. Scorpio leaves a letter at the scene of his first crime threatening to kill again unless he receives $100,000. What follows is a cat and mouse game between Scorpio and Harry but in this game Harry is determined to win and will do whatever it takes to bring Scorpio to justice.Between 1971 and 2016 there have been many cop type films and over the years we have seen many similar 'Harry Callahan' type police officers being portrayed on film. However, Dirty Harry was a very early example of a bad-ass cop who's prepared to bend or break the rules in order to get his man but, to my knowledge, no film has ever given us a cop who's quite so iconic and cool as Dirty Harry Callahan. Part of the reason this film succeeds lies with Eastwood himself and what he brought to the role; there's nobody else quite like him when it comes to tough-talking through gritted teeth and he's also capable of giving icy stares that at times can be quite unnerving. I think the important distinction to make with Harry is that he's a 'bad-ass' cop rather than a 'bad' cop; he isn't afraid to break the rules in order to do what he feels is right, but he also knows when to hold back and never allows his judgement to be clouded even in the most extreme of circumstances. For these reasons it's easy to have a vested interest in Callahan's dogged pursuit of Scorpio as more often than not we find a police officer doing a lot of things wrong but for all the right reasons. Of course every 'bad-ass' cop needs a bad-ass villain to contend with and this is where Andrew Robinson comes into play; Robinson was not a big actor (and sadly never seemed to become one either) and therefore going up against Eastwood (who was quite well-established at this point in his career) must have been quite a daunting task, but Robinson acquits himself to the role very well and manages to be chilling, menacing and ever so slightly sociopathic. According to the trivia section Robinson received death threats after his performance in Dirty Harry which just goes to show that a lot of people were so convinced by his performance that they must have forgot that he was acting!!!Director Don Siegel gives the film plenty of energy and keeps the film moving at a fair old lick; the screenplay also includes some humorous moments (I loved the unorthodox approach that Harry used to try to prevent someone from jumping off a high-rise building). Harry's general contempt for authority made many of his scenes with The Mayor and The Chief very enjoyable. To top it all off Dirty Harry also has a very exciting finale with one of the best closing lines to a film that I've ever seen.Anyone who is a fan of Eastwood really should watch this as not only is this one of his best films but he's also playing one of the best characters to grace the cinema screen (I genuinely can't think of a cooler character than Harry Callahan). Many cop films with similar bad-ass cops have followed, but few (if any) have been as good as Dirty Harry.

reviews.review_title: One of the coolest cop movies you'll ever see
reviews.content: It spawned four sequels and countless imitators, redefined a genre, brought in millions at the box office, and was both hailed as one of the best action movies in years and derided as fascist propaganda. It provided a major boost to the already red-hot career of its star Clint Eastwood. It introduced one of Hollywood's most iconic heroes and baddest bad guys. Forty years later people still quote lines from this movie- including some that weren't in it. There is no doubt that Dirty Harry is one of the most influential movies of the seventies, and one of the all time great cop movies.Eastwood stars as Inspector Harry Callahan, the original cop who doesn't play by the rules. He has no time to worry about proper procedure, isn't particularly careful about following orders, and makes no effort to be likable. He pulls no punches, doesn't care who he offends, and he keeps his job because there isn't a man on the force with sharper aim, better instincts, or harder stones than him. He may not make many friends, but he gets the job done. But he faces the toughest job of his career, taking down the mysterious sniper known as Scorpio. Scorpio is every cop's nightmare. He's driven, intelligent, and completely insane, with a sadistic streak a mile wide. He delights in causing pain, kills for the sheer fun of it, and is always one step ahead of the police. He's not picky about who he kills, but can meticulously his crimes days in advance. And he loves to make the city of San Francisco play his games. He reminds me more than a bit of Heath Ledger's Joker, who he may have been an influence on, and there are some chilling parallels to the DC snipers.Admittedly, many parts of the film seem clichéd by today's standards, from the rookie partner to the superiors who constantly make the wrong decision and call the hero out on the carpet. But this movie is the reason they became clichés. And there are parts that are brilliantly original, like the telephone chase in the middle. You'll know what I'm talking about when you see it. The pacing is excellent as well, with long periods of tension leading to explosive action scenes, with the best being saved for last.I give the director and cinematographer high marks for the camera work, including sudden close-ups, long panning shots, and extensive use of first person view. They've also made very good use of their locations, and really captured San Francisco, both the glamorous (downtown, the Golden Gate), and the seedy (liquor stores, topless bars, gay druggies in the park).Now Harry Callahan was and is a controversial figure, both within the film, and among social commentators, though not as much so as back in the seventies. He's a constant headache for the DA and public affairs, and in real life he'd probably spend half his time on suspension. I admit his knowledge of, and regard for, the rules of evidence and the rights of the accused are pretty low, even for a movie cop. I can't help but sympathize with him though. If I saw a naked, knife-wielding man chasing a woman down an alley, I'd shoot to kill. I'd also look for ways getting around the search warrant requirement if I knew that a fourteen year old girl's life depended on finding the perp. But it's also clear that he did go too far in apprehending Scorpio at the football stadium. Busting into the grounds keeper's hut without a warrant is excusable, same for skipping the Miranda rights. But there was no excuse for a police officer beating a wounded suspect, especially on the area of the wound. If this were a war movie or a private eye film he could get away with it, but for a cop it's just too far. This also leads to the one point where suspension of disbelief becomes impossible. I cannot believe that a police department, even in San Francisco, would just let the suspect walk. No matter how badly his rights had been violated, they would still find some technicality to hold him on. And they would certainly keep him under constant surveillance if he were released.These issues aside, Dirty Harry is still a solid thriller, and excellent 'guy' movie, and one of the best cop dramas ever made. Don't let the kiddies see it, but if you're high school age or older it's definitely worth checking out.

reviews.review_title: The Gritty, Tough Detective Who Wears an Agenda on His Sleeve
reviews.content: When a deranged sniper picks victims at random and personally taunts the San Francisco police department, he draws the ire of the grumpiest cop on the force. Harry Callahan, played with typical take-no-prisoners panache by Clint Eastwood, isn't here to make friends or to feel good about himself. He exists solely to conduct court on the streets, rulebook be damned; to shoot first and ask questions later. Presumably because the weapon he carries, an iconic, big-barreled Smith & Wesson, doesn't leave enough of its target to raise any objections.Although everyone clearly despises him on a personal level, it's hard to see Harry positioned as anything but the banner-waving antihero: he gets to spout the sweet quotes, wear the cool sunglasses and strike a bunch of badass poses, so his opinions become the film's opinions. That's a problem when the themes grow more ambitious, addressing the shaky ground between what's legal and what's arbitrarily "right." Harry sees everything in stark black-and-white, flying into a seething rage when a high-profile collar walks free due to his own brutish interrogation tactics, and we're meant to cheer when he stalks and eventually forces a second confrontation with the freed criminal. The pursuit itself makes for gripping entertainment - messy, gritty and intense - but the overt political messaging makes it more complicated than a simple yay-rah get-the-bad-guy.The film uses its antagonist, the aforementioned sniper, as incendiary proof of the holes in the justice system. If more situations were handled outside the courtroom, I guess, we'd see far fewer hijacked school buses or tortured kids. Odd that the fallacy of this argument is lost on Harry, who's earlier beaten to a bloody pulp by three yokels. Believing what they see, and refusing to wait for the whole story, they jump to conclusions and take him for a peeping Tom. Harry licks his wounds and carries on, blissfully unaware of the poetic irony.This isn't just your basic gunsmoke action movie. I might not agree with its conclusions, but I appreciate the debate it inspired within me. It's always good to test one's own beliefs. Also good to soak up a healthy dose of raw '70s atmosphere from time to time, which is something Dirty Harry has in spades.

Feel sorry for Inspector Harry Callahan. Not only does he have to abide by pesky laws and procedures, and not only is the Mayor a damned coward, but his new partner studied sociology. In other words, he's the sort of man who actually tries to understand criminal behaviour and fix society's problems with rational thought and all that jazz. But for Harry, what's there to understand? Criminals are damned punks. A bullet in the head is true justice.And there are so many criminals about. Just take the list of dead police officers that opens the film. All of them were killed by damned punks, and those damned pussies at city hall seem to be encouraging them. No wonder a guy like Harry is disillusioned.Of course, in the real world, a guy like Harry Callahan would be a liability. I mean, no one is right all the time, and when Harry thinks he's right, he has no qualms about shooting suspects and torturing them. But hey, this is a movie, and therefore Harry is always right. Consequently his fascism is just a committed cop doing what it takes to get results. We love every moment of it.I guess it helps that his adversary is off his nut. Really, is there anyone quite so mental as Scorpio? I don't think there is. He makes Tom Cruise look like he has all his faculties.My favourite Scorpio bit is the Scorpio scream when Harry stabs him in the leg. Words fail to describe the hilarity and the insane beauty of the sound, but if I were to try, I'd say it sounded like the sound a man would make if he were mounted by an overly friendly horse. But in the same scene there's the brilliant moment when Scorpio beats Harry up. Wearing a lurid orange ski mask, and staring at him with deranged eyes, he shouts, "Do we understand each other?" It's so crazy it's almost beautiful.Also rather beautiful is the way Harry captures Scorpio. He chases him through a football stadium and on the pitch he orders Scorpio to stop, which he does. Then he shoots him in the leg, which leads to more Scorpio screaming. At this point it seems like the scene can't get any better, but then Scorpio starts pleading like a little girl. "You tried to kill meI want a lawyerI have the right to a lawyer." And then Harry treads on Scorpio's wound and you have a fantastic helicopter shot from Harry and Scorpio on the football pitch to a view high above, almost a god's eye view. And if god did exist, I'm sure he'd approve. I know I do. Well, only because I know with 100% certainty that Harry is right.But those damned liberals at city hall don't approve of Harry's methods, so Scorpio gets released. I mean, Harry only performed an illegal search and violated a man's rights. What's the problem? But insanely dedicated cop that he is (in other words, he doesn't have a life of his own), Harry follows Scorpio around during his spare time. And classy fellow that he is, Scorpio spends plenty of time in titty bars. But Scorpio soon tires of being trailed, and in a magnificent scene, pays a large black man to beat him up, framing it on Harry (I love how mangled Scorpio's face is when he insults the large man that is beating him up; and I love how severe the beating is). But do you see what happens when you give people rights? They use their devious minds to turn everything around. Wouldn't the word be a much better place if cops were at liberty to blow heads clean off? Mayors and stupid chiefs, and laws and regulations only hinder good ole cops like Harry.And just look at what happens when someone like Scorpio is left on the street. He shoots people with his snipers rifle and he robs shopkeepers. And the shop scene may well be my favourite in the film  although it would compete with the scene where Harry deals with the jumper (he insults him, makes him mad and then punches him out; now that's policing!) But in the shop scene, Scorpio chats to the owner about how many times he's been robbed. The owner blathers for a bit and shows him his gun. To which Scorpio meekly says, "Please, I scare easy." But then as the man is putting his gun away, Scorpio smashes a bottle over his head (while still in its paper bag) and robs the bloke. How can you hate a man that's so ingenious? And how can you hate a man who pleads like a dog, screams like a girl and wants to kill Catholic priests? See, he's not all bad.Plus he's great with children. There he is singing with them and having a good old time. Sure he slaps them about a bit and tells them that he's going to kill their mothers, but children need a bit of discipline, don't they? But Harry soon puts a stop to this. Like The Terminator he jumps off a bridge, lands on top of the bus and after a bit of a shoot-out, kills Scorpio. Then he throws his badge away. It would be an ending with some symbolic meaning if Callahan hadn't returned for so many sequels. But as it is, Dirty Harry is a shallow, wafer-thin detective film that's a hell of a lot of fun. I mean, there's almost zero character development (Harry's wife is dead and that's that; and Scorpio is just loco), but that doesn't stop it from being an enjoyable ride. Just the Scorpio scream on its own would make it worthwhile, but on top of that you have a fascist cop blowing people away with his large gun. And surely that's enough for anyone.

reviews.review_title: A great action movie about an important political problem
reviews.content: After 35 years I find it amazing, how misunderstood "Dirty Harry" is (the movie, not the character). I am left-wing, in my opinion the Clintons and Al Gore belong to moderate right. And I don't see any "fascism" in "Dirty Harry". I only see an important political problem, important 35 years ago and as important in our days - think of the Twin Towers assault.The idea of maximal freedom for the individual is very attractive. The snag is of course, that there are some evil human creatures around abusing this freedom. It is possible to close your eyes and not think about it of course. But if you are honest, you have to. The first thing "Dirty Harry" makes clear, is that liberals and socialists have to pay a price. I think civil rights are absolute, the idea to restrict them in favour of safety/security is wrong. In The Netherlands Pim Fortuyn and Theo van Gogh have paid with their lives, like the two girls killed by Scorpio.So is Harry Callahan right? Of course not. Don Siegel and Clint Eastwood portray him on purpose as a racist and a loose canon. Just ask a random police officer, if he wants to work with a guy like Callahan. The final scene is symbolic: Callahan does not belong in the police corps and he knows it. If you are right wing, ask yourself some questions. With your son or daughter in the bus - or even better: if that fishing kid were your son - would you want Callahan taking those risks? Here we see the only, but a big fault of the movie: when Callahan shoots Scorpio in the shoulder, the kid should have been killed. But I suppose, that would be too shocking. It would have been reality though.Harry Callahan himself also pays a high price. He has does not have a family life. Ask some policemen; the doubts of Gonzales' wife are very real. Callahan does not have friends. Also notice, that Callahan's sex life consists of peeping. One of his partners has been killed; the other is in hospital, where Gonzales ends as well.All you right wing people, can you honestly say, that it is worth taking these risks? Especially, when your family, friends and relatives are involved? Dirty Harry Callahan has a strong right wing political view. The movie has not. Essential is the scene, when Gonzales asks his superior, if it is right not to give Callahan a cover up. Lieutenant Bessler's answer is honest: he does not know. No matter your political views, you need blinkers to answer Gonzales' question.This is exactly, why "Dirty Harry" is superior to all the other tough cops movies, with types like Bronson, Gibson, Willis and Segal. "Dirty Harry" is unsettling, because it leaves the spectator without answers. This is underlined by the fact, that regular police surveillance in the movie saves two lives ...Two final remarks. Nobody has noticed the similarities between Scorpio and El Indio. I only mention them, as they are obvious. Andy Robinson is great, but I think Gian Maria Volonte even more frightening. I also find it amazing, that so many people think "Dirty Harry" violent. Please, do a body count and compare with hard boiled movies since 1980 until today. The fact is of course, that there are not that many victims. The good guys get hurt as well. Neither is there any beauty in the violent scenes. Violence is portrayed like it is in reality: nasty, dirty, painful. It is present, today even more than in 1971, and there is no good way to deal with it.

reviews.review_title: "I know what you're thinking. 'Did he make six Dirty Harry movies...
reviews.content: ...or only five.' Because in all this excitement, I'm not sure if I should count 'Grand Torino' as a Dirty Harry movie. But seeing as this was the film that started the whole Gritty Cop Procedural, and had dozens of imitations, some of which I was in like 'Tightrope', you have to ask yourself one question. 'Do I feel plucky!' Well, do ya, Punk?"This was the film that started it all, and the other four just repeated the elements, not any of them as well. it was very much a product of its time. The Killer Scorpio was a analogy of the Zodiac Killer who had terrorized San Francisco in the late sixties. Cop who doesn't play by the rules trying to stop a psycho killer and dealing with bureaucrats and politicians who are more concerned about laws than justice.John Vernon is nice in a role as the mayor and Andrew J. Robinson (then going by "Andy Robinson") is effective as the killer. Albert Popwell makes his first appearance as a racist stereotype. There are some good action scenes and in the theatrical release, you see things you'd never see today, but it was a different time.So, yeah, still a classic.

This film is a true masterpiece, an original and well done very interesting story that keeps you hooked, about a serial killer (loosely based on the zodiac killer). This movie has an amazing casting and acting from Clint Eastwood and his character is so perfect. There is tons of action and iconic scenes, great effects, lots of suspense and very tense moments. Lots of iconic and memorable moments, just an amazing and very good movie. Masterpiece 10/10.

reviews.review_title: no wonder they call him 'Dirty' Harry
reviews.content: There are certain movies that just wouldn't work if Clint Eastwood wasn't in them. Namely, most Clint Eastwood movies. Take 'Dirty Harry.' Remove Eastwood, have someone else play the title character, and you've got just another early 70's cop thriller. I watched it the other day for, I think, the first time since it came out. It was quite a shock, seeing Clint with enough hair for three people. I was also surprised at how graphic the violence and nudity was for a 'mainstream' film from 1971; it must have been just this side of an 'X' rating at the time. But aside from that, it was the same Clint Eastwood we've been watching for fifty years. Nobody else plays the super-cool cop/gunslinger/secret service agent/whatever in quite the same way. Nobody else would make it seem so believable. Part of it has to with the character's basic contrariness, part of it's being the 'strong, silent type' because the character is always a man of few words. But he's not infallible, like some heroes. The trick that Eastwood pulls off that almost no one else can is that he's badass cool even when he's screwing up or getting the hell beat out of him. He's not afraid to play the fool and make mistakes. There's something about the persona he projects that keeps us from thinking he's a dumbass. It's not just an 'I don't give a damn' attitude on his part, it's that combined with an underlying self-respect and code of honor. It's more of a 'I don't give a damn what other people think because I know what's right' attitude, and it always shows through. Eastwood had already established the basic character in the 'spaghetti westerns' of the sixties. But in 1971 under the auspices of his own newly-formed Malpaso Productions, he brought a somewhat more talkative variation to the screen as Harry Callahan of the San Francisco police. (Hey, Los Angeles has Joe Friday and San Fran has Dirty Harry.) The thriller about a go-his-own-way cop was a huge hit and trendsetter; imitations have come out on a yearly basis ever since, not to mention four Dirty Harry sequels. The original focuses on the Scorpio killer and it set the tone for the others; there were, if not exactly running gags, recurring situations, such as Harry constantly being questioned by his superiors and others about his violent tendencies and Harry essentially telling them to shove it. For example, the first film contains the quintessential Dirty Harry line of dialogue (parodied in 'Police Squad!' by Leslie Nielsen and elsewhere). When told what the police department's policy regarding use of force is, Harry responds, "When an adult male is chasing a female with intent to commit rape, I shoot the bastard. That's my policy." The mayor is forced to concede, "I think he's got a point."

reviews.review_title: Is Harry too dirty to be a cop?
reviews.content: "Dirty Harry" is a hard boiled detective with a lot of violence, noy unlike "The French connection" (1971, William Friedkin) from the same year."Dirty Harry" was the film that turned Clint Eastwood from a Western star into an allround tough guy.The film has some similarities with "Zodiac" (2007, David Fincher) regarding the role of a serial killer (although in "Zodiac" this killer remains invisible) and with "Rear window" (1954, Alfred Hitchcock) regarding voyeurism. This voyeurism is especially evident in the opening scene with respect to the serial killer. Later in the movie we discover also touches of voyeurism in main character Harry Callahan (Clint Eastwood).There are two things that striked me in "Dirty Harry".In the first place in "Dirty Harry" Harry has to collaborate with his younger, less experienced but higher educated colleague Chico Gonzales (Reni Santoni). There are more films with such duo's, for example "Mississippi burning" (1988, Alan Parker) and "Seven" (1995, David Fincher). Most of the time they grow towards each other in the course of the film. Not in "Dirty Harry".In the second place Harry, as a streetwise cop, has frequent conflicts with his bosses. The cops priority is catching crimonals in every possible way, the priority of the bosses also extends to the bureaucracy of the organisation. Normally the sympathy lies with the cop, but in "Dirty Harry" there grows some doubt during the film. You don't want too many cops like Harry walking down the streets. His goals may be different from that of the serial killer, emotionally there are some similarities. Think of the remark about voyeurism I made earlier in this review.At the end of the film Harry kills the serial killer but also throws his police badge away. Maybe he came to his own conclusion about his fitness for the job. By the way, throwing his badge away did not preclude many sequels to come.

reviews.review_title: Clint at his most iconic in a still gripping cop thriller
reviews.content: It's hard to really gauge the impact of Dirty Harry today. Clint Eastwood took his iconic Man With No Name character from the three spaghetti westerns of the 60s,gave him a few tweaks and then placed him in modern day San Francisco,in the process creating another iconic character for audiences to cheer and critics to get steamed up about. Here was a cop who sometimes seemed as brutal as the villains he battled,yet who still lived by his own very moral code. Since this film's release,and especially during the 1980s,the cinema has been filled with tough cop heroes who get the job done by whatever means necessary and are always being told off by exasperated bosses. However,Harry came first.As a film Dirty Harry has possibly lost a little of it's edge now because many subsequent similar films have been much more action packed and violent,the action scenes in this film are fairly quick and to the point-no extended shoot outs here. However,it still has incredible tension. The plot is extremely simple-Harry versus a nasty sniper called Scorpio,that's it-and all the better for it. Director Don Siegel,aided by Lalo Schifrin's funky and sometimes chilling score {the music as Scorpio prepares to shoot people is particularly menacing} piles on the suspense with the skill of a master {possibly the only film he made which bettered this one was the original Invasion Of Th Body Snatchers}.Siegel is especially good with the scenes of violence. In one scene,Harry basically tortures Scorpio for the whereabouts of a girl he is kidnapped. As Harry places his foot on Scorpio's wound and the music goes all wild and dissonant,the camera pans up from the action very quickly until Harry and Scorpio are specks. No real gloating on the brutality,but maximum impact.Harry Robinson's Scorpio is one of the most terrifying villains ever,especially when he manically laughs as he beats up Harry and says about his prisoner "you know what,I'm going to let her die. I just wanted you to know that". Clint has rarely been more effective,subsequent films would develop Harry's character a bit,but he never had the edge and sheer cool as he had here,check out his opening entrance as he checks out a crime scene whilst chewing gum. The writers and Eastwood realise a certain amount of humour about the character without losing his credibility {listen out for the "adult male with a butcher knife" line}.This has been called a fascist movie,but if it is than why did audiences respond so much to the film and the character of Harry? In truth,people related to Harry's anger at a criminal system that sometimes seemed to favour the criminals and there is always a certain pleasure in seeing nasty folk being wiped out. Watch the afore mentioned scene where Harry tortures Scorpio,and see if you're not with Harry a bit and share his concern for the kidnapped girl. Perhaps some of the sequels had more interesting plots and situations and had more action,but Dirty Harry remains a terrific pared-to-the-bone thriller which is still extremely gripping.

The first in the series of 5 Dirty Harry movies, and obviously the best of them all, and here's why, it's the first one,, which 9 times out of 10 the first one is always the best,, it was new for it's time period, can't recall a violent cop film out there at that time.. this one was more urban , and grittier than the others,, that is not a knock on the others mind you,, the other are great in their own right,, but i feel that this one is the best of the bunch,, you got Harry Guardino, Reni Santoni,, Andy Robinson as the villain,, gotta love that scream when he gets stabbed that was classic,, there are lot's of good one liners for Clint to chew the scenery with and he does a great job of that folks. this film is about the injustice in the legal system, and how one man is going to attempt to go against the grain and fix the system his way,, one bullet at a time,, one thug at a time.. he is for the common man,, the down trodden , he kinda speaks for those who have been wronged by the justice system,, he was always one of my heroes growing up and will always be,, the character,, and the man himself,, Eastwood the great..

reviews.review_title: The ultimate reactionary movie of its day
reviews.content: "Dirty Harry" is an important film for several reasons, including the remaking of its star, Clint Eastwood, into a first-rank "modern-day" action star of American cinema; the development of a grittier-style cop drama for which DH remains the standard today; and as the first unmistakable sign, by virtue of its popularity, of a significant public turning against the counter-culture that was feeding much of the content from Hollywood by this time.People may point to "Patton" the year before, but that film retained a certain disapproving detachment from its protagonist. "Dirty Harry" is presented as our hero, plain and simple, Miranda and Escovito be damned. So effectively did Eastwood play this character that he spent four sequels apologizing for him by putting Harry up against right-wing extremists and interracial gangs while partnering with a Rainbow Coalition of enlightening partners, including the actor who played the poor bank robber he torments with his "six shots or fives" line near the beginning of the film.It's probably the only way to have kept the franchise going, because the original Harry would have been tough sledding after a while, but there's no denying that power he had his first time out was something neither he nor any other movie cop ever had again. There's a couple of scenes that bring it home, one when he confronts the DA who refuses to prosecute Scorpio ("I'm all broken up about his rights," Harry says) and the other where Harry waits for Scorpio alone at the end, gun drawn, all business, while the rest of the law-enforcement community plays the game.The film does try to show us that Harry's heart is in the right place, that while he doesn't mind being seen as a racist he really isn't one. After he blows away three bank robbers, all black, we get to see him being worked on by an African-American doctor who's an old friend. The scummy lead villain, and a great one as played by Andy Robinson, is a baby-faced white boy who doesn't like hippies any more than Harry (less, actually, since Harry isn't aiming a rifle at them).There's one stupid scene, the one involving the jumper, which is sloppy-edited and lazily thought-out. Harry doesn't seem the guy for the job, know what I mean? Otherwise, Don Siegel is brilliant putting Harry through his paces, and the result is even better than "Bullitt" for my money. The subway scene goes on for a while, but it's shot very well, superbly interplaying shadow and sound as our eyes stretch across corners hunting for the killer. I think the music makes an important contribution as well, here and elsewhere.People still debate whether Siegel's earlier "Invasion Of The Body Snatchers" was right-wing anti-communism or left-wing criticism of same. No question what colors he was flying here, but this is one case where not playing it subtle was the way to go.
In all the series of the film, how the collaborators, who are one with the criminals in the law enforcement agency, reflect negatively on life are explained in a beautiful way.
It's a film with an aesthetic as appealing as it's name. The sound of the magnum and ruthless but witty protagonist packs a punch.

The film that solidified Clint Eastwood's status as America's leading man. Dirty Harry succeeds on every level with what it sets out to achieve. The music is amazing, especially in its exciting percussion and its incorporating of background effects. The camerawork is neat, and the selective use of violence (eg we don't see the dead boy, only Chico's reaction) shows you the care and seriousness put into this film. The football pitch scene is astounding, but for me, the single factor that lifts this movie into legendary status is the astounding performance of Andy Robinson as Scorpio. Cowardly, terrifying, human and yet emotionless, he is devoted to the part for every second and is a true portrait of the serial killer. A resounding scream of defiance to all the liberal attitudes of the sixties, Dirty Harry is a product of modern society, but unlike Death Wish the film doesn't want to stand up and celebrate him, only show how he is a necessary evil.

reviews.review_title: Clint's performance ensures that Harry never grows old
reviews.content: I don't think you could have made this movie today. It would not have been taken seriously. One of the reasons is an obvious one, many of the plot points and elements in this film has since become clichés, and can't be used without acknowledging that it's a tired old trope. But also the sincerity in the portrayal of the cynical character is something that today's audience seldom see in new movies. Or perhaps I am just watching the wrong movies? Either way, I consider this as a positive quality for the film. There's no winks to the audience.But the film does feel dated in certain aspects. I think it's harder to like the Harry character today than it was back then, as the values he stands for are not really the one we aspire to today. But seen as a movie set in the era it was made, it still works. And had Harry not been Dirty Harry, the movie probably wouldn't have worked at all. The plot itself is interesting enough, but it's Clint Eastwood's performance that makes this movie last.And Clint Eastwood kills it. This movie was definitely made in his prime.

reviews.review_title: The epitome of an American action film that is overlooked
reviews.content: Much has been discussed about this 1971 cop thriller for the last four decades since its release. Many filmmakers and actors of the action film genre have paid their tribute to this film and its titular character; preserving its four decade long legacy. However, the film is overlooked for its visual storytelling. Not that it uses any groundbreaking shots and editing techniques, but the film has the precise aesthetic quality of a low budget thriller. One of the most memorable shots in the film was the overhead zoom out of Harry torturing the Scorpio killer in the foggy Kezar Stadium with Lalo Schifrin's jazzy score effectively conveying the bleak tone of the scene and shot. This kind of aesthetic detail in a low budget cop thriller (let alone an action film) doesn't get enough credit from film goers and critics. Another overlooked quality are the performances. Clint Eastwood effectively adapts his already established western hero persona in a contemporary setting. Andy Robinson's chilling performance (that certainly traumatized me when I first watched this film at the age of ten) as the Scorpio Killer paved the way for the hyperbolically insane villains that have become a staple in that film genre. The screenplay has the lean pacing of a thriller, but is cleverly written with dialog that is just as lean and to the point. Personally, the perfect American action film has the raw aesthetic quality, with a lean script, and naturally great performances. Dirty Harry fulfills those requirements successfully.

No one can play a bad-ass, squinting anti-hero like Clint Eastwood. Dirty Harry is full of memorable moments that have influenced so many movies that came after it, and it is a true classic of its genre. The killer, Scorpio, is such a sick and reprehensible S.O.B., that it makes the viewer want him caught by any means necessary, just like Callahan. Sure, it's a little beyond belief to think that Callahan wouldn't have known that his actions were going to endanger the investigation, but I'd like to think that most people would have done exactly the same things that he did. And when the end finally comes for Scorpio, it is oh so satisfying. So yeah, this was an awesome movie. I wish I would have seen it a long time ago. It completely deserves its iconic status.

reviews.review_title: Gritty Realizim will always be king
reviews.content: This is a great film about one detectives fight against a almost too liberal society. I as a liberal cannot believe that this movie does not offend me, but it brings to life the gritty realism's that do effect us as a liberal society. When this film was made killers like the Scorpio killer in this movie were getting the easy brakes, look at Charlie Manson and his disciples of hate, they all should have been sent to the chair for their sins, I cant stand people who would glorify this man and his deeds by wearing a T-shirt with his face. I am all for free speech but as it is stated in the Bill of Rights where the first ten amendments are located, free speech is only applicable when it does not infringe and , or take away from the rights of others. It is in this that Dirty Harry rises. It shows that if you are a murdering coward you should be punished. I love when Harry throws away his badge at the end of the movie showing that he is tired of the sickness that is all through out the corrupt system of police and it's over long litigation process. This film is at it's best when it showcases the hunt and the lengths to which Clint Eastwood's character will go to avenge peoples rights. This is best stated when Harry's superior officer tell him the Scorpio Killer has rights and that Callahan infringed on this rights. With that said Eastwood's brilliant character replies back in a satirical manner "I'm all broken up about that mans rights!" That is what this film stands for, too many bureaucrats allow criminals to roam the streets while they worry about falsely criminalizing people who can't afford insurance, or a place to live. These people go to jail while your local town maniac sits on his couch waiting for his next fool moon murder. Come on, we need Dirty Harry back on the case.

reviews.review_title: Great thriller with a lot on its mind
reviews.content: "I know what you're thinking. "Did he fire six shots or only five?" Well, to tell you the truth, in all this excitement I kind of lost track myself. But being as this is a .44 Magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world, and would blow your head clean off, you've got to ask yourself one question: Do I feel lucky? Well, do ya, punk?".The iconic Dirty Harry series never matched the first film in the series; Don Siegel's enthralling crime thriller doesn't waste time on extraneous action scenes and convoluted plots, focusing purely on the characters and the political, moral, and ethical repercussions of their actions, and the very nature of justice. It's a remarkably intelligent film with some outstanding acting and writing, but the director Don Siegel steals the show with some absolutely brilliant use of the widescreen format. Honestly, when you watch "Dirty Harry" you wonder why so many average directors out there don't even seem to care about things like composition. The score by Lalo Schifrin is terrific as well.The film does have its problems, of course, but for the most part they come in the form of little moments and scenes that don't fit ("I want my mother!"). By and large this film is a tremendously entertaining thriller and one with a lot on its mind. It's not dumb entertainment by any measure, and I don't think you have to agree with Harry's politics to appreciate the film (I'm left-leaning, although I would have had to restrain myself if given the chance to kill the evil bastard of a villain this movie had).Not Siegel's best movie, but a quality thriller nonetheless, and far from shallow. Eastwood is great here, of course.8.5/10

Warner Brothers is set to release the Dirty Harry Ultimate Collector's Edition so I paid respectful tribute to their cash grab by borrowing an old 4:3 version of Don Siegel's genre defining, tough as nails cop movie. What I loved about my version was how it looked like old TV reruns from the 70's: faded, scratchy, well-worn...and dirty. I'm sure the new widescreen, digitally remastered version looks sparkling by comparison, but who wants to watch a gritty film with all the grit buffed out? I want my Dirty Harry filthy.The movie itself is pretty much what you'd expect if you've never seen it or (like me) haven't watched it in a very long time. The crooks are scumbags, the bureaucrats are pussies and the law is the blast shield these weasels all hide behind. Enter Harry Callahan (Clint Eastwood) and his best (and only) friend Mr. 44 Magnum (Smith & Wesson). When Harry is finished, this same blast shield resembles a splintered, bloodied and hollowed out exit wound to the back of a human skull. Early on, Harry, gun extended, asks a wounded bank robber: "I know what you're thinking. Did he fire six shots or only five? Well, to tell you the truth, in all this excitement I kind of lost track myself. But being as this is a .44 Magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world, and would blow your head clean off, you've got to ask yourself one question: Do I feel lucky? Well, do ya, punk?" Immortal words. As far as characters go, there's not a lot of depth to Harry. We get the hint his wife has been killed and that no one on the police force really likes him, they simply fear him. Harry is ice cold, trigger happy, racist, misanthropic, cynical and is incapable of spelling due process, let alone defining it. In other words, this guy embodies the typical American in the early 1970's, a collective soured by the senseless carnage of the Vietnam War. In fact, Harry is a right winger's wet dream where the crooks are corpses long before they get a chance to beg for "habeas corpus." I suppose in many ways, Harry embodies what the typical right-wing American wishes they could have done to the Viet Cong: blow em' away and put an end to this mess. But sadly, this is a movie and, wish fulfillment aside, things in the USA would get far worse (mounting Vietnam casualties and Watergate) before they would get better. In the end, Harry's six gun justice leaves him as disillusioned at the end as he was at the beginning and aside from some blood lust being served, the audience has to ask the same questions they must have been asking about the Vietnam War: Why?What is refreshing about watching a movie like DH today is its disdain for political correctness and its balls out ability to show society as a cesspool in need of a good scrubbing. They don't make movies like this anymore and I'm shocked they don't considering how easily the Neo-Cons have made Watergate seem like a petty political prank and how Iraq is fast becoming our generation's Vietnam. The truth is, we could use a revamped and retooled version of Dirty Harry. Maybe this time around he could be a blood thirsty Secret Service Agent who snaps and goes on a rampage in the oval office. Final Draft here I come.http://eattheblinds.blogspot.com/

reviews.review_title: Well do you feel lucky punk? do ya?
reviews.content: What HALLOWEEN did for slasher movies so many years later, DIRTY HARRY did for the committed cop!  As someone quite correctly pointed out, where do you think Martin Riggs (Lethal Weapon) came from?DIRTY HARRY started it all and was unapproachably the best of the series. It had two things going for it...three, if you count Clint Eastwood. Direction by the brilliant Don Siegel who had already steered Eastwood through COOGAN'S BLUFF (who WAS of course the ancestor of DIRTY HARRY anyway) and a blinder of a performance by Andy Robinson as the Zodiac killer - absolute evil personified and as despicable a bad guy as has ever been thrown up on screen since. Audiences in 1971 had never seen violence so up-close and personal...Harry was the way...the future, the solution to all our doubts and antagonisms towards Vietnam. One of the most successful films of the period, Eastwood never looked back or ever topped this particular performance.The language and violence was jaw-dropping stuff In '71 (the only other film doing the "R" certificate rounds was Michael Caine's GET CARTER!) Siegel's direction was tight, the script - tighter and the box office receipts world wide, on fire!  If you have never seen DIRTY HARRY you have missed an integral part of American film history!

reviews.review_title: We need more cops like Harry.
reviews.content: This gritty, violent 70's cop flick is still one of my favorites. Yep, this is the one that started it all! Clint Eastwood IS Harry Callahan, a tough San Francisco inspector who always gets the job done, no matter how dirty it is, hence the name. Running around is a sniper killer (calling himself Scorpio) who is trying to extort money from the city through the murder of innocent people, a deed he thoroughly enjoys doing. Harry, of course, doesn't approveat all, and sets out to stop him. However, even though Harry does the right things, the written law is against him and Scorpio plays the system for all he can, that is, until Harry decides enough is enough. The movie never lets up and is filled with witty dialogue and thrilling action. The two leads are both very convincing in their roles and the psychedelic 70's music is excellent. One of the best scenes has Harry foil a bank robbery (by shooting most of 'em) while calmly finishing his hot dog and at the end, delivers the famous "Do you feel lucky, punk?" lines to a wounded robber whose shotgun lies just a foot away. You gotta love the .44 Mag! This film is not to be missed! The four sequels, while enjoyable, don't even start to come near the quality of this masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: A Classic crime thriller for Eastwood enjoyers
reviews.content:
An excellent crime thriller. Clint Eastwood is casted perfectly in his role as a quintessential hardened P.I. badass. The world is rough and so he is rough back; always coming out victorious despite a lacking support of all authority, weak law system, and weaker stomachs. Even when he gets his ass kicked he looks tough. The plot is simple and straightforward: a homicidal nut is on the loose, demanding money from the police and killing innocent people. It achieves this narrative fully with original characters and performances, as well as the clever and exciting way the killer sets Harry up to get the ransom. The vicious clash of this villain and well, hero, is not forgettable.
The cinematography was involving, appropriate and solid. The film grain looked beautiful. I felt 1971 all over. And there was an impressive helicopter shot from the football stadium out. Locations were sweet, good choices of San Francisco. The weak points in the film are in some of the dialogue feeling rather conscious of what a badass Clint is playing, like when he say, "Now you know why they call me Dirty Harry, because I do every dirty job that comes around." Pretty playful, I just felt it was trying to be a little too tough. Another weakness is the writing being forced or not giving good explanation, like the shooter getting away from the same rooftop a second time!
Overall very entertaining, climatic ending, and tells the story of Dirty Harry to the world true, and with fervor. Plus gives us some badass quotes to remember.

reviews.review_title: Well do ya feel lucky punk? You will do revisiting this!
reviews.content: Clint Eastwood stars in one of his most famous roles as San Francisco Homicide Inspector Harry Callahan known amongst the police fraternity as Dirty Harry for his quite antihero but ultimately successful methods.The film from 1971 is lavishly shot in the city of San Francisco by director Don Siegel. The film also boasts a soundtrack composed by Lalo Schifrin better known for composing the TV theme for Mission Impossible.The plot concerns a mad man serial killer called Scorpio who terrorises the city with ransom demands and ever more elaborate murders. The city mayor not wanting more bloodbaths seems intent on meeting the killers increasing financial demands whilst Callahan believes he needs stopping using his more direct methods shall we say that fly against the 'left wing' civil liberties of the American constitution.Eastwood directs some scenes himself in a sign of what direction (pardon the pun) his later film career will take perhaps.I was amused with the 1971 environment. For example Scorpio at first demands the 'massive' sum of $100,000!The cars look massive almost as bushy as Eastwoods hairstyle.I sometimes wonder if a more right wing method of law enforcement would lower the crime rate (minus blowing people's heads off of course!)That reminds me. The film is best known for one of Callahans phrases that he uses twice in this film. The "Do you feel lucky, punk" speech. Actually Callahan is armed with a .44 Magnum firearm. The most powerful hangun in the world at the time.It apparently could blow your head clean off. If faced with its barrel pointing at you, you've got to ask yourself one question surely. It fires six bullets. In all the excitement of a 1970s shooutout. You wonder if five or six shots have been fired. 'Do I feel lucky? Well, do you punk?'

Any one of the other actors who turned down the role of Dirty Harry could have breathed some decent amount of life into the character, but Clint Eastwood IS Harry Callahan. It's Eastwood's cool and coolness, his screw-you defiance, his height and hair, his unrealistic-but-critical-to-the-story ignorance of the Bill of Rights, and those abso-stinkin'-lutely awesome Ray-Bans that add the frosting to the cake--the really flawless chemistry between the screenplay by Rita and Harry Fink, Dean Reisner, and John Milius (uncredited) and the direction of Don Siegel, one of America's greatest contract directors.It's been over a third of a century since Harry blew a hole in America's concept of what a movie cop should be; I recently showed certain, brief moments from the movie to teach the 4th, 5th, 8th, and 14th Amendments to my 10th grade history students, and many of them had not seen the movie. They paid lip service to the idea that Harry Callahan, in real life, would be boiled in Constitutional oil for screwing up so badly--and they did well on a Bill of Rights test, thank you!--but Siegel's craftsmanship and Eastwood's "command presence" made them howl when I shut the movie off--"You can't just stop it there--we need to watch the whole thing--this is GOOD!" What a great recommendation--I hope Don is listening.

reviews.review_title: Dirty Harry is a great film on an already dropped-in theme by the 70s
reviews.content: Dirty Harry is a great film on an already dropped-in theme by the 70s, which is to say about the police thriller genre after 50 years. But the genre is now going through bad times and it is Dirty Harry that is a vivid example of this. A great and simple story, a great Clint Eastwood. A proper subject of cruelty, which many have criticized. But it was thanks to her and the position of the protagonist that the film became a cult.

Dirty Harry is amazing. Simple as that. It's over 30 years old and it's still better than most of the cop movies out today. Eastwood defined "Bad ass" with his role. The villain he matches wits with is great, too. Never in the history of every movie I've ever seen have I wanted a villain to die more badly than I wanted Scorpio to. I know that sounds kind of morbid, but it's true. He is just a horrible scumbag of a villain, and all the way through I was rooting for Harry to get the S.O.B.This is the definitive Clint Eastwood (cop) film. If you've wondered why he's so popular, just watch Dirty Harry and you'll see why. If you're not standing up cheering when he jumps on that bus, check your pulse- cause you just might be dead. It's a ultimate "guy's night in" flick.My Rating: 10/10

"You've got to ask yourself one question: 'Do I feel lucky?' Well, do ya, punk?" -- Harry Callahan, DIRTY HARRY.And a screen icon is scarred onto the face of filmdom. And the Earth is once again salted with the man-nectar of masculinity.DIRTY HARRY is about a cop who takes the law into his own hands. That's the simple synopsis. But the cultural impact of this film and Clint Eastwood's most enduring character is indescribable.Beyond the art of movies, beyond the rubric of cops and robbers, beyond the playground where good and evil frolic hand in hand, "Dirty Harry" has entered the lexicon as shorthand for righteous brutality, masculine justice, and not taking crap; the film DIRTY HARRY spawned innumerable "loose cannon" cop films (which was a misapprehension of its actual theme) and a more disturbing level of violence in movies; DIRTY HARRY took the anti-authority hippie stance of the 60s to the next level of societal angst in the newly-minted '70s.Amidst the furor over an unwinnable war (times just don't change, do they?) American aggression found catharsis in DIRTY HARRY. Simplistically, the movie advocates violence against those who spawn violence (two wrongs making a right), seemingly advocating personal vigilantism over the dinosaurian "justice system"; yet the real message was too subtle for American audiences, who prove themselves time and again too blunt to comprehend subtlety. As Clint himself espouses, "It's not about a man who stands for violence. It's about a man who can't understand society tolerating violence." And Clint Eastwood should know. He IS Dirty Harry.In a role intended for Sinatra, Eastwood owned Detective Harry Callahan like Sinatra owned "My Way." After we meet alpha male Harry as an edgy maverick San Francisco cop who "doesn't play any favorites! Harry hates everybody" he is teamed with a young Mexican Inspector, Chico (Reni Santoni) and soon on the trail of a psycho sniper killer, Scorpio (Andy Robinson, who would never again command a role so hallucinogenically ruthless and tasty).The subtext is that Scorpio is Harry on the wrong side of the law (As Above, So Below; the devil is god inverted). He hates minorities too and demands a ransom from the city of San Francisco in return for not shooting a homosexual or a catholic priest (nowadays that's the same thing).There are the authority figures stultifying Harry's methods, then castigating him with legal technicalities when he gets the job done (John Vernon as the Mayor and Josef Sommer as the D.A.). And there is the first pairing of Eastwood with the ever-frazzled Harry Guardino as his Lieutenant.Author Richard Schickel defines that moment a star becomes a superstar - the scene that establishes why Harry is Dirty, shooting down bank robbers while still chewing a hot dog.From a diner, Harry spies a car idling outside a bank. Not wanting to interrupt his break, he instructs the chef to call in a robbery in progress. As Harry takes the first bite of his hot dog, alarms start clamoring, and he resignedly drops the dog and exits the diner, still chewing on the bite. And drawing his big gun. He sees an armed robber exiting the bank (Albert Popwell in the first of his four roles in Dirty Harry movies) and yells, "Halt!" mid-chew. The robber fires on Harry; Harry fires back, sending the robber sprawling. The getaway car careens at Harry, who calmly takes aim and shoots it, sending it crashing into a fire hydrant, which jets water like a carnival.And now, the pièce de résistance: Harry saunters to the downed robber - still chewing - and calmly points his gun at him, the robber looking tentatively at his own gun on the ground, inches from him. And Harry speaks: "I know what you're thinking. 'Did he fire six shots or only five?' Well, to tell you the truth, in all this excitement I kind of lost track myself. But being as this is a .44 Magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world, and would blow your head clean off, you've got to ask yourself one question: 'Do I feel lucky?' Well, do ya, punk?" The milk of Legend.The robber declines the challenge, yet when Harry turns to walk away, the robber beseeches him, "Hey!... I gots to know." The milk of hilarity.By now Harry has morphed into a composite of Clint/Harry, as he smugly points his Magnum at the flinching robber - and pulls the trigger! Click! Empty barrels! Harry smiles that Eastwood smile and saunters away.By now we are overdosing on Legend...While his mythos as a laconic avenger was birthed with Leone's DOLLAR trilogy, the DIRTY HARRY movies rounded out this more "modern" Clint. And if Leone was responsible for carving Clint into Legend, the director of this cinematic juggernaut was the other man who "made" Eastwood: Don Siegel.The finale is the cement that hardens the Legend. Harry points his Magnum at Scorpio, who is shielding himself with a boy. In a classic callback, Harry recites the same monologue he gave to the bank robber - but this time the tone is taut disdain, a mocking death knell for the person whom it is addressed to. And the funny thing is: during Harry's first speech, he is out of ammo, during his second, he has one bullet left - yet the circumstances make him a winner both times.In Clint's Magnum opus we know that Harry Callahan stands for what is truly right - over and above any written law cravenly passed by sniveling old rich white guys who rape justice in the ass. The funny thing is: when you yourself come up against morally ambiguous situations in life, you look to someone like Harry Callahan to guide you. And you gotta ask yourself a question, "Do you feel Dirty?" Well, do ya, punk?!

There are mountains of praise for Dirty Harry, and all of them are deserved. But one thing that gets me is the justification of freeing Scorpio for the third act that comes off as pure propaganda: would any police department really free someone in a mask who shot at them so freely? The story swerves into a bit of disbelief when Scorpio, after injuring a few police officers and is in turn injured, is suddenly let go after being shot in the leg. To add insult to injury, the whole thing is turned into a right-wing nonsensefest where Harry goes on about victim's right (a valid concern) but is shot down by the personification of a smug liberal (from Berkeley, no less!) simply to get us to the third act. Even then, it's a bit hard to take seriously since they did have something to hang Scorpio on: shooting a police officer.This is a classic movie that deserves its fame. But the one flaw is that instead of writing a segue into the third act, they decided to go into an unrealistic rant that demonizes one half of the political spectrum for absolutely no real reason. It just seems a bit silly, but don't let this ruin the movie for you. Eastwood's always good, Siegel is at the top of his game, and maybe you can get a chuckle out of seeing their attempts to push the movie to the end by pathetic political doublethink.

reviews.review_title: Hard hitting, elegantly simplistic roundhouse to the crime genre
reviews.content: To tackle a storyline lynched from current news headlines of the real life Zodiac serial killer committing unspeakable murders while leaving taunting notes to the city must have taken guts aplenty, an arguably too topical event which may have attracted controversy for being passed off as mere entertainment. However, director Don Siegel must have been feeling lucky indeed, as not an ounce of fear makes its way into his boldly straightforward cinematic vision. Nor was there any need for fear, as it must have become clear that he was dealing with the stuff of legends, and his hardboiled protagonist, 'Dirty' Harry Callahan was indeed one for the ages, and his resulting film an abiding and endlessly influential classic in the cop thriller genre. Despite all preconceptions of Clint Eastwood leaving his defining genre, it is hardly as far removed as one might think, as in the end the essence of Dirty Harry remains clear: a spaghetti Western dressed up as a crime drama. From embracing countless genre themes (a lone gunman, vicious but honourable is forced to function independently to save the stifling system he could never be a part of) to having Harry brandish a .44 magnum which would hardly seem out of place in any saloon brawl to having Harry walk off by himself at the film's finish he remains every inch the classic Western protagonist, self-exiled against a claustrophobic society yet forced to protect it despite his own inability to fit in. Similarly, upon viewing in a contemporary context, it becomes clear just how influential the film was - beyond the timeless "Do you feel lucky? Well, do ya punk?" line, the blueprints for just about every ensuing cop thriller are lain, from the terse vigilante antihero to the perfectly paced breathless action sequences to the splendidly shot city feeling almost like a present character to the comic buddy banter between Harry and his sidekick of another race, resulting in many culture clash cracks. From the eighties on, the genre would never be the same, becoming increasingly flimsy templates, all of which owe countless thanks to Harry Callahan for paving the way. The film itself remains a masterclass in simplicity at its most refined: a lean, taut thriller trimmed of all unnecessary filler. From the very start the film gets right to the point with no mistaking its intentions and hardly lets up the swift, rock steady pace from that point on. There are no troublesome subplots (such as the exhausted genre convention of watching Harry drink himself to sleep at home) but instead the entire film focuses strictly on the case at hand, the only character development to speak of demonstrated by those reacting to the events of the Scorpio case. It must have become clear to Siegel that he had no need for showy dialogue or wordy exposition - it must have been clear he had something iconic in the making, and as such he simply lets Harry speak for himself in limited but piercing bursts of language. From the instant he first grimly saunters on screen, the audience has a fully defined perception of the man, and the later jokey deliberating on what Harry has done to merit his 'Dirty' billing is amusing but largely unnecessary - like the classic Western hero, Harry's actions speak for themselves, conveying a remarkable amount with next to no expenditure of effort. The simplicity works, whipping the film along at a cracking pace while only occasionally appearing underwritten, largely during terse moral exchanges between Harry and his superiors, which expose the moral crux of the film but overly falling prey to convention to be fully effective. Siegel's film also boasts some genuinely spectacular cinematography, showcasing the San Francisco locations with a visceral yet oddly aesthetic splendour, fully grounding the film in gritty realism while boasting a uniquely cinematic charm all the same. Siegel shows an eye for extracting the visual thrill of cinematic blackness like no other, as the film, often shot in barely visible or mostly obscured darkness demonstrates a bold intensity, a neo-noir grit to counterbalance the piercing sunlight of the daytime photography. This is a world of extremes, both moral and visual, and the cinematic composition echoes the contrast as strictly as Harry's no nonsense right counterbalances Scorpio's unhinged wrong. Lalo Schifrin's intriguing jazzy musical score completes the package, an exhilarating and entirely fitting concoction once again far ahead of its time. It goes without saying that Clint Eastwood is what really makes the movie, and indeed it is impossible to envision any other presence than the immortal Eastwood squint bringing Harry to life, despite the role passing through the hands of actors as diverse as Paul Newman, Frank Sinatra, Steve McQueen, Robert Mitchum and John Wayne. Eastwood slips into the character like a leathery pair of gloves, each twinge of passionate, animalistic anger and grim detachment fully realised and not for a second unbelievable - a plausibility of character he was hard pressed to match in a formidable career. Backing Eastwood's cinematic icon, Andrew Robinson makes for a wonderfully unhinged killer, his nervy twitching and erratic demeanour making for an unorthodox and genuinely unsettling threat. Reni Santori makes for a charming comedic deadpan as Harry's unwanted partner, and John Larch and John Vernon both chew scenery accordingly as the mayor and chief of police constantly battering Harry for his risky methods and fanatical dedication to the case. While some may fault the film as being overly simplistic and certain patches do come across as borderline underwritten, Dirty Harry remains a refreshingly direct cop thriller which set a precedent for countless imitators, effectively overhauling the crime genre for decades to come. While Eastwood would reprise his iconic character for three more efforts, none would match the hard hitting, superbly crafted effectiveness of this original, easily worth seeing... for those feeling lucky enough. -9/10

reviews.review_title: "The first and best of Eastwood's incarnations as Dirty Harry."
reviews.content: A tough San Francisco cop called Inspector "Dirty" Harry Callahan (Eastwood) tracks down a psychopathic rooftop sniper (Robinson) who threatens to murder one person a day unless a ransom of $200,000 is payed. The mayor of the city plays for time which results in a fourteen-year-old girl being abducted and threatens to kill her unless a higher ransom is payed. Callahan attempts to lay a trap for the killer, but it backfires and the girl dies. The man is finally arrested but the case is dismissed due to a lack of evidence and the killer takes a private revenge against Callahan and the city of San Francisco.The first and best of Eastwood's outings as the tough and uncompromising cop with no time for the rule book or his superiors, but at the same time he hates the criminals and will go to any lengths to bring them to his own form of justice. DIRTY HARRY presents the audience with the view that the central character despite his illegal and unorthodox methods has got a higher moral sense than the people in charge and therefore caused great controversy and also ensured a box office hit. Eastwood took the role on after other actors including Frank Sinatra, Paul Newman and John Wayne among them turned the role down and he gives a first rate performance that he would repeat in four sequels. They were MAGNUM FORCE (1973), THE ENFORCER (1976), SUDDEN IMPACT (1983) and THE DEAD POOL (1988). Andy Robinson is also brilliant as the psychotic murderer, Don Siegel's direction is impeccable and the San Franciscan locations are well used.
