On any level, large or small, the desire to see justice done in universal. Many will contend that it is more pronounced in the wake of a significant emotional experience, but in the final analysis, it's a craving with parameters of neither time nor place; a hunger that demands to be satiated. And in our tumultuous times and world, that longing for justice too often goes unsatisfied, and occasionally it's gratifying to get a taste of it, if only through the magic of the movies.  Which is exactly what you get with `Dirty Harry,' directed by Don Siegel, in which star Clint Eastwood introduces one of-- if not the-- most memorable characters of his long and varied career, the iconoclastic veteran San Francisco detective, Harry Callahan.	In his many years on the job, Callahan has seen it all up close and suffered personal loss, as well; so much so that he is committed to doing the right thing, even if it means discarding all the rules and proceeding as he sees fit-- playing by his own rules, as it were.  In his eyes, there's the law, and then there's justice-- and he is determined that the latter shall prevail at any cost.  Which is the lesson a psychotic killer (Andrew Robinson) is about to learn when he picks Callahan to play a game of cat-and-mouse with; a game that involves the life of a young girl he has kidnapped and is threatening to kill unless Harry jumps through some hoops of his own demented design for him.  And by the time it's over, there are lessons learned, to be sure.  Everything may not turn out happily ever after, but rest assured, before the credits roll, justice will have been served.  Dirty Harry style.	Siegel has crafted and delivered an emotionally involving drama that makes you feel the frustration and anger of being defiled without recompense, at the hands of one of the cinema's most heinous villains ever.  Siegel presents his antagonist in such a way that very quickly he becomes a truly loathsome character who is almost unbearable to watch at times.  He is so vile, in fact, that by the time Callahan draws a bead on him you want nothing more than to see him throttled from one side of the screen to the other.  As in real life, however, things do not necessarily proceed as you would like, and you may find yourself gnashing your teeth in mounting frustration as the killer eludes Callahan's grasp time and again.  But as you're biting off yet another fingernail, keep in mind that in the end, justice is visited.	Dirty Harry Callahan is the character, it seems, that Clint Eastwood was born to play.  The attitude, the nuance and the eye for detail he brings to this role makes Callahan unique and memorable.  This is a character onto which you can project your own frustrations and sensibilities, which enables you to share not only his sense of futility, but his satisfaction as Harry ultimately metes out the justice it seems the whole world is in need of by the end of the movie.  And it's a satisfaction you will carry with you out of the theater, or beyond the confines of your own living room.  There's a depth to Eastwood's portrayal that gives you some clues as to what it is that really makes Callahan tick, but at the same time he only lets you in so far, so that by the end there is still a bit of mystery behind the man.  And even now, some thirty years after this film was made, Harry Callahan emerges as the definitive anti-hero for our times, which serves as an indication of just how strong this performance by Eastwood is.  It is, without question, one of his best.	There's no mystery, however, to the fact that Andrew Robinson gives an extraordinary performance here as the killer.  He is so despicable, in fact, that one has to wonder if this part perhaps had an adverse affect on his career.  On a personal note, I know that for years afterward I couldn't stand to see Robinson in anything, because no matter what part he was playing I could not get past his persona as the killer in this film.  A good example is the 1973 film `Charlie Varrick,' which is an excellent movie (also directed by Siegel), but one I would not be able to appreciate until years later because Robinson's presence was simply too overwhelming.  In retrospect, it says a lot about his ability as an actor; that he could leave such an indelible impression with a single portrayal is certainly indicative of his talent.  	The supporting cast includes Harry Guardino (Bressler), Reni Santoni (Chico), John Vernon (The Mayor), John Larch (Chief), John Mitchum (De Georgio), Mae Mercer (Mrs. Russell), Lun Edgington (Norma) and Ruth Kobart (Bus Driver).  Backed with a terrific score by Lalo Schifrin, `Dirty Harry' is a hard-hitting, extremely emotionally involving film (especially for one of this genre) that will get your blood pumping in any number of directions at the same time.  It's escapist fare, to be sure, but it hits so close to home that it is both disconcerting and ultimately fulfilling.  Definitely one you're going to remember.  And that's the magic of the movies.  I rate this one 9/10.

Spoilers, if one hasn't somehow yet seen the film.Before Hill Street Blues or NYPD, or Police Story, on TV, and now over 30 years old. Here was a film which opened with a dedication to fallen SFPD officers. But the fashions haven't changed that much. Hairstyles are about the same (this wasn't a completely 70s-looking film). And the cynical, edgy behavior was very 90s, and even current, today.How does the film hold up? Well, the courts don't work. The criminals are preferred over the victims. Pets are protected, people aren't. One arm of the law seems at war with the other. One statue vitiates another. The 'system' only attacks the law-abiding. Etc. And Justice demands penalty for Scorpio's crimes. So Harry is justified at Kezar, something like that. He clearly is justified at the end, because Scorpio goes for the gun. It's literally self-defense. The angry wordplay, literally the taunting, could be excused as an effort to get 'the edge'. It does seem recklessly inviting nonetheless, making Harry the killer at that moment, and the psychotic killer his victim.There are inconsistencies. Earlier, when the tooth is revealed, Harry is sure the girl is dead. When Harry is on the phone, with only Chico listening in by wireless, he asks - is the girl alive? How could it be both? So Harry is sure she's dead. But then as 'bagman', he runs all over town to catch the psycho. He shoots him and tortures him in the stadium, because he wants to know if he can rescue her - before she dies? The stadium scene is really the key scene of the film. It's startling when DeGeorgio hits the stadium lights at just the right time. It ends in the helicopter shot, as that used in Easy Rider, for example (the final scene pull back, and stop, which terminates this and other Harry films). And it's a good explanation of San Francisco; 'rolled up' city streets, cold low fog, wet stadium (Kezar stadium was since rebuilt, lowered, and named after HOF 'niner Bob Sinclair).As others have pointed out, Eastwood had to apologize for Dirty Harry, at least in the subsequent two films. That's what really crippled those two sequels. They were Dirty Harry lite, even anti-Harry, that were afraid of Dirty Harry. The fourth film returned a bit to the original. And he does let himself, or rather his mirror image in Sondra Locke's character, off the hook as an angel of justice in her own right.This film is a hit because of the odd combination of the minimalist score, Siegel, Eastwood of course, but also Robinson who makes the film for his insanely perverted killer, who like Malkovich's killer in a later Eastwood film, and unlike aux. Rat-Packer Silva in a 'Eastwood-type' film from Burt Reynolds, doesn't even need to 'shoot up' to kill. He just shoots and doesn't blink, completely sober. And he seems driven to commit murder and mayhem at any opportunity. In that, he approaches the nightmarish demons of later slasher films in the 70s. And it rings true for his whimpering when it suits him, just like any real bully or hardened thug.As for Harry, again, hero or killer? He is the very model of competence without any wasted motion. Or is he just an egotist, a Bill Clinton before anyone really knew? How did you know he was a rapist - asks the mayor? Over his shoulder Harry explains - trust ME to do the job. Don't ask questions. You do your job. I'll do mine. Oh wait, that was Steve McQueen in Bullitt, dressing down Robert Vaughn's untrustworthy martinet. So yes, his role is similar to that of John Wayne, in that 'Wayne's characters would often make their own law, out of frustration or convenience, or to achieve advantage. But even as a loner, The Duke had a 'posse'. There were people in town who called him friend. Dirty Harry is the man-with-no-name, a past but no family, etc. You don't know about the guy. There is no 'posse'. There are no drinking buddies.And what else about Harry? He confronts Popwell, shotgun on the ground nearby, with the famous bluff. Harry's gun is empty. Of course, Popwell's character is injured, so Harry could just have stepped on his arm if he'd gone for it. But he taunts. He knows his bullet count, and he taunts. Harry enjoys the 'reluctant hero', a bit too much. The 'dirty job' - is fun. Dirty Harry breaks the law to satisfy justice; or at least that's his plan. But as Urich asks in one of the 'extras' - can we have cops like this? And his obvious answer is, not really. What you don't see in this film, or subsequent films, is the dangerous side of Harry; when the bet goes bad. You only have hints. On the exit to 'Q' (and, of course, Scorpio doesn't live long enough to even get to prison), he hops the bus, potentially putting the kids and driver in further danger. In fact, the killer slugs the terrified driver because of the new danger.One last thing. The camera angles and perspectives are very interesting, and should be studied by anyone making a movie. The minimalist, almost drum n bass with choir, soundtrack is the extension of the Leone soundtracks, really, and a no-frills counterpoint to Shaft, perhaps, which had been released earlier that year. The characters, the actors themselves, look real. This is hand-held cameras and realism ala NYPD in the first year, and so on. That's how you make a 'B-film'. The chopper cops, and other detectives, people in the street - these look like real people on the job, not actors playing real people on the job. Much was made of this sort of thing in Bullitt, for example. The sets are faithful, and sometimes the progression of scenes are faithful to the geography.

reviews.review_title: amazing central character in violent crime movie
reviews.content: The narrative.As a crime genre, Dirty Harry fulfils many crime conventions such as gun scenes, chases, cop jokes, mystery and suspense. The direction by Siegel (Two mules for Sister Sara) is great, especially at the beginning when the first incident happens. The story builds up the tension at necessary points with many gun scenes encoded for emphasis. Its clear to see nowadays that gun scenes are overdone where as here in this classic there are few, adding a more realistic view of crime life. The film captures the realistic conventions of everyday police work and fulfils its purpose. It may lack at points but it's certainly entertaining throughout. The ending is very well directed and is very gripping.Characters and acting.Harry is certainly an astonishing character. His charisma towards his job is amazing and the way he treats others is jaw dropping, a terrific performance by Oscar winning Eastwood (Million Dollar baby). His infamous catchphrases make his character what he is "Do you feel lucky?" Many police are used to show a wide cop force, emphasising the power of Harry's reputation. The villain, played brilliantly by Robinson (Charley Varrick) is exactly what was required, a dominant force, a complete lunatic running riot to do what is needed to get what he wants for himself and he alone adds the suspense to the narrative.Ideologies.There are issues regarding jobs and murder used to build up the tension. Harry is particularly negative towards his job at many points and this technique is perhaps used to advice audiences to respect what they have. The murder and paedophilia issues are also very powerful and capture audience interest.watch it if...crime and amazing catchphrases are your thing

Dirty Harry is one of Clint Eastwood's quintessential roles after his western trilogy playing "The Man with No Name." In it he plays Harry Callahan, a cop who play by his own rules and doesn't give a damn about what anybody else thinks of his methods. Essentially, he is the epitome of the unconventional cop. Yet, despite his somewhat disparaging attitude, he is a very likable character. He is the tough guy, beaming with attitude and style, who you would always want on your side in a fight. It's not to say he doesn't take his job seriously though. He does. In the movie, Harry is chasing a serial killer who calls himself Scorpio (Andrew Robinson). But due to his unconventional behavior, Dirty Harry soon finds himself at war with not only Scorpio, but also the legal system. This, of course, causes Dirty Harry to take matters into his own hands. And so ensues an exciting and violent game of cops and robbers.Dirty Harry is a movie with style and attitude. It is what it is, and it makes sure you know it. It's the story of a hard-boiled cop fighting the most dangerous of criminals, and it shows in all aspects of the movie. It is a fun and riveting film with a climax that will have you on the edge of your seat. Don Seigel's directing captures every harrowing moment in the chases between Dirty Harry and Scorpio and Harry and Rita Fink's script delivers some fantastic one-liners that won't be forgotten.What the film lacks in a deep and intricate plot it makes up for in its style. Clint Eastwood makes a very believable tough guy as always and Andrew Robinson plays the crazed and psychopathic serial killer almost too well. Dirty Harry is an overall fun experience that doesn't leave you billowing over with emotion, but it leaves you satisfied nonetheless.

reviews.review_title: For fans of hard-boiled detective thrillers, this film has it all.
reviews.content: A violently inclined San Francisco police inspector (Clint Eastwood) is the only cop who can bring to book a mad sniper (Andy Robinson). When the man is released through lack of evidence, he takes private revenge.Dirty Harry was the inspiration for a spate of 'dirty cop' films, it was widely criticized at its time for its reactionary attitudes. But while Eastwood's Harry Callahan has little patience for civil rights for criminals, the film itself passes no judgement either way. Yet it does offer audiences a guilty thrill of pleasure to see bad guys banged up without formality, impartiality or courtesy. The film was followed by four sequels: Magnum Force in 1973, The Enforcer in 1976, Sudden Impact in 1983 (directed by Eastwood himself), and The Dead Pool in 1988.

reviews.review_title: The Best Cop Movie of All Time
reviews.content: Dirty Harry. The title itself suggests a high level of veracity and a bad-ass performance from the title character. By God does this movie deliver in more ways than one. Before Lethal Weapon, Clint Eastwood was the ultimate cop. San Francisco Police Inspector Harry Callahan is our cop fully realized. A man who cares about protecting the victims and getting the job done, before bureaucrats and the law try to stop him. Eastwood and director/mentor Don Siegel give us one of the best movies ever made, especially considering what genre it's in. It also ranks high for me because I am a native San Franciscan, so seeing my city for a story such as this is breathtaking.The story entails Harry's cat-and-mouse game between him and the psychotic killer known only as "Scorpio." Scorpio is based on the infamous Bay Area Zodiac Killer, who killed and kidnapped people for ransom from City Hall, but unlike the movie, he was never seen or identified. The actor who plays Scorpio, Andy Robinson, plays what is one of, if not my number one, greatest villains of all time. He looks like a choir-boy (as Siegel had intended) and he plays him with absolute menace and sadism. He is truly terrifying and looks like he just has fun playing the SFPD (especially Harry) like fools when he throws a loop in the procedures. He is flawless all the way to the end, and I believe Robinson was unfairly snubbed for a Best Supporting Actor nomination.We also begin to see one of the biggest ideas in the movie. During this game, Harry gains an even greater enemy, the suits from City Hall and even the higher-ups in the Police Hall of Justice. Because of Harry's methods of bringing Scorpio to justice. The issue of victims rights vs. the rights of the criminals and often how criminals are unfairly released because of the red tape and laws that would allow it are presented extremely well in this movie and also annoys us when we realize there are such laws on the books.With that in mind, when Harry takes it upon himself to apply the law as he sees it, it leads to some of the greatest scenes in Hollywood history. He is able to stop a bank and deliver his signature line "Do you feel lucky punk?" all while chewing on a hot dog on his lunch break. The other is on the field of the hallowed Kezar Stadium as Harry shoot Scorpio down and tortures the information of the girls whereabouts out of him. When I said that Harry is our idea of a cop fully realized, these scenes are what solidifies that statement. He does what we want to do to sickos like Scorpio, and shows us how people like this should be treated, instead of worrying if we will get in trouble. Is the torture scene violent? Yes it is. But that violence is what gets people talking about this movie, much like what Quentin Tarantino seeks for his movies, a debate about the ideas presented in the movies.This is one of my favorite movies of all time. The acting is perfect, the writing is phenomenal, Don Siegel is at his finest here. San Francisco looks spectacular and gives the perfect backdrop for such a story. If you are feeling lucky, check out the movie and judge for yourselves.

reviews.review_title: Good parts cannot make up for the inconsistencies and uneven flow.
reviews.content: This is kind of a hard one to decide about. First of all, Clint Eastwood is totally overrated as an actor. The part where he says, "Ask yourself: do I feel lucky," kind of reminds me of Terminator 2, where they kind of go fishing for memorable lines and the anticipation falls short. It felt totally cheap and forced. The second time he recites the famous screed, at the very end, to the killer, felt overdone and overused. This movie kind of feels like a composite of known serial killers in real life, and they could have been a bit more creative. You have the Scorpio killer in the movie, which is a take on The Zodiak in real-life; you've got Harry as a Peeping Tom, which was what Ted Bundy was known for; and you have a killer who targets gays, like Jeffrey Dahmer did. After watching this movie, I got the impression that Eastwood himself is a bit of a perv, as a recurring motif is "Peeping Tom." Such as his one line, where, while on a stake-out, he says to himself, "You owe it to yourself to live a little, Harry," while spying on a swingers' party when he should have been looking for Scorpio!! I thought he was a supposedly good detective!! Needless to say, there's a lot of nudity interspersed into the story. There's very little character development, as Harry is a person you either love or hate, and you mind is not changed throughout the very singular and narrow narrative. In fact, this feels more like a documentary in the style of 'Cops' than it feels as an actual movie. The music is very good, however. I give credit to Lalo Schifrin, who does a fantastic job. The plot elements are intriguing enough to give this a watch, I suppose. Andy Robinson's performance as a likewise- one dimensional Scorpio killer is at least passable. What this really was, was a personal statement about life in the 1970's and not much more.
A crime drama western, superb film, Clint Eastwood is great as are all the other actorsVery enjoyable. Well worth a watch.

reviews.review_title: A great example of how an action movie should be done.
reviews.content: This is what a good action movie today should be. Because what we have in this film are incredibly well written characters and a simple yet engrossing story. Inspector Harry Callahan (Clint Eastwood) is a San Francisco police officer who is assigned to track down a serial killer known only as "Scorpio" (Andrew Robinson). Scorpio kills for fun and is a disgusting human being. Harry knows how dangerous he is but his preferred methods of bringing him down get him in trouble with his superiors. Harry eventually gets fed up with his bosses and sets out to arrest Scorpio using his own methods. One of the things that makes this film great are the characters. Harry doesn't really follow the common rules but never fails to get results. Scorpio was based off of the Zodiac killer which is easy to see because he goes all over the place. By that I mean he doesn't really have any one signature weapon, or one type of victim. Most serial killers have one type of person they go after but Scorpio is completely random. The dialog from Harry is pretty funny because he's sarcastic, and a wise guy to his superiors and to pretty much everyone. Overall this is a really good action movie, so I highly recommend it.

reviews.review_title: The First and Most Disturbing of the Dirty Harry Series.
reviews.content: For those of us who lived in the Capital Beltway area during the sniper shootings a few years ago, this movie hit pretty close to home. It's a pretty frightening feeling knowing someone could be watching you and targeting you for a killing for no reason other than they just feel especially mean.Some scenes in this movie are hard to watch. In fact, I won't watch the scene where Scorpio terrorizes a bunch of children on a school bus. (Incidentally, I have lived around natives of Scorpio all my life. Most of them are wonderful people.) I really feel sorry for the actor that played him. This part must have ruined his career. I think someone on this site said he got death threats after playing this role. It's a pity so many people out there can't distinguish make believe from reality. Andy Robinson did a fine job. Scorpio is the most despicable movie villain I have ever seen.This is by no means adverse criticism of this movie. I am a huge fan of Clint Eastwood and of the Dirty Harry series, except for maybe THE DEAD POOL, and I've already commented on that. They really draw you into this movie and tells a riveting story.I think people who say Harry Callahan meted out vigilante justice are totally misreading his character. I have seen this movie many times over the years, and Harry always followed police procedure before shooting anyone. The only times he shot at anyone was (1) if they tried to shoot him first and (2) when a fleeing suspect wouldn't stop after he ordered them to. In most police precincts across the country, an officer can shoot a fleeing suspect if he doesn't stop after being ordered to do so.The scene that really gets my Irish up is when Harry asks the DA who speaks for the murdered Deacon girl. The DA says, "We will, if you will let us." Yeah, right. While we're at it, let's hire Charlie Brown to coach the Washington Redskins. Every thinking person knows that the government has an uncanny knack for screwing up a wet dream.In spite of its disturbing aspects a great movie. 9.5 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Do I feel lucky for watching this movie? Yes! 7/10
reviews.content: Clint Eastwood kicks ass in this film and delivers an unforgettable line. It is a simple story of cops and robbers but the script is written geniusly with a dark tone and a reflection of reality. That reality is though and how the villains get the upper hand on the good guys. But dirty harry isn't a good guy, he is just a man lost in his on world doing whatever he wants simply because he can.

A very well-done film and a must watch for Clint Eastwood fans.Here's my breakdown:STORY:
Cops chasing bad guys is / was old news, but this brings a twist, a "dirty" twist.This film may be where the term "cop with a gun" comes from. Dunno. But if you have a hankering for some real-time,
no fluff justice, then this may be the story for you.This almost has that Eastwood / spaghetti western tone to it.ACTING:
While this has the feel of TV acting, the characters are believable while conforming to some simplistic cliches.ENTERTAINMENT:
This film has average -> good entertainment value IF men speaking through their teeth with big guns appeals to you.Note: yes, there are plenty of boobs for the males.TEMPO:
A steady tempo and diet of chasing, shooting, and an occasional "Do you feel lucky?"CINEMATOGRAPHY:
A great tour of parts of San Francisco and sunny skylinesDIRECTING / WRITING:
Director: Siegel loved two (2) things: TV and Clint Eastwood. Aside from "Harry" I have no interest in his other work.To note, the other films in this series are not near as well-done.Writers: These were TV writers, and I only see one other film among them that I'd recommend - "Starman" (1984).Is it a good film? Yes, if you like Clint Eastwood-ish storiesShould you watch this once? YesRating: 7.8.

reviews.review_title: Big bang of modern action movies
reviews.content: The first film in the Dirty Harry franchise is a classic that was very influential for the development of 70's and 80's action movies. For example Arnold Schwarzenegger has said that Clint Eastwood's performance with his calm yet tough delivery and memorable one-liners was a very important inspiration for him.I also like the sequels because Eastwood's presence is always spectacular. But the original film has also other strong points. It has the most chilling story and the wickedest villain in the whole series. Another memorable thing are the impressive aerial views of San Fransisco rooftops. That's one of the first things that come to mind when thinking about this movie.If you haven't seen this film...you gotta ask yourself one question. Being this is the most powerful cop movie that could thrill your head clean off. Do you dare to watch it. Well, do ya, punk?

reviews.review_title: This movie is never given enough credit.
reviews.content: This is in a sense the cinematic version of The Sweeney in tersm of the public perception of it. People seem to see it as another Bronson-style tough cop movie, yet it is so much more. This attitude is not helped byt he rather cheesy title and the let's face it, pretty dreadful sequels which became caricatures of themselves. Dirty Harry succeeds on every level with what it sets out to achieve. The music is amazing, especially in its exciting percussion and its incorporating of background effects. The camerawork is neat, and the selective use of violence (eg we don't see the dead boy, only Chico's reaction) shows you the care and seriousness put into this film. The football pitch scene is astounding, but for me, the single factor that lifts this movie into legendary status is the astounding performance of Andy Robinson as Scorpio. Cowardly, terrifying, human and yet emotionless, he is devoted to the part for every second and is a true portrait of the serial killer. A resounding scream of defiance to all the liberal attitudes of the sixties, Dirty Harry is a product of modern society, but unlike Death Wish the film doesn't want to stand up and celebrate him, only show how he is a necessary evil.

reviews.review_title: Do You Feel Lucky In Best Of The Best Cop Western
reviews.content: Renegade San Francisco cop dirty harry Callaghan tracks down a brutal serial killer with grit humour and a deadly fire arm. Perhaps this is the one movie i have seen the most often over the years, From the original release through reruns, video DVD and now revivals back in the cinema. A classic like this defies any potent criticism it has Eastwood's career defining role number 2 as is very much a film of it's time.Watching today the none PC attitudes are jarring but the violence has mellowed with time but this is as much a film, in which the city of San Francisco stars every bit as much as Clint Eastwood.As a foot note i expected at the time for Andy Robinson to go on and have a big movie career but somehow it just did not happen for him yet he is quite brilliant as Scorpio the deranged gunman while the dialogue throughout the film remains sharp and terse and instantly quotable.

This film is one that has greater implications than just being a great film to watch. It has a place in film history for a number of reasons. The first is that it is among the best of Eastwood's acting career. The second is that is among the first films where a serial killer is the villain. That would definitely change over the course of the next two decades. It also is one that was made for Richard Nixon's "silent majority" of people who were tired of a lot of the counter-culture society was experienced. Some have called the film racist. Others have called it fascist. I don't see those things in the film-not to say you might not see them in characters in the film, but not the film itself. Andrew Robinson is great as the villain. This is one that has changed over time but is actually still worth watching.

Don Siegel's collaborations with Clint Eastwood have always been resulted in interesting movies, but 'Dirty Harry' may be the apex of their teaming up! Siegel and Eastwood push the thriller genre a bit further in this movie with a fresh new type of character in cinema - the radical tough cop who fights the inconsistencies of the Law to achieve justice - and a frightening new attitude to the villain: Scorpio is just about one of the creepiest, most sadistic and brutal villains in cinema: he goes from killing innocent children to inflicting pain on himself to have his sick way; Scorpio is hardly a cartoonish villain as you'd find in a ridiculous movie like 'The Punisher.' 'Dirty Harry' is also a well-paced story with lots of thrills, twists and gripping moments: Scorpio sending Harry Callahan run all over town to see if he's bugged, his brutally spanking him, the chilling sequence at the stadium where Harry shows just how much he wants justice, and the final action sequence at the school bus, make sure this movie is never boring! Sure, Harry, Scorpio and all the other supporting characters aren't particularly developed, nor will anyone find anything new about the human condition in this thriller. If anything, the movie is a treatise on attitude and how to live in an insane society with strange laws that let criminals go free; it emanates a lot of pessimism for society and lack of trust in authority figures, and shows how those who just want to serve good may in the end have to break the law for it. No doubt, this is really a product of the spirit of the '70's, and yet the frustrations Harry feels remain completely fresh today for anyone to relate to.

Okay, this is one of those movies that everyone "has" to see, according to my family. Alright, I saw it yesterday. And...I didn't like it very much. I have grown up with different movies which use the same plot structure and settings. I was most offended by the nudity in the film. If you have kids, and you're like me, keep them away from this one. Mom saw it in the theater (when she was pregnant with me! Now I've dated myself) and didn't recall the nudity at all. Well, I sure do now. If you have seen any movies with "rogue" cops who do things their way, this is the mother of all those movies. If you can handle the fact that it seems cliché NOW, after so many movies have followed in its footsteps, then go for it. Just beware the content is more of NC-17 than R.

Dirty Harry is the grandfather of the modern renegade-cop flick, such as Lethal Weapon, Beverly Hills Cop, Bad Boys, and countless others.However, its age shows and it lacks some of the refinement of modern cop flicks.  First off, let's be clear what Dirty Harry is: despite Callahan's title, this is not a detective movie.  Rather this is a pure, unadulterated cop flick, and plotwise a rather generic one.  There is very little actual detective work and there is no whodunnit subplot.  There is a bit of one-on-one, cat-and-mouse intercourse between the cop and the crook, but unlike say Insomnia, Seven, or Eastwood's own In the Line of Fire, Scorpio is by no means a sophisticated mastermind.Rather, he is a generic, carefree blend of society's worst stereotypes: thief, rapist, killer, kidnapper, pedophile, conman, racist...you name it. Because Scorpio is such an obviously awful person and because he's able to so easily exploit the system, the movie comes off as a bit one-sided politically.  At times the movie seem superficial to the modern viewer; some of the trimmed fat might even be construed as outright plot holes.  For example, it seems silly that the DA and the judge need to lecture Harry as if he'd never heard of the Bill of Rights.  How would someone rise to Inspector without at least a basic understanding of the legal system?Nevertheless, Dirty Harry is high on style and a must-see for any fan of the genre.  It's a back-to-basics movie on how to characterize and develop a cop lead.  And of course, it has Harry's immortal speech.  The action is okay too for its time, and its impressive that Eastwood did all his own stunts. All in all I give it an imdb 7.

Whether it's the hard cop, psychologically-thrilling villain or unscrupulous police department, it's clear Scorpio is menacing San Francisco. Whether it's midday shootings or midnight terrors, it's a city's worst nightmare and one that will not cease.Clint Eastwood flourishes in his role as Harry, who's as dirty and stone cold as they come. The world is the limit for him, but he is conflicted with his duties and moral obligations. With a killing spree capturing the innocent lives of Californians, Harry goes to incredible extents to track and take down an elusive criminal. It's an uphill battle, though, as it appears both the criminals and department have no respect for the spirit of the law. Dirty Harry shies away from being a cliché crime movie as it displays a multidimensional killer; one that is knowledgeable and cunning--necessary qualities to deceive the whole public. It's thrilling throughout and the upbeat tempo ensures there's never a dull moment. I was quite surprised with this movie. I've always been a fan of Eastwood's films and this is no different. With great acting across the board and an even better storyline to match, Dirty Harry will surely entertain.

reviews.review_title: Hott to trot t on harry's butt and tell him he sucks
reviews.content: OH MY GOD. I was let down, down down down to Chinatown and fisherman's wharf too. Good god what a crap movie. huh. YES a lot of movies have a political thrust which oftentimes can be very offensive to some viewers, while egging others on. But I looked at the date, and it was 1971--so, if Sweet Sweetback's Baaaaaaaaaaaddddddddassssssssss Song had come out, it was very recently, and it only played in 2 theaters in the nation at first anyway. . . so I guess it's safe to assume this movie wasn't a response to blaxploitation (a genre in which cops are generally looked down upon. But Le's' just examine that for a minuet, shall we? Who was looked down upon in "Dirty Harry"? Ineffectual cops, the overly liberal SF justice system, the pussy mayor--so surprisingly emf, I guess there are some bizarre similarities between Harry and Coffy. Each is a "wildly" independent character reacting against an ineffectual legal system. Maybe today it just smarts to see the law portrayed as not-tough-enough when people get arrested for being black/poor/breathing wrong all the goddamn time. What a world. I give the movie 10 stars because I'd rather have to walk barefoot on 10 stars in outer space than watch Droopy Hairy again. Jeah.

reviews.review_title: A perfectly timed film, for an audience who was fed up.
reviews.content:
I just rewatched DIRTY HARRY for the umpteenth time. Still great. Since it is now 2020, here's a more recent take on it.
This movie was a result of the sixties. And yes, I was there. It's rather relevant today too, with all the rioting taking place but - we will, unfortunately, never see another Dirty Harry. Too truthful and therefore too 'triggering'. Our current establishment has gotten much too mamby-pamby for that.
Death Wish was another well-timed flick, for the same reason. Violence running over in the city and politicians and bureaucrats too afraid to do anything about it. Yep, that's 'Dirty Harry'. So, Harry does what needs to be done. He is what 'most' members of the audience, in 1971, wanted to see. Well placed and deserved ACTION. A comeuppance. The movie even plays upon the pathetic-ness of our courts by allowing Scorpio to 'walk' due to some ridiculous LEGAL technicality - AFTER he tells them where to find the dead girl. Our justice system. No different today. No justice for the law-abiding. But again people, in 1971, were fed up.
It's a satisfying film too in that the psycho gets it in the end. Way too many more modern films twist their ending. Since movies, to me, are supposed to be escapism, having a satisfying ending is important and having just invested two hours of my life into a film, I demand it. So, if the powers-that-be decide to 'subvert my expectations? Well, ... I will probably NEVER watch it again and will no doubt, share my displeasure with others. That is of course, THEIR choice. Mine, too. They need be prepared, though, for a rather dismal after-market for streaming and DVD sales cause I, at least, won't be buying it.
Give it a watch, while you can, if you like well-placed action and mild violence. When compared to today? Yes, it's mild.

reviews.review_title: A great introduction about an inspector
reviews.content: ACTIONThis is the fourth of five movies director Don Siegel made with Clint Eastwood and the first of 5 movies the Dirty Harry character had been used. The set up is reminiscent of the movie called "Targets" which serves as a backdrop to Harry's persona. That has psychotic sniper calling himself Scorpio (Andrew Robinson) killing his first potential victim before he blackmails the city of San Francisco for large sums of money. Until Inspector Harry Callahan was chosen to handle the case who of course, butt heads with his chief before he butt heads with the mayor. This is a fine introduction to an indifferent inspector one is not accustomed to seeing who refuse to always follow the rules. And he will bend them to his advantage on whatever case he's assigned for it's sort of like a Steve McQueen's "Bullitt" but not really. A different type of hero started by Don Siegel, played by Clint Eastwood which the role was first offered to John Wayne.

reviews.review_title: An iconic legend is born and makes cinematic history.
reviews.content: Dirty Harry makes cinematic history by introducing audiences to SFPD Homicide Inspector Harry Callahan played by Clint Eastwood. Inspector Harry Callahan is someone who is not afraid to bend the rules and overstep the line to bring criminals to justice, in some cases stopping them cold in their tracks with his Smith & Wesson Model 29 .44 Magnum revolver handgun. Along the way Inspector Callahan defies incompetent superiors to get the job done. Since Dirty Harry blasted its way onto cinemas in 1971, Harry Callahan has since became a template for a new breed of cop audiences have come to love. An antihero who is not afraid to cross professional and ethical boundaries in their fearless pursuit of their own vision of justice, especially when the law is poorly served by an inept bureaucracy and hampered by red tape. The main character finds themselves frequently reprimanded, suspended or even dismissed by superiors for their renegade actions. Dirty Harry was criticized by some critics who considered the movie to be fascist and sparked many debates about police brutality, however the film resonated with an American public that had become frustrated with increasing violent crime rates that was characteristic of the time. Dirty Harry was also a critical and commercial success, and to this day is considered to be a classic movie as well as one of Clint Eastwood's best movies.Clint Eastwood introduces us to Inspector Harry Callahan, an unorthodox homicide detective who is fearless in his pursuit of bringing criminals to justice but is willing to bend the rules and police procedure when necessary. He often butts heads with his superiors and his partners often end up wounded or killed in the line of duty. We get to see Inspector Callahan in action when he foils a bank robbery in downtown San Francisco while he is having lunch, killing two bank robbers and wounding a third. When the wounded robber reaches for his shotgun, Callahan challenges him by introducing us to the immortal line, "I know what you're thinking: 'Did he fire six shots or only five?' Well, to tell you the truth, in all this excitement, I've kinda lost track myself. But being this is a .44 Magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world, and would blow your head clean off, you've got to ask yourself one question: 'Do I feel lucky?' Well, do ya, punk?" The robber wisely surrenders but tries his luck again by asking Callahan is he had one round left or if the gun was empty.Inspector Callahan has been assigned a new partner, the fresh faced Chico Gonzales (Reni Santoni) against Callahan's wishes to which Lieutenant Bressler (Harry Guardino) tells him that the order is final. Inspectors Callahan and Gonzales are tasked to take down a madman sniper calling himself Scorpio (Andrew Robinson) who has been terrorising San Francisco by killing innocent citizens with a sniper rifle and making ransom demands. The cat and mouse game takes a dangerous turn when Scorpio kidnaps a teenage girl and buries her alive along with a larger ransom demand. Inspector Callahan must stop Scorpio's reign of terror, even if it means throwing police procedure and rules out the window.Clint Eastwood previously made his mark in Westerns such as the TV show Rawhide and the classic The Good, The Bad and The Ugly (1968). In 1971, he reaches a turning point in his career with Dirty Harry, as well as being cast in further roles as a police officer. Clint Eastwood gives his take on Harry Callahan as an urban cowboy fearless and relentless in his pursuit of justice. Considering that the role of Harry Callahan perfectly fits like a glove for Clint Eastwood, it's hard to believe that many actors were considered for the role including John Wayne, Frank Sinatra, Robert Mitchum, Burt Lancaster, Steve McQueen and Paul Newman.Dirty Harry works perfectly as a hard boiled crime movie. There's no car chases, explosions, minimal action sequences, and thankfully no romantic scenes. The movie is tightly wound with no nonsense direction from Don Siegel.Dirty Harry spawned a further four sequels as well as leading the way in popular culture. Without Dirty Harry, there would be no Axel Foley from Beverly Hills Cop, no Marion Coberetti from Cobra, no Martin Riggs from Lethal Weapon, no John McClane from Die Hard, and actors such as Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sylvester Stallone, Bruce Willis, Wesley Snipes, Steven Seagal, and Jean Claude Van Damme feature similar characters that were strongly influenced by Clint Eastwood's Harry Callahan. There have even been TV Shows that have been inspired by Dirty Harry. 80's cop show Hunter with Fred Dryer as LAPD Detective Rick Hunter was inspired by Dirty Harry. 80's cop comedy Sledge Hammer! with David Rasche in the titular role is a parody of Dirty Harry. And in recent times, Kiefer Sutherland's Jack Bauer from 24 introduced modern day TV audiences to a more ruthless version of Harry Callahan, who is not hindered by rules and the law in his pursuit of terrorists, sometimes even torturing and murdering suspects.Dirty Harry lives on as an iconic movie, and Clint Eastwood's loose-cannon and trigger happy Inspector Harry Callahan remains as an iconic character in cinema history.9/10.

reviews.review_title: Benchmark for cop thrillers of the seventies.
reviews.content: Clint Eastwood is one of the very few actors who can be regarded as the one who is the epitome of numerous genre's. He first made his mark in Spaghetti western's playing characters who were enigmatic loners with a haunting past which is barely revealed, but was his motivating factor for dealing harshly with outlaws who preyed on the defenseless. The 'Man with no name' had little to say - he did it all with handguns used with deadly precision and his icy coolness unsettled his opponents. Eastwood has definitely surpassed John Wayne as the cowboy people most remember when westerns are mentioned. Then fortuitously he landed the role of 'Dirty Harry' after Frank Sinatra was forced to drop out. Although the man who 'did it my way' was a shrewd choice for the lead role, one doubts whether he could have claimed the character as his own the way Eastwood did. Now Eastwood defined another genre - the action genre.Harry Callahan is a man who believes in his heavy handed brand of justice. A tragic past drives him - his wive's death at the hand of a drunk driver - and once again Eastwood is the lone gunman defending the weak. He cuts out his individuality in the police force with his long hair and big gun. The gun is his means to rid the streets of those who harm others. He has no regard for 'outlaws' who operate outside of society's morals and will taunt them with sarcastic remarks. His taunts took on a more serious tone at the climax when he challenged Scorpio to go for his gun. We are in no doubt that he hates this man and that he wants to clear the streets of him permanately. Harry's flaws are also outside of what is acceptable and proper. His drive to deal with the bad guys endangers others and he has little time for inexperienced partners who may get in the way of his own brand of justice. But the audience forgives him for these flaws as he vigilante style rids society of it's menace. His one - liners are not frivolous and create tension as he challenges the bad guys. Harry thus exudes immense power since his is doing what others wish they could do. He becomes the hero of those who may be disheartened with the system and deals out just rewards. Harry is frustrated by 'gutless' superiors who he regards are the ones who are putting society at risk. They regard him as a loose cannon, but serves a use when it comes to dangerous jobs. In the end he gives up on the system and walks away from it. Thus Harry is the 'man with no name' in the 70's. We can see that Eastwood found the transition very natural.Scorpio is ultimate example of scum to Harry. He will harm anyone who gets in his way and kills to gain a sense of power. Money is not the compelling factor in his deadly game, but the power to challenge authority and take lives. He even pays for a severe beating so that he could frame Harry. Undoubtably he wants to make society pay for his misfortunes. The fact that no motivating factors are revealed makes him seem more cold - blooded and psychotic. His maniacal laughs and twisted expressions create a man who is separate from us and only exists for one thing - to kill. Andy Robinson's contribution to making this movie the benchmark that it became, must almost sit beside that of Eastwood's. He creates a character that seems so inheritly evil, Dirty Harry became Clean Harry after killing him. Performances like this were lacking in the sequel, although that is not the only reason they pale by comparison.Although Harry will be incomparable to the police of that time, the movie starts off with a tribute to them. They get away with it since Eastwood makes Harry the cop the audience wants to see. Of note here is the fact that some police departments produced training videos showing scenes from 'Dirty Harry' and using them as an example of 'how not to it'. This, as proven by the numerous sequels, was never to prove a deterrant for audience's as Harry blasted his '44 across our screens. He was also to influence action heroes of the future, most notably Arnold Schwarznegger.To have not watched this movie, is to have missed a genre defining one. Not only did Eastwood claim title to another unforgettable character, action thrillers were influenced by him. His one - liners are a huge part of our action heroes of today. The anti - hero (Harry), although not started by this movie, become the benchmark against which audiences were to measure others. It may seem dated, but complex characters and great acting will always provide entertainment through the generations.

I finally saw the original Dirty Harry a couple of months ago when it was broadcasted on TV over here.  I thought it was a cool film.  It had plenty of violence, cool dialogue and plenty of bad 1970`s-haircuts. Dirty Harry is a cop who must track down a serial-killer, and he is not afraid of playing dirty when he has to.  This is an original cop-movie, and an enjoyable cult-actionmovie. 8/10

Extremely entertaining "Dirty Harry" is a very manipulative movie which leads us to cheer on a vigilante cop who's virtually breaking the law to bring in his murderer.Since Andy Robinson's portrayal doesn't reveal anything but an evil human being, it's so easy to side with Eastwood's vigilante cop. Especially when we know that the letter of the law in many cases protect the criminals more than their victims. Richard Donner must have been a fan of this film since there are so many similarities to "Lethal Weapon" which he made 16 years later. Clint Eastwood's "Harry Callaghan" and Mel Gibson's "Martin Riggs" could almost be the same guy.Clint Eastwood is magnificent in his part revealing the person underneath Harry's tough exterior.A great action-flick if you don't mind the politics.

reviews.review_title: You just don't see movies like this anymore.
reviews.content: I can honestly say, this is one of my favorite movies of all time. It's quite simple from a plot-perspective point of view. But the acting and script is just spot on. You really get into the movie and root for Harry to catch the killer.It seems as if the script was written for Clint Eastwood. His acting made Dirty Harry truly come to life. The actor who played the killer was also fantastic, he played the role of a more twisted version of Alex DeLarge from "A Clockwork Orange"The director managed to capture the essence of what San Francisco was all about in the early 70's.You just don't see movies like this anymore.

Just like his Westerns and Spagetti Western's Dirty Harry is one of his classic movies, Dirty Harry has witty dialogue, a cool catchphrase, the most powerful handgun in the world and a interesting plot. The acting is great, Clint Eastwood's performance has Dirty Harry is fantastic, he's performance inspired many other tough cops like John McClane in Die Hard and Martin Riggs in Lethal Weapon, Andrew Robinson is great as the Scorpio Killer, he makes the character look so normal yet he's so insane especially on the school bus. Dirty Harry has a classic 70's music score that goes with the pace, the sound effect for Harry's gun is cool and makes it sound like the most powerful handgun in the world.Dirty Harry is a classic 70's cop movie that stars the iconic Clint Eastwood, this is one film that shouldn't be missed. 10/10

reviews.review_title: One of his greatest early "middle period" movies and arguably his best movie.
reviews.content:
Clint has starred in and directed some wonderful stuff and this is a particularly good example and justifiably famous. It has so many stand-out moments of drama and wit and irony. He
plays such a fantastically defined character, that in one way or another it shaped the rest of his career. Like some fine musicians that have distinctive styles, we have glimpses of most everything
at least in earlier form, of his trademark stylistic craftsmanship acting. The humor, the sneer, the gunslinger, the sense of irony, his most famous lines, and probably the best example of his
delighted grin when "the punk" just "gots to know" if this is his lucky day or not. I suppose if anything is more or less left out or merely implied, it's the tenderness
that he reluctantly trots out in his later work like million dollar baby, which wasn't so much reluctant as delayed, or grand torino.Anyway in a career as truly splendid as his, where as a director/star his work seems to get better all the time, this movie, for me anyway, was a milestone, and 50 years later has not been surpassed.Predating taxi driver, I'm not sure that movie would have come into existence without this preceding it. Andy Robinson puts in a howling performance in his semi fictionalized version of the actual
zodiac killer. Set in early 70's San Francisco, at a time when a person could still afford to live in that beautiful city, as I did just a few years later, it's also a great period piece for the town, as movies
like James Caan's 'Thief" depict so much of older Chicago, my main home, which digitalization ruined utterly years ago, as it has to the whole planet.

reviews.review_title: Now I see why he's "Dirty Harry"...
reviews.content: Dirty Harry is undoubtedly one of Clint Eastwood's more famous roles throughout his career.Usually these "rogue cop" movies are thin-plotted and redundant, but Dirty Harry was different.The plot however is simple. A killer called The Scorpio Killer (undoubtedly molded after "The Zodiac Killer") is loose on the streets and its up to rogue cop Dirty Harry to stop him by any means necessary.Clint Eastwood was perfect to play Dirty Harry Callahan, the rogue detective who is "turned loose" on the streets to find the Scorpio Killer (played by Andrew Robinson).Eastwood knows how to make a good role even better. He delivers his lines with such coolness (yes that is now a word) that you would doubt anyone else could play the part.10/10.

reviews.review_title: The grandaddy of all renegade cop flicks.
reviews.content: Often imitated and sometimes successfully duplicated, "DirtyHarry" is the movie that spawned all those cop films where theheroes break the rules in order to enforce them. Sure, "Bullit"back in 1968 was a film about an unorthodox cop that was earliermade than "Dirty Harry," but of course, "Dirty Harry" is farmore popular. Clint Eastwood plays his most famous role ever as HarryCallahan, a tough San Francisco cop nicknamed "Dirty" because ofhis nasty and uncompromising approach to law-breaking scum.Harry is assigned to nab a psycho killer named Scorpio, playedwith evil sleaze by Andrew Robinson. Scorpio manages to outfoxHarry during a mad chase, but Harry soon gets the upper hand anddeals justice through the barrel of his huge .44 magnum.The raw violence found in this film must have first shocked bothcritics and audiences alike because bloody violence in movieswas fairly new and unheard of back in the early 1970's. But withEastwood's gritty, stone-cold performance won the love of manyaction fans worldwide soon enough. With several sequels tofollow, "Dirty Harry" is one of the most beloved actio

reviews.review_title: THE no nonsense zero tolerance cop thriller
reviews.content: One of the most charismatic movies ever made. It's infuriated liberals ever since it premiered but that was one of its intentions. Well done for it, and it was partly inspired by factual cases where killers had their charges dropped after lawyers argued the accuseds' abuse and violation of legal rights by police. Eastwood plays a homicide inspector who is so sick of the legal system being played by defence lawyers he has decided to be judge himself, meaning trouble for any murderer he's chasing.What's surprised me reading about the making of it is how many big name star actors were approached for the role of Dirty Harry and turned it down in apparent disgust at the character and the tone of the film. Newman I could understand but not some of the others - Lee Marvin! Step up Clint Eastwood and walk into movie super stardom! And there isn't anyone who'd've done a better job of it. Wayne maybe in his day but his day had gone to do it credibly.Eastwood played the zero tolerance cop with relish and conviction and no shortage of style. From the half eaten hot dog to the pistol pointing wise cracking ending, the first shoot out scene, so blunt and direct and full of charisma delivered a picture into movie folk lore. Relentless from then on with really hard hitting scenes for 71, this would cause a stir in the movie industry after audiences loved it and wanted more. They got a lot more and not just from Dirty Harry, as there were many imitators after this iconic (sorry couldn't avoid it) movie.Eastwood was supremely charismatic and super cool in his portrayal, giving us one of the most memorable and quotable movie characters ever. But a special mention must go to Andy Robinson as the really disturbing killer who has nearly as much screen time as Eastwood and goes to town on his nutcase compulsive murderer, Scorpio. You'd probably question the Mayor not insisting Harry Callahan be taken off the case, considering he wanted to pay off Scorpio from the start but it's clear even Harry's superiors have more than an sneaky admiration for his no nonsense methods.Dirty Harry, the movie is a hard slapping crime thriller that still serves as an antidote to legal weakness and injustice and political correctness. I've watched it countless times and it just seems to get stronger with every passing decade. The film packs a punch on many levels, not least pure entertainment and should be on any serious top 250 list. The fact it isn't on this one is down to the same true villains of the movie, liberals.

This film came out in 1971, I didn't see it until it was on TV. I remember this was one of the best Dirty Harry films, too me they are all good; but the one is awesome. The opening scene you have a sniper on a roof top aiming at a woman in this roof top pool across the street. He shoots her in the back and we know this guy is a few short of a six-pack from the beginning of the film. He sends a letter to the San Francisco P.D. claiming that if they do not cooperate his next victim will be a Priest or an African American. He calls himself Scorpio and this guy loves to kill, a real sicko; and it's up to Dirty Harry and his new partner, Chico Gonsalaz to stop this sicko. A lone gunman who targets innocent people for the thrill of it, it's a movie that will make you cringe in away, especially now that violence is more prominent. It's a movie that makes you think how can unstable people like this obtain a firearm. I am not against firearms; but our gun laws need to be revised and stricter. Too much has happened lately, especially with teenagers, that could have been prevented if the gun laws were harsher. Kris L. CocKayne

An old classic, a film that inspired cop films in its time and films I very much enjoy even though they are quite fascist underneath it all. Dirty Harry Callahan delivers his own version of justice and when someone known as the scorpio killer starts randomly people for a ransom Harry deals with it his way even if it angers his superiors. Dated but still fun and a must watch for those into action or even just Clint Eastwoods catelogue of films.

To watch this film now is to take a peek back at a time when we weren't so conservative, or P.C, or concerned with things like 'racial stereotypes'. It's a breath of fresh air. Hugely influential, this film hasn't aged one bit. The music is distinctly 70's, yes, but it's very good. Easily the best film in the Dirty Harry series - the follow up suffered from very weak, 2 dimensional bad-guys and the progressively more boring sub-plot of Callaghan's continual clashing with his superiors. Detective Inspector Callaghan is a flawed man - a xenophobe, a voyeur and prone to going with his gut rather than obeying the rules. However, he was the first in a long line of flawed cop characters to be brought to life on the cinema screen so his character should be looked upon as a seminal touchstone in popular film culture. Mel Gibson's 'Martin Riggs' from the first Lethal Weapon film is a similar character, and probably the best successor to Callaghan, and it's interesting to note that the rooftop jumper scene in the first 'Lethal Weapon' owes much to the similar scene in 'Dirty Harry'. Of course, one of the reasons that this film is so great is because of the infectious malevolence of the villain 'Scorpio', played to the hilt, and then some, by Andy Robinson. All of the villains that followed in the Dirty Harry series paled by comparison and that's probably one of the big reasons why this is the best film in the series. A great film that stands the test of time.

Dirty Harry is one of the most iconic role of Clint Easthood and in film in general and a far as police movies go is one of the oldest and the best even though it is at the time of that review forty five years old! Here I won't spoil the movie, for you have to see it, because it rocks hard and the action is even harder rather I will write down the significance of Dirty Harry for the film industry and then a focus to the genres in which the impact was more apparent. And here we go!Firstly the movie is a bit like a western, logical for Clint before he became a hardcore cop he was one of the most bad ass cowboys in movie history. So from letting that type of character die out along with the westerns they adapt it into the modern (seventies) age. Keep in mind that this is the early seventies and back then the anti-war movement against the Vietnam War was at its peak, the crime rate was increasing at an alarming speed and the audience need for blood in general was at an all time low. In short a movie, which made a violent policeman a hero, should had been shoot from the sky. But why that didn't happened?Firstly Harry Kallachan (yes I know his surname) and his unorthodox and cynical attitude mirrored the view of many people back then for the government which seemed unable to do protect them from crime and domestic abuse, despite the strong outraged by Peace promoting and Feminist organizations at the time, for its raw character and as they said fascist behavior against the law and the rights of a person. Also in my point of view that backlash may help the film to make almost nine times its budget of 4 million dollars, for least be real when you here when you her so much hate for some piece of art ,then you are going to see it in order to determine yourself how good or bad it is. The same happen with Batman v Superman, X-men Apocalypse and all the Transfomer movies!Now to the two focus parts: 1. The crime fighting in movies. Before Dirty Harry the crime movies were,for the most part, tales of good versus evil with a little gun- fight in order to remind the audience that they aren't watching a kids film. After it and its brothers of the French Connection (the original of 1971) ,a Clockwork Orange and of course The Godfather opened the crime depiction to more Grey areas were the protagonist lacks some characteristics of the hero types, in short he becomes an antihero and the villain has values that makes you like him! 2.Vigilante justice. Now that is also the most important influence in my view because a man taking justice to its own hands what completely out of question up to that point, with the hippy movement and what we said before. But after its success many more people went to give their take to the way of vigilante. What we got was films like The Taxi Driver, Death Wish and if you go farther in time you get the Batman films series,2012 Dredd The Crow,the films of Kill Bill, V for Vendeta and the awesome television crime series of Daredevil ,Arrow and Jessica Jones. To put it simple no Dirty Harry, no vigilante movies and no superhero films and series for what are these people but judge, juries and executioners?This my take to the legacy of officer Callahan actions and impact to popular culture ,I hope that this analyses will make you watch it and then spread the word.

9.2A lot of people don't like police officers. They see them as men and women who are abusing power. It is easy, in their eyes, to become a police officer and gain authority. While I agree that there are certainly a great number of police officers (and military men) who fall under this stereotype, there is still the fact that when things get shaky, the first person you want to see is a police officer.The character Dirty Harry, the protagonist in the film, is a very cliché character. In your fantasy, if you were a cop, would you be something like Dirty Harry? You most likely would. He's a man of action, he get's the job done, no matter how dirty it is. He keeps his top on, until it's time for it to come off. Dirty Harry doesn't say much, but he's got a lot to say. The tensity of the two scenes where he spouts his very famous line produces the highlights of the film. Dirty Harry is wild, but he has style. And boy, does it come off with style. That's one thing that the film has going for it, style. From the surprising use of natural colors, such as the blue sky against yellow text and the greys of San Francisco, to the soundtrack, with the hip music that plays once the villain is about to make an appearance. San Francisco feels alive, and the film made me want to go visit the city.As interesting as Dirty Harry is as a character, as well as the crazed villain, the film trades realism and humility for Hollywoodized fantasy. Dirty Harry is the cop that people who aren't cops want to be. He's not afraid to break the law to capture the criminals. The villain, Scorpio, is the criminal that people who aren't criminals would like to be. He exhibits insanity (but doesn't lack intelligence and craft), appears to do wicked things with absolutely no motive, and manages to keep the hero on his toes.But movies aren't supposed to be realistic. They are well off being the fantastical exaggerations of society that they are. In that sense, Dirty Harry is perfect. It's got good performances, incredible amounts of style, and very powerful scenes. From the first scene to the very last, the film will surprise you with its lack of mediocrity. There's just one thing that I still want to know. Was it ketchup, or was it blood? Dirty Harry is the quintessential crime film. Don't cop out, watch this classic.

The first Dirty Harry, directed by Don Siegel, is a legendary film.It succeeds by transferring the Clint Eastwood of the 1960s Spaghetti Westerns to an urban milieu, where the lawlessness is even greater and the requirements for a lawmaker with the willingness to wield the Magnum 45 at "high noon" as it were, all judges, magistrates, police chiefs, rules and laws to the contrary.The rebellious aspect of "Dirty Harry" both identifies with the Zeitgeist of the Seventies, as well as grasping at the Nixonian "Silent Majority" who feel overwhelmed by too much liberalism in the press, the media and the courts.It remains a controversial film, but a superb one.A final note is a excellent jazz scoring; every Eastwood film has a fine jazz score.Legendary, and unforgettable.

reviews.review_title: Detective Harry Callahan you don't assign him to cases you just turn him loose.
reviews.content: Dirty Harry is the prototype for a lot of the Cop flicks that surfaced after this one made it's debut. Dirty Harry was condemned for the violence and the attitude of Harry towards the criminals. The movie was not intended to glorify violence but rather to present it in a horrifying light. The story is simple: A crazed sniper named Scorpio is on the loose he just killed a young girl in a pool atop of a hotel. He sends a Note to the city demanding one million dollars or he will kill a priest or a black person. When the city does not comply he kills a black youth. And kidnaps a young girl. The Cop in charge of this Case is inspecter Harry Callahan partnered with a rookie cop named Gonzales despite his protests (Things happen to my partners he informs him) Harry agree to make the ransom drop and what follows is one of the most psychological and physical moments on the screen as Scorpio literally has Harry run all over San Francisco until He is satisfied that Harry is tired and cannot fight back. When they meet Scorpi taunts Harry intending to kill him and then he tells him He changes his mind the girl Dies. Harry and Scorpio fight and Gonzales Saves Harry .Harry then proceeds to beat and torture Scorpio for information to where the girl is. He invalidates his case and finds the girl's body. What follows is Harry pursuing the killer determined to stop him even as the city warns him to back off. Even when Scorpio tries to frame Harry for beating him a move which fails and sets up the climax in which both men finally face each other and Harry finally dispenses justice. The movie is not about Harry's methods but rather the failings of the system in which the killer's rights are more important then the victims. Dirty Harry comes across as a noble knight in a savage land on some crusade why he's on this crusade is never explained nor is it pointed at said he's on one but you can tell by his actions. This movie is perhaps one of the greatest high points of the 70's and it actually is a classic that deserves it's place in history. It's dated in some places but ahead of it's time in others.

reviews.review_title: Still one of the great movies if all time!
reviews.content: I've seen this many,many times and still love every minute of it. I'd say one of Clint Eastwood's finest movies and the beginning of a new screen hero and the many great sequels! Sit and enjoy this movie and you'll see why he's a great movie star.

Dirty Harry is the first and easily the best in the series of "Harry" movies. It has been analyzed, dissected, reassembled, then analyzed again. Lots of social commentators had huge concerns about "loveable" Harry. They claimed he was glorifying violence--he was acting like a fascist !!, he was making violence fashionable & hip. They were not amused by his fun line "do you feel lucky ?--well do you --punk ?" They claimed Harry was having too much fun toying with his adversaries. Well, all of that may be true, but it still remains a hell of a good movie. Harry Callahan the San Fransico cop who hates people who break the law. And ..real baddies ?? he cant stand them. When a mad bad person (played by Andy Robinson) starts killing people and asking for a ransom, (after he kidnaps a young girl) Harry becomes mad. I mean real mad dog mad. His methods do not amuse City Hall, but Harry cannot be stopped. He knows this type of man needs to be terminated-----for good. This is a very good movie...as Harry would say "you have to ask yourself one question, do you feel lucky ?" If you do--watch this movie. (The music by Lalo Schifrin is excellent).
Clint Eastwood's Dirty harry is an amazing movie. By far the most realistic and the darkest one. I will make sure to rewatch it whenever I can.

Dirty Harry you s just an all time classic thriller and character. I love his character. He does what he has to do to get the bad guy. Speaking of bad guys Scorpio is genuinely one of the best. So convincing, so scary. What an amazing performance from the actor. The sound track rocks as does the cinematography. Set in the 70s but just has not really dated as it is such a good movie. Yes the fashion and music are 70s through and through but the plot and performances are immense and that is the overriding thing that makes it still relevant. If they tried to do it now it would be so PC, probably full of martial arts or something and just would not cut it. Great cinema.
One of the best 70s movie. The plot and characters are the awesome. I watched 20 times and it's not boring at all.

_Dirty Harry_, along with _Death Wish_, is arguably the genesis of the modern vigilante/rough justice film which took up where the western took off.  The quest for vengeance continued on a new frontier - one of concrete and asphalt.In terms of images, emotions, gut reactions, _Dirty Harry_ is immensely powerful.  However, the morality and philosophy underpinning it is a hopeless muddle.  It's unusual that I lay the blame for anything at the feet of a film, but this movie, and the myriad imitations that have followed, have lodged vigilante morality deeply within popular culture, forming the basis for some very bad politics.It's not a bad flick for what it is, but it pays to view _Dirty Harry_ with a critical mind.

reviews.review_title: The first of a superb run of "Dirty Harrys."
reviews.content: Frank Sinatra, John Wayne and Paul Newman were first choices for the role of Harry. Sinatra and Wayne were simply too old for the role and Newman was too slight and wouldn't have have portrayed the stoicism that Clint did. The role of Scorpio was supposed to be played by AUDIE MURPHY! Why not Woody Allen? Who made the above choices?Aside from those comments DIRTY HARRY was a magnificent blockbuster! It's what people want to see. They've had enough of the insanity spoken by the judge in the film.I want to congratulate the writers, Don Siegle the director, and all connected with this cinematic triumph. If anyone should have received an award, or at least a nomination, for best supporting actor it was Andy Robinson for his Scorpio. It was the most realistic playing of a psycho only equaled by Jessica Walter in "Play Misty for Me" also starring Eastwood. The only fault I find is Harry throwing his badge away at the end. Absolutely no reason for that. All the sequels prove this was one of the most appealing films.

The 1970's were the decade for American cop movies, not to mention the TV police detective shows that seemed to be being churned out with such regularity throughout the decade.It clearly was a genre defining period in big screen and small screen entertainment. So much so that by the end of the 1970's vertically every veteran actor or upcoming newbie had all rolled their dice in the game at least once, some with more success than others.The film that really started the ball rolling though was 'Dirty Harry' made right at the beginning of the decade in 1971.Cop/detective films were nothing new of course, they had been making them way back in the 30's and the film noir vogue of the late 1940's gave us the model for the hard boiled 'Private eye' or dishevelled police Lieutenant.However, although back in the day these films were considered 'gritty' they were still heavily sanitised by the Hays office. It wasn't until movie censorship was well and truly consigned to history that true realism could be brought in and the lines between good and evil could be blurred into total ambiguity.We are fortunate therefore that by the late 1960's actors like Clint Eastwood and Director Don Siegel were free to not only bring such stories and portrayals to the screen but do so better than anybody else could.Eastwood and Siegel started their collaborations a few years before in 1968 with the film Coogans Bluff, a film where the good cop was literally a modern day cowboy who was a tough and merciless as the bad guys themselves.The character of Coogan must have stayed within the psyche of both Eastwood and Siegel however as the character of 'Dirty' Harry Callaghan bears more than just a passing resemblance and they found the perfect vehicle in which to resurrect him.By 1971 the social situation in America had digressed to the point where victims rights were being overlooked because, murderers, rapists, drug dealers and kidnappers who were also human beings also had rights that were considered just as important.Many high profile cases had seen criminals acquitted to reoffend, all because their 'rights' were violated through some bureaucratic technicality and people were quite rightly getting angrier.Dirty Harry sets out to redress the balance. As in Coogans Bluff, Eastwood plays a cop who is more akin to a western lawman than anything suited to contemporary San Francisco.He wants results and cares more about getting the job done rather than how it is achieved. You step out of line around Harry you're just going to end up dead punk!The plot involves a psychotic serial killer, blackmailing the city, and leaving a trail of bodies in his wake. The city want to cooperate with his demands to stop more people getting killed, Harry wants to find the killer himself and deal with him in his own way...in order to stop more people being killed.You see many times throughout the movie where Harry has run ins with his superiors who want to namby pamby their way around the situation whilst Harry believes the longer they dick around with this guy the more people are going to get hurt.One poignant scene is where the killer has kidnapped a 14 year old girl and buried her alive. Time is running out to find out where she is before her oxygen runs out...Harry with anger and desperation for the girls welfare clearly etched in his face literally tortures the wounded perp until he finally gives up the information he needs to save her.The next scene sees that his arrest, his evidence and the killers confession will all be thrown out as inadmissible due the way it was obtained and the killer is going to be set free."That man had rights" says the DA"What about (the girl)? She's raped and left in a hole to die, what about her rights? Who speaks for her?" replies a frustrated Harry, hardly believing what he is hearing.The film was a huge hit and I said at the beginning of this review it started off a decade long run of hard boiled loose canon cop movies, but it was not without us detractors.Many called it fascist or right wing, citing that the police had no right to be Jury, Judge and executioner. Many of the original intended stars (which incidentally included Frank Sinatra, John Wayne, Robert Mitchum, Steve McQueen, Paul Newman and Charles Bronson) turned it down for this very reason.I personally do not find it so, for however brutal Harry Callaghan seems at times, you know his actions all stem from his desire to save lives and protect innocent people from the actions of evil people. There is nothing wrong with wanting to do that.I think if there is a moral to the story at all, it is that if you don't want to be shot and tortured by a cop don't kidnap 14 year old girls and bury them alive... under those circumstances the Dirty Harry's of this world, no matter how dirty they are, will pose no threat to you whatsoever.Don Siegel would leave the Dirty Harry franchise after just this one outing, but Clint would go on to make 4 sequels over the next 18 years featuring Harry Callaghan. He was not only the character Eastwood would become most associated with but a character that has become one of the most iconic in movie history.

Dirty Harry, the film that rocked the 70's and that rocked the world on its release date. Remembered as a cop thriller and to be remembered as one of the best to date. Harry Callahan (Clint Eastwood) who must find and bring down sniper expert Scorpio from causing any more extreme terror to Sanfrancisco City. By this he demands the sum of $100,00 to be paid to him, before he kills his next victim. Wild car chases, classic action are all in this film, keeping the suspense flowing rapidly and the action exploding dramatically, but worthy not of its 18 certificate.
