Director Don Siegel recreates the suspense and action like from such films as the Fugitive.With Clint EastWood at the helm of the acting role nothing could go wrong, adding great dialogue to Harry and fab characteristic development. With his Magnam in his coat pocket and an air for causing trouble, Dirty Harry explodes onto the screen with full on action and cant look away acting.

This is really a movie that has been neglected throughout time mainly because of its content. I still stand that this is one of the greatest films of the 1970's. Dirty Harry is truly a classic character and delivers the classic line, "Do I feel lucky? Well do ya punk?" Clint Eastwood delivers one of his strongest performances, and is a very likable character that you can agree with, despite the system that can sometimes not make any sense at all. With the passage of time, I think that this is a great movie- almost a classic- and will never be forgotten. Eastwood has said himself that he didn't understand why Dirty Harry wasn't well received. It probably deserved a shot at the Oscars. Great film- 9/10.

reviews.review_title: The Beginning of the Dirty Harry ERA
reviews.content: TITLE: Dirty harry was released on December 23, 1971 and the runtime was 102 minutes. Dirty Harry is a 1971 crime thriller film produced and directed by Don Siegel, starring Clint Eastwood, Harry Guardino and Reni Santori. This was the first in the Dirty Harry series. Clint Eastwood plays the title role, in his first outing as San Francisco Police Department Inspector "Dirty" Harry Callahan.SUMMARY: A serial killer who calls himself "Scorpio" (Andy Robinson) murders a young woman in a San Francisco high-rise rooftop swimming pool using a high-powered rifle from the top of the 555 California Street skyscraper. When SFPD Inspector Harry Callahan (Clint Eastwood) investigates, he finds a spent shell casing and a ransom message from the killer, promising more deaths if the city does not pay him $100,000. The chief of police, with the agreement of the Mayor (John Vernon), assigns Harry to the case and arranges for extra support. Later, Harry waits for his lunch in a local café, but notices a robbery-taking place at a nearby bank and tells the café owner to call the police and report an armed robbery in progress. While he waits for reinforcements, the robbers emerge from the bank, forcing Harry to confront them alone. During the confrontation, Harry utters to one of the robbers: The next day, Harry is assigned a rookie partner, Chico Gonzalez (Reni Santoni). Harry notes that his partners always get injured (or worse), and that he needs someone experienced, but the Chief gives him no choice. A police helicopter foils Scorpio's second attempt at murder while he is targeting a black man in a park, but Scorpio escapes. The next night, he manages to kill a young boy from another rooftop. Since Scorpio's last victim was a black man, the police believe Scorpio will pursue a Catholic priest as his next victim; feeling "owed" one for the disruption of his earlier attempt. The police set up a sting, with teams on rooftops throughout the city, but leaving the rooftop Scorpio used in his disrupted murder attempt clear, and providing a target of opportunity, a priest at the Saint Peter and Paul Church. Harry and Chico wait for Scorpio on an adjacent rooftop, Harry with a high-powered rifle and Chico with a spotlight. When Scorpio appears, a shootout ensues but he eventually escapes, killing a police officer. Infuriated that his plans have twice been foiled, Scorpio kidnaps a teenage girl, rapes her and buries her alive. He contacts the city and demands twice his previous ransom, giving the city until 3 a.m. the following morning, when the girl's air will run out. The mayor decides to pay, and tells Harry to deliver the money to a location at the docks with no back up. Without permission, Harry wears a wire, has Chico follow him, and tapes a knife to his shin. When Harry reaches the drop point, Scorpio contacts him through a public payphone, sending Callahan on a journey between various pay phones in the city, in order to separate the inspector from any back up that he may have. However, Harry's wire allows Chico to follow him. The chase ends when Harry reaches an enormous cross at Mount Davidson, one of the city's parks. Scorpio instructs Harry to drop his gun and the money, then to face the cross and stand up against it. Scorpio then proceeds to beat Harry before revealing that he has "changed his mind" and is going to let the girl die anyway, and kill Harry as well. Chico arrives at the scene and shoots at Scorpio, saving Harry. Chico is shot, in the ensuing shootout. While Scorpio is distracted, Harry stabs him in the leg with his concealed knife. Scorpio screams hysterically and escapes without the money. Chico survives his wound, but tells Harry he will be resigning from the force.QUESTIONS Why did Harry have to get a new partner? Why was Harry looking for the doctor that treated Scorpio? Why was Scorpio living and working in nearby Kezar Stadium? Why did Harry stand on Scorpio injured leg? Why Debralee Scott body was found overlooking the Golden Gate Bridge? Why was Scorpio release from all charges? MY THOUGHTS: This was the beginning of the Dirty Harry ERA. This movie kept you on the edge of your sit right from the beginning. I thought Andy Robinson did a good job as his role as the bad guy. Once again however this was a movie that no leading lady. Sure, there was a lot of action. However, it takes more than action in my eyes to be an excellent movie. In my eyes, a movie must have a leading lady if it wants to get 10 weasel stars. Since this movie had no leading lady I can give this s movie 8 weasel stars at best.

I don't usually watch old movies but tried this one out and it was worth it. It had a lot to do with society that rings true today. It really shows how. From a good intention place, with a history of delusional policies and culture, can derive deranged people who can reck havoc on a defenseless population. It's shows Harry a harden strong character, who have to do whatever it takes to keep that society afloat. Tough people equal easy times. Ts nicely made but it's older, a classic.

reviews.review_title: The originator of the bad ass hero....
reviews.content: **POSSIBLE SPOILERS BELOW**Finally seeing this film, its as good and 'groundbreaking' as was advertised.  Now I see where other films like Die Hard 3 & Along Came A Spider got the 'bad guy sending the good guy on a wild goose chase' idea from (with the public phones).  I'm not sure if this is the first film to do it, but its definitely the earliest film I've seen it in.  Dirty Harry is the original bad ass good guy; I've dabbled in the character's other films like The Enforcer, etc but never the original......and I must say it's a pretty damn good movie.  It's intriguing throughout; the 'Scorpio' character is as creepy as it gets.  You just get such a good and relieving feeling when Dirty Harry finally gets him in the end.  Clint Eastwood fits the Dirty Harry character perfectly; the now famous 'do you feel lucky' line is absolutely classic.  It was good to finally experience the originator of it all; this movie has spawned a lot of children in action cinema, all praises due to the father....Dirty Harry.*** out of **** stars.
" Clint Eastwood" owns this character. Even if the film is bare bones, there is atleast an ark that draws its themes into focus.

reviews.review_title: Setting the foreground for vigilante cop movies.
reviews.content: In what may be Clint Eastwood's defining role as a screen icon, the narcissism and heroic setup is what makes this movie such a draw for young male fans. This was the pivotal point in Clint's career that would make him a legend I believe, even more of an impetus than the 'man with no name' trilogy. In Dirty Harry, Clint defined his charisma and the secured the monumental franchise.Yes, I grew up in the 70's and watched Eastwood's movies and especially loved Dirty Harry for the same reasons why any other red blooded kid would. Clint's style is what makes him and this movie so magnetic. With his classic and signature steely-eyed grin, whispering voice and stoic righteousness, that in itself is just the surface. Harry Callahan is a no nonsense cop out to mend justice with his unorthodox approach. But technically this makes him a rebel to a flawed legal system that inadvertently protects the perpetrators and bad guys.So the argument that this is a right winged biased approach to law and order is faulty due to the fact that Harry is actually a rebel and defies the ineffective system that is confined to so many left winged statuetes.Dirty Harry is basically a cop movie which the plot is fuelled by the hateful murderer and the justice sought by one man, Harry Callahan. It's a beautiful and gritty film with all of it's inner city backdrops of San Francisco. The hippie era had reached status quo by the early 70's and I could see how the theme of the story took political chances.But it's a good cop movie. The murders are realistic, the violence still holds up and the tension builds inevitably as the denouement face off between Scorpio and Harry's chase scene reached its climax.Unfortunately the sequels relied to heavily on political pundits for justice. We don't need to be taught these elementary lessons on morality and that is what gets old to me. It's more interesting, as in the original Dirty Harry, to see a portrait of a lawman face adversity when trying to uphold what is right and what is fair in an unfair legal system, only to be hindered by the laws and police hierarchy.

reviews.review_title: One of the finest cop movies ever made
reviews.content: Dirty Harry reminds us why Clint Eastwood is so popular. The film is fantastic, Eastwood excelling as the no-nonsense maverick cop Harry Callehan, complete with Magnum 44 handgun, a weapon so powerful it can 'blow your head clean off'. There are numerous thrills in Dirty Harry, Eastwood tracking down a demented child killer, played by a man so ludicrously over the top that you look forward to his inevitable execution at the film's end. The dialogue is fast and witty, whilst there are enough action scenes to keep things flowing. The soundtrack is very 70s and whilst the tunes can only be described as weak, they at least create an atmosphere of sorts. Eastwood doesn't mince his words in this picture, a very uncompromising cop being portrayed. The Magnum 44 steals the film, its awesome sound and power making for acres of entertainment. The legendary 'do you feel lucky punk' quote of Eastwood also makes its first appearance in this movie. Overall a great offering and one of the 70s better films.

reviews.review_title: The greatest rogue cop of them all
reviews.content: Dirty Harry Callahan just might be the greatest anti-hero that cinema has ever known. Like the movie says, you don't assign him, you just turn him loose. Obsessed with delivering justice at whatever the cost, Harry makes you wish that there were more cops out there just like him. Dirty Harry starts off the eventual 5 movies in the series with a bang. All 5 are great but it is the original that I keep coming back to. Everything about this movie is well done and entertaining. The period soundtrack is wonderful. The streets of San Francisco are practically a player in the movie. Great shots of the city circa 1971 abound. Scorpio is the perfect bad guy. You can't wait to see him get his. Despite Clint Eastwood's many movie roles, and especially his westerns like The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly, Harry Callahan is his best character in my opinion. He gives Harry just the right amount of humor and humanity so you know that Harry is just human and not some superhero. When Harry and his .44 Magnum are in town, the bad guys better watch out. Bottom Line: Buy the Dirty Harry collection on DVD and you will never want for police dramas again. That is, if you feel lucky. Well do ya punk?

In the 70s you can tell movies started getting more greedy and violent, like in The Texas Chainsaw Massacre and The Last House on the Left. Here there is some of that, moro blood and explicit scenes. But overall is boring, there are scenes that could perfectly have been removes, like when the bad guy pays a man to hit him, that went nowhere.

reviews.review_title: The best 70's cop thriller movie. A classic!
reviews.content: Dirty Harry alongside with Sergio Leones "the man with no name" must be Clint Eastwoods most famous role. The fact hat this movie spawned a franchise of 5 films is no surprise. It's even director Michael Manns favourite movie.To sum up the character, he's the incarnation of the "bad cop" expression. He follows no rules, but gets the job done. he has he's own sense of justice and this gets him in trouble with the law. On the other hand, he saves life, and get's the crooks off the street. So the main question is, does the cause justify the means? I think everyone have heard of Diry Harry, and he's the character most people think of when they hear the name Clint Eastwood. He's though, he's grumpy, how can you not think is an awesome character? And at some point everyone have heard the line: "Do you feel lucky? Well do ya Punk!?" For this classic Clint Eastwood cop thriller, I give a 8/10. if you don't like the genre, you won't think much of it. But if you like action, thrills and enigmatic characters, this is the film for you!
Its just fantastic too see the old great movies the way they were and just remember the old times againe. Love it !!!!

reviews.review_title: "You got to ask yourself one question - do I feel lucky? Well, do ya punk?"
reviews.content: We follow an unconventional, "take no shit", straight talking San Francisco homicide Inspector, Harry Callaghan (Clint Eastwood), as he tracks down a psychopath and serial killer the "Scorpio" killer. Harry is a widow and doesnt like most people - especially criminals - and certainly doesn't like regulations. Harry has a background of cutting corners and not following said regulations.Scorpio (Andrew Robinson - known for his role as Garak in Star Trek) preys on the police and baits them for ransoms, kills four people (two children) and hijacks a school bus. Scorpio knows how to play the ever more regulation heavy system, baiting the loose cannon Harry into stepping over his mark as a police officer, affording Scorpio more freedom and release from prison.A new world is opening up, and changes are coming to law enforcement - more and more suspects know their rights - so an old-school cop comes into conflict with a new breed of killer and new rules on how he is meant to operate.The film is more about Clint Eastwood's attitude and demeanour more than anything else. The Scorpio killer is not really compelling, feels more like a comic book killer than a real life killer. A times it seems like he is just there to test the waters of new police regulations than actually having a motif. There is a nice polar opposite feeling between the cool, slow, unconventional Harry, and the bumbling maniac.The film suffers from realism here and there - Harry never does paperwork; his superiors are more willing to allow him to act as he pleases and just give him a drink and telling off; he is allowed to carrying weapons that are not service standards etc.Clint Eastwood is super cool in it - and there are many bad-ass scenes (like the bank robbery segment at the start). Its an anti-regulation, anti-liberal, anti-criminal piece.There are some creative shots, and some creative direction and writing - very little dialogue; the viewer learns about Harry through his actions and the lack of normal behaviours, e.g. He doesnt have a partner as his partner is in hospital, but we dont see or learn about this much. Has a sense of mystery due to these bits and pieces.Worth watching if you like the shoot-em-up style of westerns and city based thrillers.

Two movies are the most influential of the 70's: "Star Wars" and "Dirty Harry."   "Dirty Harry" took the Western -- which had ruled for decades but was fading out -- and converted it into the "rebel cop action movie." Everybody from Charles Bronson to Nick Nolte to Mel Gibson would take a shot at this genre. But Eastwood got there first."Dirty Harry" also created the concept of the "action hero":  Bronson, Gibson, Nolte -- sure.  But also Stallone, Schwarzenegger, Segal, Van Damme. "Dirty Harry" also inaugurated the "evil psycho villain" movie. Henceforth, villains would stop at nothing, and audiences would demand their gruesome payback deaths.  There's no reason to understand the villainous killer/rapist/extortionist Scorpio, no reason to want anything for him other than death:  he kills women, children, priests.  He hijacks school buses. He buries a girl alive after doing unspeakable things to her.  From here on out, movie villains would be evil, incarnate.  "Dirty Harry" started it all, but there's a big surprise within it: it is one of the greatest movie thrillers ever made, thanks to skilled director Don Siegel ("Invasion of the Body Snatchers," "The Shootist," "Charley Varrick") Siegel's skill with images, editing, and narrative give "Dirty Harry" the feel of a film noir turned horror movie, nowhere more evident than in the long, central sequence where Harry must run a gauntlet through nighttime San Francisco trying to get ransom to Scorpio before the buried girl dies.   This is one of the most harrowing, suspenseful, and dynamic sequences ever filmed, as hero, villain and .357 Magnum meet in deserted SF Kezar Stadium in the dead of night."Do ya feel lucky, punk?" is a great speech, first in the film's early, light-hearted action sequence, and then in the dead-serious finale.A hell of a movie.  A classic. See it.

From the moment you hear Scorpio's haunting soundtrack (which was later sampled by the great NWA on 'Approach To Danger') you know you are in for a treat. The film doesn't disappoint. It has been copied many times (most notably by the infamous Die Hard 3) but nothing will surpass it. It is superbly shot and the whole film oozes suspense on what was, in comparison to today, a shoestring budget. Action how it should be: without a gratuitous explosion in sight. Brilliant.

Difficult to comment such a movie... If you review it at the time it went out or nowadays, the appreciation is going to be very different. Indeed when it went out the movie was pretty violent and dark, with very incisive dialogues, but now compare to what we similarly make today ("In Bruges" for example), it looks quite old-fashioned. However if you put aside the lack logic in police procedures and some "loose" in the pace, many things are still extremely good. First of all some of the dialogues are still and always be memorable. Secondly there are some great acting skills that still impress today. For example, Clint Eastwood is truly amazing there, playing an inspector who is fair but doesn't make any concessions. In conclusion, a must see if you a cinema enthusiast, or a fan of Clint Eastwood, otherwise you should probably see something more recent.

reviews.review_title: Not that much of a good movie
reviews.content: Well I only watched this movie because of Clint Eastwood, I have watched Gran Torino, Good Bad and the Ugly , and many .They were pretty good movies. My hopes were lot higher with this movie . I mean it's Clint Eastwood. People write songs about him. He made old cowboy movie look cool. But this one I found to to be boring. And many things are happens for no reason. Last half an hour is bit of interesting but many people would just left the movie.

I think anyone who hasn't seen Dirty Harry, still a staple of late night television in Britain, is either lying or died before it came out. Everyone must know the plot by now: tough cop Harry Callaghan ( Eastwood) is assigned to catch a psychopathic serial killer, Scorpio, played by Andrew Robinson, whose innocent and clown like features make the role more chilling.Basically Harry has little time for the hippyish liberal philosophies that were taking hold in America at the start of the seventies- Dirty Harry is filmed in a San Francisco just coming out of the hippy era and ironically Scorpio wears some hippyish clothes- and is a tough cop of the old school who believes violent criminals should be hunted down and, if necessary, killed off. No wonder in America, which was suffering a big increase in crime when Dirty Harry was released, the character proved popular with millions of Americans even if one critic predictably referred to the film as fascist for its brutal approach to solving crime. However, who is the real fascist: a decent cop trying to stop a psychopathic killer on the rampage or Scorpio,the serial killer terrorising San Francisco.From the opening credits where a young woman is gunned down in a swimming pool to the end where Scorpio is blown away by the most powerful handgun in the world, the action never lets up and both Eastwood and Robinson play excellent roles. Dirty Harry, even if you have seen it a million times, will always make your day and spawned four excellent sequels that are just as good as the original. If you can, try and watch all five of the Harry Callaghan films as the characterisation is fantastic and the wisecracks as good as anything from James Bond.

Much debate has been sparked over the political stance of this film. Nevertheless, it is an immensely entertaining action thriller that solidified Clint Eastwood as the ultimate action hero of the 70's. Police inspector Harry Callahan works on tracking down maniac rooftop killer Scorpio before a kidnapped 14 year old girl dies. Once he is caught, Harry violates the murderer's civil rights which leave the police no choice but to let him go free. When the madman hijacks a school bus full of children, Harry is called on once again. Eastwood is perfect in the title role, as he creates one of the most memorable characters in movie history. Harry carries himself with a cool, suave, and in-control disposition. He's intimidating but definitely likable. Don Siegel's direction is terse and suspenseful. He doesn't waste time in giving us the goods from start to finish. The great dialogue is also accompanied by an eerie jazzy electronic score by Lalo Schifrin. I found this kind of ghostly sound to be used in many other crime thrillers of the day. Siegel provides us with an interesting look at how one man defies the law and takes matters into his own hands. Are his actions justified? Well, that's up to you! One of the best films of the 70's!

reviews.review_title: Who knew that the film world could churn out a film as great as this....
reviews.content: Unbelievable cold-blooded vigilantism played by Clint Eastwood as Detective 'Dirty' Harry Callahan, the cinematography, the score, the script, its all pure genius wrapped in a bundle called "Dirty Harry". The story of a crazed roof-top psychopathic killer who goes by the name 'Scorpio' (played by Andy Robinson of 'Hellraiser' I believe), Scorpio loves to leave notes to the mayor about how he will kill different people of race, gender or whatever it may be, in order to receive a ransom he feels he is entitled to. Harry Callahan (Eastwood) sees it a different way.... Callahan doesn't like seeing killers get their way and he really doesn't like Scorpio. The Mayor, Chief of Police and any other authority thats in Harry's way are determined to appease the killer in order to hopefully desist this carnage from going on any longer, Harry again sees things a different way. The mayhem that ensues is just cinematic genius and an unbelievable script that will keep you compelled from beginning to end. This movie will either make you or break you of the action/thriller genre. 9/10 stars will definitely suffice, brilliant work overall by the crew of this film.

reviews.review_title: "Dirty Harry" is a great cop movie
reviews.content: "Dirty Harry" is a great cop movie. It features Clint Eastwood in the eponymous role, trying to chase down a psychotic killer played brilliantly by Andrew "Garak of Deep Space 9" Robinson.The plot is fairly simple. Harry stop Scorpio (the killer). In between Harry gets to foil a few other crimes - my favorite being the hilarious scene where Harry talks down a man from committing suicide. This is a prime example of some the delicious black humor running through "Dirty Harry", that helps elevate it above the dross. The main killer is particularly effective because of the way Robinson portrays him, as if a wild man is trapped inside a normal citizen. The killings themselves are violent and brutal and perfectly match the film's gritty nature.Eastwood suits the dry, sarcastic, down-beat Harry to a tee as he's perfected all the looks necessary over his career. He's a cop you don't ever want to mess with. His partner - who have previously had the career of a Spinal Tap drummer - plays surprisingly well off him, considering the circumstances, even if his fate is somewhat inevitable.I'd recommend "Dirty Harry" to any fans of the cop genre, as Dirty Harry - the cop, not the movie - is a great character.

reviews.review_title: ''Justice in your own hands'' never seemed so entertaining.
reviews.content: Since many Oscars have gone in the past years to movies that have a leftist political subtext (that's not a bad thing tbh, but I've just grown a bit tired of them), I wanted to see a movie whose message and subtext leans towards right, a movie with a perspective that I haven't really thought about that much.I still think it's not ok to ''take justice in your own hands'' and become just like Dirty Harry, but man... we all need this kind of escapism sometimes. This thought that you - and not some institutions controlled by some snobbish politicians and demagogues - can decide what's wrong and right and act in this way is a short pleasure that you can't allow yourself in real life but have part of through fiction. Of course, even murderers have a tad of humanity left in them and they shouldn't be humiliated or downtrodden and most of them aren't psychopaths but rather victims of the failure of society to care about them, to educate them. But just for this time let's forgot about this and see how ''the hero'' beats the s*** out of the bad guy.It's also the second movie I see that casts Clint Eastwood after Million Dollar Baby, but this time much younger. Great cinematography, some memorable lines and a good action movies, maybe a bit old but still very good.An 8,7 out of 10 from me.

I have no idea why this movie is popular.The action is stupid, the story is horrible, the san francisco cops are morons.There's a part of the movie where there are sharpshooters on every skyscraper and choppers flying around. The guy threatens that he'll kill, so they pull off every cop off the case, so it is just harry and the killer.Then the killer gets off because the miranda rights weren't read to him and when harry tells the DA that he'd kill again, the DA says, "how do you know?". How stupid do they think the cops are, the audience is?I don't even have the energy to curse this movie ... I just want the last two hours of my life back. The only reason I'm writing this is that IMDb wants 10 lines of text, a policy that's got to be as bad as the movie.

reviews.review_title: Dark, hard-hitting, sadistic and brutal, and yet... perfect
reviews.content: *this may contain a slight spoiler*Who could forget the classic Clint Eastwood lines: "Do you feel lucky, punk?" Well, no-one; and that's why they're all the more fantastic today. To hear about a truly historic movie moment is one thing; but to actually hear it, feel it, breathe it? That's just different ballpark. Harry Callaghan is a homicide detective. He's a tough, uncompromising guy, almost darkly comically; I swear the bloke could go through several different emotions: happy, sad, angry or confused, without having the audience a clue what he actually is. He speaks up, yet keeps to himself; it truly is a testimony to how perfectly and toughly the script was written. So when a sadistic psychopath is loose killing innocent victims in San Fransico, who else could be assigned to the case? It really is an amazing feature to see how his emotions do in fact change, slowly, as the case turns from your average run-of-the-mill homicide case to an obsessive and impassioned literal fight to bring down the biggest threat in the city, at any costs. Hardhitting, brilliantly acted, and, well, fantastic, this is not your standard snip-cut police action movie like Die Hard or Lethal Weapon. This is serious, intricate, thoroughly well done work, that should appreciated by all. 10 out of 10

This is as close to perfect as a movie about a police chasing criminals gets. The plot is good, manages to fill the whole movie without any dull "cannon fodder" bad guy sidekicks. Harry and the killer has several confrontations without killing each other, and it only gets better by that. The killer gets away to plan his next sick move.I tend to believe that one quantity that affects the quality of action movies is the number of bad guys, especially number of kills. Fewer is better. More bad guys means less time on understanding each. This movie focuses on a single lunatic, and win a lot by that. Later Dirty Harry movies has more bad guys, but they add little or nothing, they are more or less paper thin sidekicks that are done away with with a quick bang.Casting is also just great. Many movies, not least new ones, have so bad casting that it takes an effort to tell characters apart. Not here. All leading characters are razor sharp and also doing their job flawlessly. Even some small parts (Albert Popwell, had parts in all 4 Dirty Harry movies) are impressing.And to add the last spice, the movie has a great one-liner, used with perfection, so good that Dirty Harry 2 opened with it.I find very little that I don't like. Police movies are not all that interesting as a theme, tend to land around 4-7 for me. Not this. Great stuff.

I first saw Dirty Harry round about the same time the fourth film 'Sudden Impact' was released, which was either 1983 or 1984. This film is perfect.This is THE film that gave Clint Eastwood his signature role and movie immortality. This film is to cop thrillers what Star Wars is to sci-fi, like all great movies there are many moments and images that stay in the mind long after you have seen the picture.Classic moments: The opening sequence, the rooftop Sniper called Scorpio taking aim at a young woman swimming on a skyscraper pool; just listen to Lalo Schfirin's haunting and murderous music scored in perfect timing to the movement of the two characters (her swimming, him aiming at her through his rifle lens). brilliant.2nd classic moment: Harry running around San Francisco with a yellow gym bag filled with $200,000, running from phone booth to phone booth on the instructions of the Sniper in order to save a young girl that the Sniper has kidnapped. The sequence comes to a head at Mount Davidson Park at a huge monument called 'The Cross' where Harry is almost kicked to death by a red ski-masked Scorpio, and Scorpio shows his true nature by changing his mind and letting the girl die of slow suffocation. When Harry finally catches him at the Kezar stadium, and tortures Scorpio i defy anybody to forget this moment a year after seeing it.The ending is simple good guy versus bad guy,which for future generations i will not type here for although Dirty Harry was released in 1971, for me personally, it is timeless and in the time to come those future generations will see this film and maybe, just maybe, they will know that for all your Bad Boys and Lethal weapons out there, nothing will come close to the power of Clint Eastwood in Dirty Harry.

I think this was a great movie. I always like Clint Eastwood's movies though. The way that filmed this movie I also liked. The way things ended up in the movie I think was pretty accurate to what happens in real life with real cops. Also with the court systems. Like how they didn't even try him. So Clint ended up shooting him in the end which is what needed to happen in the first place. They don't act fast enough. They let people die because of it. Sometimes they cant help it but if they did hurry things up they can always help to save more people. I think there is a lot of cops who do wanna do what Clint does and take matters into there own hands. Which sometimes wouldn't be the best thing but sometimes I think it is necessary. I think that some of the parts were funny and over all was a great watch for people who like justice type movies or just action films.

reviews.review_title: Do I feel lucky? WELL DO YOU PUNK??!!
reviews.content: After acting the character of The Man with Noname, spaghetti western films like The Good The Bad And the Ugly. Clint Eastwood plays the modern day cop of the west. That still influence us today, even after 35 years. Dirty Harry.I guarantee, if you like action, and a cop with a bad-ass attitude( sorry about the language), you'll love (even though he hates you) Dirty Harry. "Dirty" Harry Callahan is a tough San Francisco Cop, who hates criminals and scumbags who breaks the law and gets away with it, while he himself hates the law also, but obeys it anyway. His most famous quotes that everyone loves is this.... "I know what you're thinking punk. You're thinking did he fire 6 shots or only 5? Well to tell you the truth I've forgotten myself in all this excitement. But being this a .44 magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world and would blow your head clean off. You've got to ask yourself a question; Do I feel lucky? Well do you punk? *BANG*The plot so far is about a sniper, who calls himself Scorpio, (who is loosely based on the Zodiac Killer, around that time) is killing people around the San Francisco and holds the city at ransom, or more people will die. He is portrayed by Andrew Robinson, and does a stunning job as acting as Dirty Harry's first nemesis in the film. Dirty Harry is at the case to nail him, no matter what. The success of this movie has spawned 4 sequels, and since then became a legacy of one of the greatest cop movies of all time, even to this day. Of course there is a rumor I heard saying there could be a 6th Dirty Harry coming, but I think it's false....but then again... I'd say this..."Go ahead, make my day"

I really mean what I say in the title of this.  This is probably my favorite movie of all time.  The acting is good, tha action scenes are good, and you never get bored during it.  Andrew Robinson stole the show as the psychotic killer Scorpio.  He is sometimes unintentionally hilarious like the scene when he gets stabbed in the leg and screams.  But I was still glad when Harry capped him at the end because of all the bad things he had done. Eastwood is a man of few words but his precence is felt throughout.  I recommend this movie to anyone who likes movie, especially action movies. 5/5

Dirty Harry is a celebration of violent, vigilante violence and the power of a man with a gun. I can't at all relate to this message, I find it a bit scary in it's implications. However, the amazing acting on the villain's part and the wonderfully written character of the jaded Harry combined with bombastic shootouts make this movie one hell of trip I can't help re-watching.

At this moment, with the D.C. Beltway sniper still at large and still killing. I thought for sure there was some kind of Moslem angle to this thing, until the word got out about some kind of "ransom" demand. That doesn't seem to fit my Moslem theory at all. Those guys don't give a hoot about money. It's almost exactly as though the killer was emulating the "Scorpio" killer in the movie (himself evidently somewhat modelled on the never-caught late-Sixties/ early-Seventies "Zodiac Killer"). Too bad we don't have a *real* Dirty Harry to get this guy and kick his @$$ just like in the excellent and ground-breaking 31-year-old movie.

This film is a classic.People love it because Harry dishes out his own brand of justice.All the BLEEDING Hearts out there don't watch.Harry is glad to shoot any crook that comes along.Scorpio is a vile villain.He enjoys killing people.He will meet his match in the streets of San Fransico Harry Callahan.The ending is still a surprise to viewers.Music and acting are first rate.

This film contains outstanding performances from Eastwood and the rest of the cast alike. The storyline is good enough to keep you on the edge of your seat in suspense. At times, it can feel slightly clichéd and a bit predictable as you know he will eventually catch Scorpio. In spite of this, the film and action scenes running throughout will keep your eyes fixed to the screen as although you have a fair idea of what the end result will be, you remain uncertain as to how this will actually happen.When Scorpio gets released without charge and goes on the run again, it can be slightly frustrating and appear to be exactly what you would expect and the whole pursuit resumes again as before. Regardless, the film is still worth a watch and the random jokes scattered throughout make it very entertaining!

reviews.review_title: Line after line of punch, scene after scene of excitement...
reviews.content: What started out as a vehicle for star Frank Sinatra, eventually became Don Siegel's classic, hugely influential cop thriller that confirmed star Clint Eastwood's place in Hollywood.  Eastwood was made for his now legendary role as Harry Cahallan, the tough, hard-bitten cop who goes in pursuit of a deranged sniper (a terrifying Andy Robinson) after his superiors fail to bring the killer to justice.  More than thirty years after its original release, the film carries a distinctive early Seventies look that is more compellingly realistic than dated.  The screenplay is more or less unforgettable with line after line of punch, scene after scene of excitement, all coming to the fore in the film's climatic scene.  The film was almost notoriously controversial and undermined in its day, which wasn't helped by the string of less credible, cash-in sequels that followed that were inferior on every level to Siegel's original offering.  All in all, a strong achievement for Siegel and Eastwood.

reviews.review_title: THE film that defined the tough cop action movie
reviews.content:
This is the film that people of a certain age watched as kids in the 70s/80's. On a vcr with your mates.
It is Clint at his best, the story, casting, direction and action set pieces are all flawless.
The tough guys of the 80's, Stallone, Arnie, Segal and Van Damme, to name a few all owe a large chunk of their careers to Clint in his role as Harry.
Also a shout out to Andy Robinson, as Scorpio, acting just like you want your mad villains to be.
One of the very first videos I owned in the 80's and having just watched it again, still holds it worth now.
Brilliant and still brilliant.
Go ahead....

Clint Eastwood epitomized toughness for two decades, and his iconoclastic anti-hero persona is on full display in 1971's Dirty Harry, my personal all-time favorite movie. While criticized at the time for its violence, and a cop's disregard for individual rights and "right wing" theme, Dirty Harry was nonetheless appreciated by those tired of rampant crime and lawlessness in many of the nation's cities. A revolutionary film, "DH" illustrates the frustration felt by both the general public and those in law enforcement with a system that too often weighs in favor of the criminal rather than the victim. It is a theme that is just as relevant today, and Eastwood perfectly conveys this concept by waging a one man war against a criminal totally devoid of humanity or viewer sympathy.When a crazed killer terrorizes San Francisco, Detective "Dirty" Harry Callahan is assigned to the case. Fed up with red tape and ineffective "traditional" police procedures, Callahan pulls out all stops to nab the killer- disregarding Miranda and Escobito procedures which are the linchpin of our system of jurisprudence. Andrew Robinson's portrayal of killer "Scorpio" is indeed a tour de force- one of the screen's best ever villains that stands up 38 years later. His performance is even more remarkable given the knowledge that Robinson in real life is a softspoken, peace loving man with a disdain for guns. Fine support is offered by veteran actors Harry Guardino, John Vernon and John Larch, all staples of 60's and 70's television. Lalo Schifrin's creepy score fits the theme perfectly and Don Siegel's direction is excellent.Dirty Harry spurred four sequels and cemented Eastwood's reputation as a box office titan. One of the best movies of the 70's and an all-time classic.

reviews.review_title: The Liberal Establishment as Public Enemy #1
reviews.content: The key to understanding the immense success and popularity of Dirty Harry lies in its location: San Francisco. With its reputation for being an official sponsor of political and cultural liberalism, San Francisco was already at that time becoming seen as the new enemy in American society, and Siegel's attack on it is remorseless.Compare Dirty Harry with two previous Siegel films: Coogan's Bluff and Madigan (both 1968) and it immediately becomes clear why Siegel's 1971 film touched a nerve his previous attempts did not. Both set in New York the enemy is embodied in an individual and the plot centres on the usual problems faced by cops pursuing those who operate outside the law. These are without doubt exciting action movies, but deprived of any wider social context within which success can be established they failed to gain the notoriety Dirty Harry succeeded in gaining.With Dirty Harry we must remember that Scorpio, though clearly evil, is not Harry's main enemy. It is the collective efforts of the defense attorneys, judges and politicians who allow Scorpio to walk the streets a free man which cause the biggest problems for our hero. Similarly, this dichotomy on which the narrative depends cannot be successfully resolved merely in a confrontation between Harry and Scorpio. Whoever wins, the liberal establishment still stands. Knowing this, Harry's final act as a cop comes as no surprise.At the close of the 60s the Western - which had defined America since John Wayne portrayed the Ringo Kid in 1939 - was running out of steam and destructively turning in on itself (in violent Peckinpah style). Western actors (Eastwood and Wayne) moved to cop thrillers (Dirty Harry and McQ), and crime became the new prism through which American society could be understood. By portraying the establishment itself as the biggest criminal, Siegel is clearly reflecting the views of a society ill at ease.(Originally published on IMDb 24 October 1998 under an ID that has since been deleted)

An action movie without any kind of depth. The movie works fine if you want to turn your brains off and relax. You don't need to do a lot of thinking watching Dirty Harry do his "dirty things". I just wish the creators of this movie would have done a little more brainwork for this one. It could have been a great movie. Now it's only really remembered for the legendary lines of Harry Callahan.Easwoods part in this movie is the thing that keeps the boat floating. Without him it would have sank fast. All the characters lacked dimensions. I really would have loved to hear more about the death of Harry's wife. He never really seemed upset about it. I'm thinking I'd like to see Harry get drunk and smash the bottle on the wall and then go in front of a mirror and just stare at himself and maybe break the mirror with his fist. If a movie is called Dirty Harry, I want to see a Harry that is dirty in more ways. It's all about one man but still you hardly get to know him at all.The bad guy, Scorpio, is such a screw up... One of the worst bad guys I've seen in movies. I'm not even going go there.I heard a lot about Dirty Harry before I finally saw it. I was having my expectations high and got quite disappointed. I do though understand why this is such a classic. I just wish people would be more realistic when they talk about this movie. It's way overrated.

reviews.review_title: Row row row your boat. Come on sing!
reviews.content: This film is a marvel from the bravura opening sequence with the sniper on the roof followed by Harry locating the rifle shell, to the iconic moment when he casts his badge in the lake. All held together by an outstanding Shifrin score. The opening is a great example of effective storytelling during a title sequence. Andy Robinson is a great psychopath as he seems completely believable and the film features great moments like him getting a bus load of children to sing nursery rhymes. Very uncomfortable, as is the stadium scene which has an incredible helicopter shot in it where the camera keeps on pulling out until the stadium is lost in the San Francisco fog. A wonderful film with a great star that seems to get better and better on repeated viewing. Siegel did a great job with this one. It also contains great dialogue that is highly quotable.

reviews.review_title: the one that started it all
reviews.content: This has to be the finest example of the "bad cop out on the edge" movie going.   Don Seigal was renouned for his violent films before this,and did nothing to stop that reputation. This is an extremely violent film,for its day,and still now.  The character of cop dirty Harry Calaghan was the perfect vehicle for Clint to break into the mainstream american consciencenous. In a time when all of america was in upheaval over the Vietnam war,and everyone was getting very anti-establishment,Dirty Harry gave them a hero to believe in. He didn't play by the rules,and still got the job done,but his own way. He was an uncompromising passionate police officer who cared deeply about law and order and didn't like the way the system seemed to work in favour of the criminal.The killer,or Scorpio as he is called in the film,but not the credits,was brilliantly played by Andrew Robinson,who can now be seem in Star Trek Deep Space 9,playing a Cardassian spy. He is still one the scariest villains in movie history,a wonderfully manical laugh,and not afraid to do anything to get what he wants.... In fact,very similar to the hero,Harry This film is a true classic,one of Clint Eastwoods best.If it hadn't been for this film,we might never have seen all those cop movies that proliferated the screens during the 80's. Take Mel Gibsons cop in Leathal Weapon,had there been no Dirty Harry,there definitely wouldn't have been a Martin Riggs. So if you've never seen this movie,and have seen,and liked the Leathal Weapon series,then I suggest you have a look at where it all started

reviews.review_title: Dirty Harry: One great Cop Movie
reviews.content: This was a feel good movie for Americans who have seen the criminals and law breakers thumb their noses (Or give a middle finger) to the police and those that abide by the law as they continue to walk away from their rightful place behind bars or capital punishment. Clint Eastwood as Dirty Harry is the inspector,Judge and Jury in this first of the "Dirty Harry" films and is one of the best as he fights to stop a madman from killing more innocent people in San Francisco. Armed with his .44 magnum and showing he is a tough handsome dude with lots of hair and several cool sports jackets he proceeds to do the right things a cop should do while making his boss and the mayor (John Vernon Mad ;who would show up again in a few years as Dean Wormer in "Animal House".) During one of the opening scenes Clint goes into a corner hamburger shop for lunch and the camera shows a movie house on the side street next to the lunch shop. On the theater marquee is one of Eastwood's first films :"Play Misty for Me". It goes by fast so you need to be looking to see it. Wish Hollywood would make a few more good movies like "Dirty Harry".

Even after 50 years, this is 10x better than the junk that Hollywood churns out now. Excellent story, excellent writing, excellent cast, excellent acting; Clint Eastwood, Harry Guardino, John Vernon and John Larch. And as the frosting....REAL composed music by Lalo Schifrin. Why can't they make movies like this now?

I'm not grading this one.Dirty Harry is not a film for everyone, and I would recommend it to few. I believe Dirty Harry to be as much as an exploitation/political statement as much as it is a feature film. It's the dirty, hard gritty grimy slummy nasty scum riddled streets of San Francisco. The film se7en is also all of the above (bar the setting), but se7en raises the bar in terms of violence, and so it falls out of the category that Dirty Harry has created for itself and stands alone in.Clint Eastwood portrays Harry Callahan, a tough, un-compromising homicide cop whose first case is the murder of a woman in the scope of the infamous Scorpio killer. The plot is very straight forward and requires no hard thinking whatsoever. The plot is in fact as far as I am concerned secondary. It is the 'tour' we are taken on shot in a very basic documentarian fashion. It's eye though highly polished cannot hide its grain, even on Blu Ray disk. It is that which perhaps holds the most significance.There are no fancy camera angles, no special effects, no sunshine and flowers. This is a hard 70's cop film that pulls no punches whatsoever. The violence though strong is not stylalised. The images we see are dark and cold and the music that accompanies is of sadness when not picking up that famous 70's pace.The story takes us down the alleys and backstreets, into peoples lives where vice and homosexuality and cop hate are rampant. Everything is sordid and there is little in the way of humour or romance. That said, it contains the very famous monologue in the beginning that is mirrored in the end and in my opinion, part of what elevates this piece of cinema to it's status.In the beginning Callahan is mocking, being smart with the crook who's bank heist he foiled with the 44 magnum. In the end, his expression and actions complete a full circle. Yet there is no happy music and victory. He has stopped (by playing against the rules) the truly infamous bastard of a homicidal maniac. Andrew Robinson is Oscar worthy. I don't know if he received an accolade for this. I'm guessing that upon release the film had to surf an onslaught of political outrage. Harry does not save the girl, her limp naked body is pulled from the drainage and the evils of mankind are realised.To summarise, it's an important film. It is hard cinema, but for the discerning palette it is a must watch must own if only on the principle of being a film fan.

reviews.review_title: Early 70's "super-cop" takes law into his own hands, in pursuit of a psycopathic, deranged killer, in this vintage Eastwood thriller.
reviews.content: Arguably Clint Eastwood's signature film, and certainly my favorite of his films, Clint (San Francisco Detective "Dirty" Harry Callahan) Eastwood pursues a vicious and heartless killer, but he (Dirty Harry) finds himself fighting the political bureaucracy throughout his manhunt.Perhaps not the movie to originate the "catch-phrase," this film certainly made it famous, and other, subsequent films also contained classic, memorable Eastwood phrases (i.e., "Go ahead--make my day!" of "Sudden Impact.")  This movie tastefully had our hero utter the phrase just twice, hence preventing us from tiring of it.  This minimization of use, coupled with the phrase's actual contents, and topped off by Eastwood's inimitable style, makes this one of the most memorable catch-phrases in movie history: "I know what you're thinking--did I fire six shots, or only five?  To tell you the truth, through all this excitement, I've kind of lost track myself. But being this is a forty-four magnum, the most powerful handgun in the world, that would blow your head clean off, you've got to ask yourself one question--'Do I feel lucky?'-- Well, do ya', punk?"The movie has plenty of action, excitement, and suspense.  Andrew Robinson is dead on target playing "Scorpio," a psychopathic sniper who attempts to extort San Francisco, in exchange for cessation of his murdering spree. Several chilling scenes provide plenty of satisfying movie-watching, and most are well-scripted and well-acted.Unlike the majority of today's movies, this one's ending is just as compelling as its individual scenes, and this final sequence serves to punctuate the film even further.  It's a joy to view a well-balanced film, and to be as pleased and as moved by the ending, as by the film's individual scenes.  So common is it to sit through an apparently soundly constructed, intriguing movie, only to be vastly disappointed by an incongruent or nonsensical ending, to ultimately cheapen or destroy the film.  On the contrary, this ending delivers, satisfies, and leaves us yearning for more--which we do get in the less enjoyable, albeit above average sequel, "Magnum Force."The original and one of the best 70's super-cop movies, "Dirty Harry" is a must-see for anyone who missed it, or for any of the younger generation who will undoubtedly appreciate this vintage film.As an aside, even though Andrew Robinson played the role of the killer with great style and a with a very distinct presence, I think the ultimate person for the part would have been Dennis Hopper. Just imagine Dennis in this role!I would rate this movie a 7.9 out of 10 over-all, but for its time, for many individual trend-setting nuances, and for its uniqueness in the "super-cop movie" genre, that rating would be nearly a 10.

Well, maybe I've seen the movie too many times since 1971, but was watching it with my two sons the other day and have any of you ever noticed this:When Scorpio has Harry running around to ensure he is not being followed one of the locations he is sent is a BART subway platform. As he rushes down the stairs on the way to make the train there is a brief second as he turns around on one of the stair flights where you can see painted as graffiti on the wall behind him in large letters the word "KYLE".It is only visible for a second or two, but KYLE Eastwood was at that time Clint's only child, born in 1968!Look for it next time!Brian

reviews.review_title: The Original Cop Vs Killer Thriller
reviews.content: I first saw "Dirty Harry" back in the 1980s and I never get tired of watching it. It's so well-made that it's always a pleasure to watch. The script is one of the best Hollywood scripts ever and is filled with unforgettable characters, dialogue and action scenes.According to the Mayor of San Francisco (the great John Vernon), "there's a madman loose." The madman in question is a serial killer called Scorpio (he is also a paedophile, a rapist, a thief and an extortionist). Enter his opponent - unconventional cop Inspector Harry Callahan. From the start it's clear that Harry does things his way and resents authority, but he's a good cop and is let loose to hunt down Scorpio.It's in the conflict between Harry and Scorpio that the movie really comes into its own. They are equals in many ways, both are expert marksmen, both are control freaks and both enjoy sadistic games (Harry taunts suspects to go for their gun if they think he's out of bullets, a kind of variation on Russian Roulette. Scorpio kidnaps and buries a young girl and he runs Harry from one phone booth to another, if Harry misses one call, she dies. It turns out she was dead all along and Harry was wasting his time.) It could also be argued that Harry is as crazy as Scorpio, just look at his face when he steps on Scorpio's wounded leg in the football stadium to get him to confess the buried girl's whereabouts. Yet they are different in that they are on opposite sides of the law.Like Buffalo Bill in "The Silence of the Lambs," Scorpio is a fictionalized version of a real killer. The Zodiac Killer terrorized Northern California in the late 60s and was still at large when this movie came out (he has never been caught to this day). In one of his infamous taunting letters to the press, he claimed he would shoot a bus full of children. Although Zodiac never carried out that threat, Scorpio makes good on it in this movie by hijacking a school bus with children on board (while Scorpio never kills any of them, he has already killed a young black boy and raped and killed a young girl earlier in the film, so it's quite possible he could have harmed the kids had Harry not intervened).Andy Robinson has a field day playing Scorpio and he never really got a role that good again and it's a pity. Clint Eastwood suggested him to Don Siegel after seeing him in a stage play.John Wayne and Frank Sinatra were once in the running to play Harry Callahan - Wayne passed, Sinatra injured his hand. Thank God for that, Clint Eastwood was never better than in this and the role of Harry fits him like a glove (if you want to see what Wayne and Sinatra would have been like, check out "McQ" and "The First Deadly Sin" respectively.)The running gag throughout the movie is the reason why Callahan is called Dirty Harry. Another cop gives his theory that it's because Harry "hates everybody" and goes on to list all the racial slurs for those types of people. Harry himself, after stopping a suicidal jumper, explains that he's Dirty Harry because he gets "every sh*t job that comes along." Another possible explanation for Harry's nickname comes in two scenes where he voyeuristically spies on naked girls while tracking Scorpio (this voyeurism is another way he is like Scorpio, the movie begins with Scorpio watching a girl swimming in a rooftop pool through a telescopic sight and Harry even follows Scorpio to a strip joint later on).There is a fascinating example of how primitive criminal profiling was back in 1971. The chief of police makes a throwaway comment about how "sick guys" rob the same place many times. Today, forensics and profilers would be all over this case from the first murder and Harry's old-fashioned leg work would take a back seat.The subtext of Dirty Harry is really about the beginnings of Political Correctness and how old school cop Harry is unable and unwilling to conform to it. Harry would have begun his career as a cop when police brutality and racism were the norm and confessions were routinely beaten out of suspects. He gets a rude awakening when he tries that heavy-handed tactic on Scorpio and is berated by his superiors for it. It's clearly a shock for him; the other shock is that Scorpio goes free because Harry never got a warrant even though the dogs in the street know he's guilty as hell. It leads to the famous finale in which Harry, having cut through the bureaucracy and killed Scorpio, realizes he can no longer function as a cop in the system and throws his badge into the water. Box office success would dictate that Harry would get a replacement badge for four sequels. None of those movies could touch the original "Dirty Harry" (although the first half hour of "Sudden Impact" came close to matching it and gave us that other classic Harry line "Go ahead, make my day."). "Dirty Harry" remains an all-time classic nearly 40 years after its release and it remains my favorite Clint Eastwood movie and his best collaboration with director Don Siegel.

Don Siegel is part of a dead breed, the pulp filmmaker. They don't really exist anymore as film has become overrun with auteurs and popular films. Such directors like Quentin Tarantino, S. Craig Zahler, and to a lesser extent Eli Roth have attempted to replicate the effects of the 'pulp filmmaker' movement, to varying levels of success. The superhero films of now could be considered something of the 'pulp' age of films, but they don't quite capture the edge that the original pulp films had back in their day.Dirty Harry came out 5 years before Scorsese would put the vigilante sub-genre to rest with Taxi Driver, a complete deconstruction and tearing down of the genre, showing the vigilante as he would really be: a pitiful, alienated loner, lashing out at society and yet unable to find that the issues that he struggles with might be because of things that he can't control. No one was ever able to make a good vigilante film afterwards, and even some of the later Dirty Harry films struggled with the fallout from Taxi Driver, its impact and influence are inescapable.But Dirty Harry is interesting, as it doesn't quite lean into the more escapist, power fantasy aspects of Death Wish, it very much is a product of its time. It was made as the infamous Zodiac killings were being investigated, and coming after a decade where hope was smashed time and time again with the assassinations of figures like John F. Kennedy, his brother Robert, Malcolm X, and Martin Luther King Jr. It very much has the angst and anguish that came from the age before it. It has a raw anger and bitterness that can be felt throughout the film, and it's that hard edge that keeps it intriguing even after all of these years.Dirty Harry often goes back and forth from forcing you to confront harsher realities of the world to creating a new form of sensationalism with its more 'badass' moments. Clint Eastwood is iconic in the titular role: he's hard, cold, and steely in his conviction. He would be an ideal, yet he's hardly a man. He's a force of nature who seeks to avenge the wrongs of the world, and there is a certain escapism to it. But Siegel never seeks to glamorize Harry or anything that happens in this film. The violence and suspense built throughout the film are usually played to be horrific and intense, rather than something to be celebrated and cheered on. I was also surprised by the ponderous nature that it sometimes showcased, a trend that would be carried on in its post-Taxi Driver sequel Sudden Impact, though it was unfortunate to see the other films go on to become more like the other films of the vigilante genre.I'm surprised the so called 'cancel culture' of today hasn't gotten their hands on this film yet or the other ones that it followed, considering it's a film that teeters with celebrating police brutality and vigilantism, it often attracts reactionaries and boomers, who take the themes and ideas explored in the film and adapts them into their own short sighted ideologies, but I'm still surprised that in our more enlightened age that we haven't been asked to leave this film in the past and move forward, yet I don't think that it ever will. Its impact on popular culture is too great to be ignored.Dirty Harry is a neat contradiction, walking the line between entertainment and subversive artistic prowess. It's very much of the pulp film era, it's too interesting to be discarded, yet too of its time to be timeless.

reviews.review_title: "Eastwood can do no wrong. Let's see the picture." Richard Nixon on 'Dirty Harry'
reviews.content: Recently deceased Hunter S. Thompson claimed that Nixon lifted a policy against showing R-rated films in the White House theatre so that he could see Dirty Harry. (According to Dennis Bingham's book 'Acting Male') 'Dirty Harry' was one of many collaborations between director Don Siegel and star Clint Eastwood. Indeed, Harry Callahan bears numerous similarities with the character of Coogan from the Siegel/Eastwood offering 'Coogan's Bluff' (1968). The pair both get the 'dirty' jobs, and both go above and beyond the call of duty to get their man.The first in five 'Dirty' Harry films opens with a roof top sniping. Eastwood is soon on the case, tracking down the mysterious and dangerous Scorpio, who wants money or else he'll kill again. The ransom isn't paid, and Scorpio continues killing and even kidnapping - crossing Harry more than once, and injuring him in the process. Harry catches up with Scorpio, beats him, and then Scorpio is let go because of police brutality; leading to the school bus kidnap and the now iconic shoot-out.Harry can be seen as a reactionary figure, who disobeys all law to bring his own brand of justice to the streets. Indeed, it is strangely ironic that the counter-culture was a part of society Harry disliked and 'punished' (homosexuals, hippies etc) and yet they were part of the main fan base for the film. Harry presented the dichotomy of law enforcement figure, who was willing to bend the law to get justice. Something that appealed both to the likes of Nixon (although hardly the most law abiding citizen) and 'hippies'. And this aspect could be one reason for the films success.Furthermore, police in the US invited both Eastwood and Siegel to speak at functions because of the film, reading the movie as one which contained a wholly pro-police force message.Eastwood is brilliantly stoic and 'hard' as the iconic Harry, whilst Andy Robinson is delightfully manic as the rooftop killer and kidnapper Scorpio. There is also a brief but memorable cameo from Siegel and Dirty 'Harry' regular Albert Popwell (who appears in every 'Harry' film except 'The Dead Pool').Pauline Kael famously dislikes the film, calling it fascist, which led to numerous other critics agreeing with this verdict. However, both 'Rolling Stone' and 'Time' film critic raved about the movie. 'Time' man Jay Cocks even named it on his top ten list for the year! I thoroughly enjoyed the film, and whilst I see the 'fascism' in the film, can easily rise above this and enjoy it for what it is. Ten out of ten.

What I like about Dirty Harry is the Clint Eastwood performance in the greatest city I've ever been.... straightforward story, no pretentious acting, the 70's setting and music.... great.When I visited San Fansisco several times in the late 90's, sometimes it felt as if Inspector Callahean might appear around the next corner. It gave my trips a special dimension.Although I think Clint Eastwood is not a great actor, the Callahan character seems to fit to only him. The best Clint Eastwood performance ever. A monumental movie.

SYNOPSIS: A San Francisco Police Investigator hunts down a psychotic serial killer in the 1970s.CONCEPT IN RELATION TO THE VIEWER Sometimes you have to break the rules in order to do the right thing. Dealing with the endless red tape that comes from living and working in a bloated and spineless bureaucracy. Coming to terms with the frustrations that we all must face at some point in our lives.PROS AND CONS This film is iconic. It set the standard for the 'new' cop/buddy films that were to follow it like a stampede. Lethal Weapon, Die Hard, L.A. Confidential and a slew of others owe their origins to this film. This film solidified Clint Eastwood as a major presence in Hollywood.This is a film that we have all seen (probably numerous times). It has been a staple of television and cable for years. However, the version I watched on Laserdisc was the uncut original film that I don't believe is seen much these days. This film is easily censored and shortened in order to make more time for commercials and to fit into a 2 hour time slot. After watching this version, there were scenes that I don't recall having seen in the past. Scenes that don't add to the plot, but do flush out the character of Harry Callahan more and make him more complex than I remembered.In this original version, Harry has a lot of inner demons and is not a nice guy. He is bigoted in a very politically incorrect way. There are racial slurs and references to ethnic stereotypes all through the film. There is also a lot of casual nudity in the background which is something that censors and advertises eagerly cut out to get this film on public television.Along with "Bullitt" (Steve McQueen's police drama, also set in San Francisco), this film redefined the role of the police from angelic and efficient protector of the populace to the anti-hero where the rogue cop fights not only crime but his own department to get the job done.Several things stand out in this film. First of all is the wonderful melding of Lalo Schifrin's musical score with John Surtee's camera work. They bring an intimate sense of voyeurism and hip-ness to 1970 San Francisco. Going back to when I first saw this film, I have always been impressed by Scorpio (the serial killer in the film) played by Andrew Robinson. Even at the age of 10 I was curious why he didn't get an Oscar nomination. He scared the bejesus out of me and still does.As with anything successful (Rocky, Die Hard, Rambo), this film spawned 4 follow-up works all staring Clint Eastwood. The later films are somewhat curious after seeing the first film. At the end of "Dirty Harry", Harry Callahan, throws away his badge and as he has hinted all throughout the film, gives up his life as a police officer. Having disobeyed the police commissioner, the mayor and his supervisor, it seems unlikely that they would have kept him on the force. But then again, box office receipts are a powerful motivator.

reviews.review_title: THE best cop action thriller of all time.
reviews.content: Here's a thriller that stays tight as a drum from start to finish. I've seen it a bunch of times and still love every frame. Clint Eastwood takes his unmatchable work from the '60s westerns and takes it to a whole new level here. This is the defining role for one of film's most iconic figures.The story boasts the most devastating setup and payoff you can possibly imagine. If you don't know what I'm talking about, you haven't seen the film and need to.A thriller is only as good as the villain and Andrew Robinson deserves full credit for rendering the most loathsome bad guy ever. You absolutely cannot wait to wring this character's neck! (But you'll have to...) It's a shame that Robinson wasn't more visible after making this film, because he really does great work here. If the subsequent Dirty Harry films are less worthy than the original, it is in no small part due to the lesser caliber of the villains.Flaws? I don't see any! (Maybe political correctness, but if you're looking for that here, well that's just sad.) This is the absolute peak for director Don Siegel, Clint and composer Lalo Schifrin. (If the performances don't put a chill down your spine, the score most definitely will!)I really can't imagine anyone ever making another thriller as exciting and satisfying as this one.

reviews.review_title: You've got to ask yourself a question - Have you seen this film?
reviews.content: Dirty Harry surely remains on of the most iconic films of all time, even if it's not the best. Clint Eastwood become an icon and achieved film immortality with his role as the dirtiest police officer in film history as he faces one of film's best villains in a race against time. 'Dirty' Harry Callahan is a San Francisco cop with a difference - he's warped, perhaps even psychotic. Because of that, the police tend to keep him reserved for the most diabolical cases where they need a man who will bend the rules to get the job done (hence 'Dirty' - every dirty job that comes his way). After the precision shooting of a woman, Dirty Harry is assigned to the case. He soon finds out that there is a serial killer on the loose, who wants money to stop killing. The serial killer, known as Scorpio (Andrew Robinson), is a psychopath who knows no pity or remorse. When the city doesn't pay, he starts killing. Dirty Harry knows that the man won't stop, but is hampered by a flawed law system. A girl is then kidnapped and supposedly buried alive, and Dirty Harry lets lost his own psychotic side - one that matches Scorpio's. There are many messages in this film about the law, police officers, killers. But at a basic level, this film asks a very good question - what happens if a child is buried alive, has 5 hours to live and you know who the kidnapper is? That's the basic question asked. Harry goes much further than the law allows him, which in turn raises questions about the flawed law system, but also about why the police would hire someone like Harry in the first place. Is he literally hired to clean up the law's mess, or failures? Does he represent a total failure in the law system?The acting in this film is second to none. Clint Eastwood is perfectly cast as the ruthless Dirty Harry, and gives one of his truly iconic performances. He is then matched by the exceptional Andrew Robinson, who acted Scorpio so well that he received death threats in real life - he creates a character that you absolutely hate beyond all reason. And the direction and action in turn matches the acting. Don Siegel's relentless, level-headed direction keeps the action grounded and realistic. And the shot where Harry is waiting on the bridge for Scorpio is one of the best in cinema. Overall, this film is very, very good and iconic. Sometimes, the message is lost in the violence, or it becomes muddled. But it's enough to make you question the law system, and whether it's effective or not. And it's also enough to question how anyone would respond in desperation.

reviews.review_title: I can't get past the logical nonsense
reviews.content: I've tried to put myself in the 70s and watch this through that time but just I can't get there with this one. This to me is basically cult cheesy, and I can't get past the terrible sound, completely irrational logic, and utter ridiculousness. For example (aside from police letting a killer walk in fthe first place): There was a promise of no molestation of the terrorist (it literally says that). Dirty Harry couldn't resist molesting the terrorist via school bus anyway (and we had to combine molesting with a school bus stunt really? Is that meant to be ironic somehow??). Plus, it's the 70s. There wasn't any technology available letting anyone know that it was an OK time for a cop off his rocker to take a dive onto a bus full of kids who were happily harboring a terrorist who was participating with them in a really annoying sing along.Is it quotable? sure. But in a way where I'm making fun, not because I'm overcome with awesomeness.I know I will get crap for this review but it's how I feel. Not just because it's old, I like some old movies. It's because it's really just ridiculous to me. I don't like 99% of middlebrow movies that come out during any time period so that's likely why I don't like Dirty Harry.

Cinematography was great showing the many areas of San Francisco.Clint Eastwood was great as Dirty Harry but a lot of credit also has to go to Andrew Robinson (from Deep Space 9 fame as Garak) who was fantastic as the psychotic Scorpio.While the one shot kills with a .44 magnum were a little over the top and the music might seem a little dated, don't let it put you off to a great cop movie.

reviews.review_title: "Shouldn't They Have Left Well Enough Alone?" (Not a Spoiler)
reviews.content: In my opinion Clint Eastwood's performance as "Dirty Harry Callahan", in this film, is as good or better than any other in his career. This includes his role in "Unforgiven" for which he received an Oscar Nomination for Best Actor in a Leading Role. Those of you who have, thus far, and plan to continue to avoid this flick based on the myriad of dreadful sequels that followed don't! This is a very good crime drama.Trust me, there are no scenes where Eastwood walks down the middle of the street picking off armed criminals who are mesmerized on the sidelines like sitting ducks. As a matter of fact, he is actually quite vulnerable in a number of scenes. A good example is when four out of shape middle aged guys mistake him for a peeping tom. They nearly beat him senseless before his partner arrives on the scene to break it up. In the sequels I imagine he could have given these guys a stern round of stares, instantly sending each and every one of them into a coma.Andrew Robinson plays the role of the psychopath to a tee; his character is intriguing and genuinely creepy. The only thing that really bothered me about the story was one particular scene where a debate ensues between Eastwood's character and the district attorney, regarding probable cause versus the rights of the criminal. Based on what little I know about the law, Harry was at least partially right! Even if you're not fond of him, in any capacity, I think most of us have come to terms with the fact that Clint Eastwood is a better suited to direct films as opposed to acting in them, particularly at this point in his career.I'm sure that the sequels to "Dirty Harry" made millions, and in Hollywood you can't argue with that. Unfortunately in the process they tainted the reputation of a pretty good film.
